I wanted the blue one sold out twice im still gonna buy it from Huwaei if i have to they offer a swag bag deal tripod special case, so ill wait n see if Amazon gets the blue one back. Screen size is awesome speed is fast dual sim use one for a 256 gig sd card from samsung overall this is the best deal i hope Amazon gets the red valentines day edition when it comes out. great buy go out and buy this phone oreo 8.0 is out real soon so great deal.This is an update the screen lags a bit when scrolling up or down in apps hope this is fixed soon.
reviews.review_header: but this phone is sexy and beautiful. I wanted the blue one sold out twice ...

reviews.review_text: I love this phone! It's my second $200 phone (the first was the galaxy j7 prime) and this one is miles better. The camera is much better and that was my biggest concern. The screen is really big but it's still easy to use one-handed. The fingerprint scanner is incredibly well placed and works immediately every time. The battery also easily lasts all day and I'm on my phone constantly. Something kind of funny is that the stock keyboard come with what I assume is Chinese emojis and they're hilarious. I originally came from the galaxy s7 edge and this phone really doesn't feel like that much of a step down for saving $700 dollars. The camera isn't as good but that's a lot of money too pay for a camera. As you can tell, I've been a Samsung girl for a while and switching to an almost stock Android has been great. I always thought I liked the little changes Samsung made but now I think they would just get in the way. There are a few cons. First is that you need to either put the free case on it or get a screen protector immediately. The corners of the front screen got scratched up after having the phone for less than a day just from setting it face down on tables. Also, Snapchat occasionally runs slow. And finally, I would suggest resetting your phone every so often because it does get bogged down sometimes.

UPDATE (2/18/18): After having the phone 1 month, the one nit I have is with Android Auto on my Volt. Sometimes the 7x has problems keeping up (i.e. map screen is blank). The remedy is to reboot. But, I've had a love-hate relationship with Android Auto on my Nexus 6p too - not this particular problem but enough other things that makes me wonder how much real testing is done on the app. So, it's hard to say if it's the 7x or Google. ORIGINAL REVIEW: Unfortunately, my previous phone, the Nexus 6P (which was also Huawei-built) entered into the boot-loop of death this last weekend and I needed to get a new phone. Settling on a new phone is a life-decision for me because it's with me more than anything else that I own. I was looking for a short-term phone before the upcoming Galaxy 9 announcement and decided on the Honor 7x because of the reviews - the 7x was oxymoronically termed the "premium budget" phone. Once I bought a new flagship, I'd let the Honor 7x become a backup phone. Wow - I was not expecting this phone. What's great * Built Quality - it feels like a flagship * Snappy performance - enough said * Headphone jack - I'm a big user of bluetooth, but many times I don't want the hassle * Included case - another $20 that I don't need to spend * MicroSD slot - I like the option of more memory without having to pay extortion pricing for embedded memory * Low phone stress: At this price, I don't need to guard this phone like a Faberge egg (yes, I had to look up the spelling for that) What's not great and why it doesn't matter to me (i.e. would I pay an additional $400+ to get these features) * No Type-C: Yes, I'm trying to standardize on this but I've got plenty of microUSB devices now. I'm living in a mixed charger world for a while so I'm okay with it (but only this time) * Not OLED: Yes, my Nexus 6P was brighter. But, fixing a cracked OLED cost more than this phone (so I lived with a cracked screen) * Camera: I'm sure the camera isn't as good as the flagships but it doesn't move my $400 needle * Bezel - it has a small bezel. Who cares. * No fast charging: You need fast charging when your battery can't get you through the day - this battery will more than get you through the day * No 5GHz WiFi radio: It's loading apps and streaming videos plenty fast for me now. * No NFC: Since I can't depend on vendors accepting Android Pay, I've always got my credit cards with me. * Not waterproof: I'll just continue to be careful with the phone. * Not SnapDragon latest: As long as the performance is good - it doesn't matter. * I can't remember how to spell Hawui: But, I feel superior to others in that I can pronounce it. What's not great and may not matter to you: * Comes with Android 7, not Andriod 8. Given that only .2% of devices were on 8 you probably don't care about this. For me, it's inexcusable for a manufacturer to release a phone on an old OS. This is why when I transitioned from Apple to Android, I settled on the Google Nexus because I knew I would always get the latest. As a tech enthusiast, when I read about a new software feature that's available, I need to have it. But, the reality is that, unlike the old days when new major versions of OS's contained exciting and life-altering features, the last set of major releases have been kind of a yawn-fest. But, it's still important to me and how Huewai keeps pace with the latest releases will be a factor if I choose them again. Summing it up, great phone at a fantastic price. I would pay more if I needed to, but with the Honor 7x, it don't. IMHO, if you are buying a flagship phone from Samsung/Apple/Google, you're making a fashion statement. (but, I'll let you know if I change my opinion)
reviews.review_header: The Honor 7x has reset how much I will pay for a phone

reviews.review_text: I have been an iphone fanatic for many years now, and while I still love their products, the iPhone X left me disappointed. The phones have just gotten so expensive and it seemed like there were some really cool phones available at a fraction of the price so i decided to take a gamble and try out the Honor 7x and I have to say that so far I have been incredibly impressed with how good this phone is! I think it is important to keep in mind that the phone is still $200 so of course things like its camera and processor won't compare flagship offerings such as the iPhone, Galaxy S8, or Pixel. However, the difference between this and those phones is very small considering the price difference and using a phone like this has made me skeptical of whether I can ever pay 1000 for a phone again. Below I have included the things that stood out the most to me while using the phone: Pros -Price: this phone is $200, but it feels like a much more expensive phone! You can buy 4 of these for the price of most flagship phones! -Design: feels like a premium model, similar design to the iPhone 7+ but with almost no bezel, really beautiful to hold and the metallic build makes it feel nice while holding -Micro SD Slot: one of the biggest advantages of using an android phone over an iPhone, so convenient to be able to expand your memory (especially now that you can download netflix and amazon prime movies) -Unlocked: always awesome to have an unlocked phone that you can easily travel with and the phone even includes dual sim capability so you don't have to swap multiple sim cards if you travel often -Screen: the screen looks great! the design is beautiful, it's awesome that there are almost no bezels (videos and pictures look fantastic) -Fingerprint Reader: the fingerprint reader works very quickly and consistently and I love the placement on the back of the phone. It's also really cool how its functions can be customized (so you can do things like snap a selfie with the fingerprint reader) -Performance: I wouldn't compare the speed of this to an expensive flagship, but so far I have noticed no issues with lag or slow downs while multitasking (im not a heavy gamer so not sure how that would perform) -Headphone Jack: still such a convenient way to use any pair of headphones you want and its still so nice to be able to easily plug your phone into your car or into some speakers at a party using an auxiliary cable -Battery Life: the battery life so far has been great, I have been able to easily get through a day and a half without having to recharge -Protective Case: comes with it's own clear protective gel case, nothing too fancy, but it's nice and slim and its really cool that it was included with the phone Cons -No USB C: For being a phone released in 2018 it was very sad to see that the phone still used a micro usb connection -No Water Resistance: having been using an iPhone 7 for a while it had become very comfortable to know that my phone could survive smaller water accidents -No NFC: not a feature I use too too much, but may be annoying for some people -Camera Quality: this is the main thing that would still make me invest in a more expensive phone. I use my phone camera alot and would really want something that is better quality and more reliable
reviews.review_header: Amazing value!!! Can't believe how many features are included in such a cheap phone!

reviews.review_text: DAY 4 UPDATES --------------------- I have mixed feelings (still positive though) about this phone knowing fully well that it's not a flagship phone and expectations should be toned down accordingly. Here are a few more updates - Battery life: have uploaded three more pictures that show the Screen On Time (it's amount of time screen was on and in use with battery starting at 100% and discharging to almost 0%). In my case, the battery discharged to 5% and the SOT was 4 hr 13 mins approx. This is not bad but it's not good either given the battery capacity. This is running the screen at 50% brightness, not running power saving mode and using the phone to play a couple of heavy games, watching youtube video, browsing and then some social media (all in all that's typical of an average user) - Performance: This is also mixed. I played Asphault 8 for about 10 minutes. The battery drained faster which is expected but the phone also became hot (backside upper part). Without the case, it felt hotter. The performance after this was not good at all, perhaps because the processor was throttled due to it being hot. Without playing games, the phone performs good but after playing a heavy game, it didn't perform well - apps took longer time to open and there was stutter in scrolling too - Bluetooth: it was easy to connect to any bluetooth enabled device once the phone had bluetooth on so it's all good here. However the issue was trying to switch on bluetooth from the pulldown menu. At least in my unit, it didn't work though I tried multiple times. Maybe it's a software defect. Will keep on trying. - Selfie Camera: this can be easily put in good category. The selfie camera to me at least pulled in better pictures than my iPhone 7 plus in day time and in dim light past evening. That's a major plus so happy with that. - Sound quality through headphone jack: it was good, infact very good. I tried the AKG earphones that came with Galaxy Note 8 and the sound quality was at par with Note 8. So happy with it I'll certainly lower the rating from 4.5 to 4 with the processor throttling and bluetooth switch on issue. Otherwise the experience has been good so far. DAY 1 UPDATES --------------------- I have always had flagship phones but was looking for a backup phone and thought that this would be a good candidate. I received this phone today so posting this review based on my initial impression of it. Will keep it very simple - what's in the box, what's there to like about this phone, what's not so good about the phone WHAT'S IN THE BOX - Phone with 5.93 inch display, IPS LCD panel - Charging brick and micro-USB cable - A TPU transparent case - SIM ejector tool Note: like other Huawei phones, was expecting that this phone will have a pre-installed screen protector but there isn't one WHAT'S THERE TO LIKE ABOUT THIS PHONE - Build Quality: it's excellent to say the least. Holding this you can't say that this is a $200 phone. It has a premium solid feel with no flex. Metal on the back and gorilla glass on the front - Looks: the phone looks good with aluminium back that is blue (check out the pictures). From the front too, it looks and feels modern and follows the current trend of 18:9 aspect ratio. - Fingerprint sensor: It's lightening fast and has always worked up until now. So overall very good - 3.5 mm audio jack: it's there. Putting this in the things to like section because even the most premium and expensive phones don't have this now. Example, iPhone, Huawei Mate 10 Pro, Google Pixel so it's really a luxury now-a-days - Software: this can be subjective for a lot of people but I do like EMUI software. The version is 5.1 which is not the latest but still EMUI is a good skin because it feels like a good mix of iPhone and Android (am a fan of iOS and this is a good mix) - Call Quality: It's very good. I am using T-mobile and getting a good signal in my area. It's comparable to my Galaxy Note 8. - Sound quality through bottom firing speaker: Again at this price, would definitely say that that sound quality is good. There's just one bottom firing speaker but its plenty loud. Not a lot of bass but enough clarity WHAT'S NOT SO GOOD ABOUT THIS PHONE - Rear Camera at night: I have taken just a few shots from this camera, mostly night time - a few of them indoor and a few of them outdoor. In both cases the images are falling apart. Indoor images have a blur so unless you hold the phone steady, you won't get a nice shot. Outdoor it doesn't capture enough light and the results are grainy photos. Will try to post some samples. - Use of micro-USB port for charging: In this day and age of USB type C, this phone comes with micro-USB. No way a deal breaker though. There's no fast charging but again with the price, it's ok A few more things: - Battery life: Though I have used this for a short period of time, the battery life at least for now appears to be good. After a couple of days, it would be possible to put this in the above two categories - Performance: This phone comes with Andoid Nougat and not the latest Oreo. It's a bit slower than flagship phones maybe due to the processor being mid-range. I know this phone shouldn't be compared with a flagship phone. - Rear camera in day time: yet to be tested during the day, will try to post some sample pictures - Selfie camera: yet to be tested both in day time and night time so would update in next few days - Sound Quality through headphone jack: would be able to update in next few days I would have rated this 4.5 given that it's not a flagship phone but that's not an option. In the end rated this as 4 because it's a bit behind in terms of both camera and performance
reviews.review_header: A good phone with a lot to like about it ... (updated)

reviews.review_text: I have Cricket and after being through several of their phones in four months, I figured I had nothing left to lose. This thing is great!! It downloaded my 3 banking apps, credit card app, credit karma, Facebook, messenger, and pages all under six minutes. The UI is quite pleasant, as is all of the customization you can do to the phone itself. It's speedy and efficient, and feels like an expensive phone. No wonder Huawei is so big in Europe and India. UPDATE: After a month of heavy use I still enjoy this phone. It can be a little laggy and get hot if I'm running too many apps. I am pleased to say that it isn't glitchy often at all; it has only froze on me once. No dropped call complaints, and everything is clear and still running well. UPDATE: Here we are, April 4th and my Bluetooth doesn't work. The phone has been in a case and screen protector since day one. It's a huge shame I need Bluetooth for my business and after less than three full months of use a critical part of something for me is now broken.
reviews.review_header: Actually, this is a load of crap.

reviews.review_text: TL;DR: Great bang for the buck. The screen is solid enough, providing "true" colors, viewing angles a bit weak. Overall call quality is decent. The exterior design is modern, looks like a flagship device, thin bezels, however, a bit uncomfortable to hold, wish it was more curvy. Performance is great for the price to performance ratio, wish it came with 4 GB of RAM, like what the international model has... Camera is great for this price range, strong in good lighting, a tad weak in lower lighting. Wish the overlay of EMUI was closer to stock Android. After much frustrations with the limitations of my Moto G, trying to run two apps at a time, it was time for a much needed upgrade. I'm not a "power user" when it comes to phones, I just need something that works for casual use, and that can be a handy tool. For $200, you're getting a lot of phone, thanks to the popularity of the Moto G, phones entering in the mid range market with a lot of bang for the buck, and Honor 7x so far has shown that is what it intends to do. The design of the phone looks as well as those high end phones 2 to 3 times the price, and the screen, camera and performance isn't so far off from those flagships. The screen being at 1080p, and nearing 6 inches is still very crisp, the viewing angles are a bit weak, and the colors are not as "poppy" as more expensive options, however... the colors seem to be "true" and not exaggerated, which I personally like. I'm glad this phone stuck to 1080p, I feel like the higher resolutions showing up on phones are not really needed, and just impact the overall performance, and battery life. Motorola phones, always had awesome call quality, I expect my phone to actually be able to function as a phone, crisp voices, incoming and outgoing, but for some reason, many phones fail at this, *cough* iPhones *cough.* The call quality on this Honor 7x is not that bad, could it be better? Yes. It works, it's crisp enough, it does sound better than some higher priced phones for sure, but it's not at the same level as Motorola phones. The exterior design takes some elements of the iPhone 6, in fact a bit too much to be fair, this could be a plus for some, a negative for others. Although it looks nice, and modern, I hate the flat design; it's somewhat uncomfortable to hold, might as well hold a brick, the first 3 generations of Moto E, G, X had it right with the curves that blend with the hand, I wish more manufactures took this approach to design. The performance of the phone is pretty snappy, no complaints for the price. I've been hitting my head against the wall using my Moto G the last year. It's really nice to be able to go through multiple applications, and not get hold ups, I really hope the 3 GB of RAM can hold up for at least 2-3 years, I'm a bit bummed that the U.S. model didn't get 4 GB of RAM like the international model(s). Cameras aren't super important to me, I don't have the desire to take a picture of every food dish I eat, of every tree I see, ect... I think for those moments I need to take a picture of video, the camera does pretty well; in good lighting, the camera does a great job, in lower level lighting, it's a bit weak. Compared to the god awful camera I've been using on the Moto G, this is personally a big (MASSIVE) upgrade in quality. I like to start off with a pure, or nearly pure stock Android, I'm not a big fan of skins over Android, most of them impact performance, and always seem a bit messy in terms of U.I. EMUI adds nothing for me, I don't know if I will eventually root this phone and clean it up, and/or install a custom ROM, if any actually get made and working... For now, I just uninstalled any of the bloatware apps I could, and disabled the ones I don't use, replaced the EMUI stock launcher with Nova launcher, and added a bit of my own personal touch. I wish after all the bloat manufactures add to there custom skin, I wish that they would have a setting where you could not only customize your navigation keys, BUT FREAKING RESIZE THEM!!! In fact, I wish Google actually would add that setting to begin with… Honor(Huawei) if your listening! Two features I would add to the software experience is the resizing of the navigation keys, and navigation gestures to the fingerprint sensor: swipe left to go back, swipe right to go to recent apps, swipe up to go home. Overall, great device, I'm glad I decided to purchase it, rather than going with a Moto G5 plus. Hopefully the device will last me for at least 2-3 years without much headache.

I still get $350 left for other proposes. The look of the phone is amazing, Much better than iPhone 7 plus. As well the screen is larger. The Fingerprint lock is so good which can unlock phone fast and correctly. The fingerprint lock on old iPhones are just too slow and keep failing. The processor on the phone is much faster than my old iPhone. Apps response fast. I guess the phone is the key for huawei to open the us market. Great phones with really low price. I wish I could give this phone 4.5 stars. It's not perfect but for $200 it's pretty close. The build is solid and the screen is suprisingly good. I wasn't expecting much for the price so it has exceeded my expectations. The only thing it doesn't have that I wish it did is fast charging. I haven't had it long enough to say how big a deal that is but it sure would have been nice. The other odd quirk I've found is that you can't transfer apps to the SD card. They said it will release on Jan 25 when i pre-order it in Dec last year, but I got it Jan 24. this is the best smart phone I have ever had. for the price and quality, it is nothing to compain about. Some useful info.: 1. this phone came with a clear rubber case, so if you are not really care about the personality, the case is quite good. 2, there is curve on either side, so if you buy the screen protector, it may not easy to install. 3. it only support NANO sim card, NOT the micro sim card, so i need to change to a new card. 4. use the small pin provided to push out the side slot for SIM and microSD card. 5. support Daul sim card
reviews.review_header: this is the best smart phone I have ever had

reviews.review_text: If you have read any of my other reviews, you know I like phones and test drive MANY in search of really good phones, were kind of s phone family. Having said that, I am a Huawei fan since the Mate 2. They just build good phones for an incredible price. We have owned all the high end Mates and everything since the Honor 5 to this phone, the 7x. I say that to say, I don't mind paying more for a good phone...but the Honor line has made it so I don't have to pay more for a quality phone with really good specs. I never would have imagined a $200 phone could be this good. The photos are a side by side comparison to the Honor 5, for size comparison. The first thing I noticed about this phone is how remarkably thin it is for an almost 6 inch screen, with three cameras (two on back, one forward facing) It's much lighter and thinner than the 5, yet feels more solid in the hand. This phone has a nice large battery and I'm sure it will last my husband all day, with moderate text and web use. It uses a micro USB charger, which is fine for most people who still have a ton of micro USB chargers around (I personally prefer type C, but my husband hates change and likes the micro USB). Even though the screen is almost 6 inches, it doesn't feel too large..and definitely feels smaller than my Mate 9. The screen is bright and the resolution looks great. ALL my husband's apps and data transferred over (all 64 apps) within 16 minutes with the phone clone app that Huawei uses for data and app transfer. The phone is super fast and switched between apps quickly with no freezing or lag (yet). The UI is typical Huawei, but you can download the google launcher or other launcher of your choice to give a more familiar feel. We use cricket (which is AT&T prepaid) and had no issues with the APN, it configured automatically. Placed a call and the sound was good and definitely loud enough on speaker. The camera is good...it's not the Mate 9 Leica but it's good and I didn't feel the need to mess with any settings. Is plenty good for social media pics, selfies and pics of the kids, pets, life's most embarrassing moments, etc. It still has a headphone jack, which I prefer to an adapter or even wireless. The finger print sensor is lightning fast and works before you even realize you have pressed your finger against the sensor. Not too much bloatware, certainly not as much as carrier locked phones! It has 64 GB of space, AND room for a memory card. Comes with Android 8 which is pretty similar to 7, but nice to have updated out of the box. It encrypts the SD card so be aware if you choose this option that you won't be able to just pop your SD card out of this phone and into another without changing the settings. Time will tell, but based on prior experience with Huawei, as well an Apple, Samsung and various bargain phones, I believe this is another keeper! It's a shame AT&T backed out of the deal to bring this phone to the carrier, but it may work to the consumers advantage by keeping prices competitive. DAY THREE of heavy use and no glitches, lagging, freezing or resets. Love this phone more worth each passing day.

Had this phone for just over a week now and I can honestly say that I have zero complaints. It does exactly what I wanted and then some. I was previously using "BLU" phones and after quite a bit of researched decided to switch over. Where as my BLU phone was sluggish and laggy this phone is fast and takes almost no time to load anything I ask of it. I also really really love the double screen feature it has. The camera could be better, but the pros definitely outweigh the cons for this gem.
reviews.review_header: I also really really love the double screen feature it has

reviews.review_text: For $200 this phone is a absolutely a bargain. Pros: battery last long, screen are big resolution are good.... Cons: no 5G WiFi and speaker is a little weak, no Android 8.0 yet. other than that its a perfect one for the budget I'm really happy that I bought it.
reviews.review_header: Good phone for the price for sure

reviews.review_text: I've owned the Honor 6x in the past, and since it worked for me I was pretty confident the 7x would be no different. With prices of phones getting higher and higher I was looking for something that wasn't so expensive; I'd just returned the Mate 10 Pro for this very reason and decided to stick with Honor/Huawei. I love that it gets VoLTE on my carrier (T-mobile), and that it includes a case in the box - definitely something other phone companies need to do. The handfeel is a HUGE improvement over the 6x, and though it's not what the market considers premium (glass) I like that if I went without a case the device would probably be ok too. So far battery life has been about what my 6x was able to do, and for my usage/needs that's more than enough - I can get through a day in with 60% remaining, and that suites me just fine. I'm not a gamer, my apps are mostly time killers/utility apps, but I haven't had the device slow when switching or freeze while trying to load something. EMUI isn't something that's a deal breaker for me, in fact I love that it has features that I sometimes have to unlock with an app or ADB on other devices (night mode, fingerprint scanner gestures, mobile hotspot toggle, data toggle, etc); about the only thing I wish it would include is the ability to load customer icons and/or make the default icons smaller. Overall for what I paid for the phone I'm extremely satisfied right now, even if it does get an Android 8.0 update I'll still consider this money well spent as the feature set is pretty killer. There's some good competition in this space, so definitely look around but I'm happy with my purchase.
reviews.review_header: Feels so much better than the 6x!

reviews.review_text: I have been using the iPhone since the beginning. I have never owned an Android device so I can’t compare it to others. I even have the iPhone X. The reason I purchased this was I wanted a phone with dual sims. I hate carrying around two devices. I did a lot of research and wanted a good value. This phone fit the bill. It will work with any gsm network. T-Mobile, AT&T and other prepaid gsm providers in the US. Pros- Fingerprint sensor is lighting fast! Camera is pretty good. Screen looks great The phone is pretty snappy as far as speed. No real lag. I am using the stock software and from what I have read installing different launchers can slow it down. Cons- No 5ghz WiFi. No fast charge, it takes a long time to fully charge. No wifi calling Second sim only 2G, you can still text but I don’t know if it can handle picture messages on 2G No native mail app. You must use a third party mail app. Yahoo, google. I think it has some form of ad software installed. The usb connection to most new car radios does not allow you to play music or streaming apps from the phone. That can only be done with Bluetooth. This might just be an Android thing and not a phone thing. My iPhones have always worked with the usb connection. Android messages.. this is by far the worst feature of an Android phone. There is no comparison to iMessage on the iPhone. It has limited features and a character limit.. seriously? Its 2018 and text are limited to 160 characters 🙄. If you are a heavy texter which I am not, Android isn’t for you if you are coming from an iPhone. I guess some of my review is about the Android 7 OS. 😂 I feel like I am using Windoze again. It’s not too bad but If you are tech savvy you can figure it out. I’ll keep using it for a couple of weeks and if my opinion changes I’ll update my review. If you are looking for a good value then this is the phone for you. For $200, you can’t go wrong. UPDATE.. Well, I spoke to soon.. I am returning the phone. It is now locking up. I have to constantly reboot it, I have had to reset it and when I install a few apps it starts happening again. I am guessing it’s the Android OS that is the problem but.. if the OS won’t run correctly it doesn’t matter how good the hardware is. I am not a gamer or a frequent texter.. I do use a few social media apps and shopping apps, that’s about it.. still a good value if you can deal with the android OS.
reviews.review_header: I am a diehard iPhone user.

reviews.review_text: The Honor 7X is a great device, you're getting a lot of value for the price. Compared to other smartphones within the price range, the Honor 7X is a no-brainer. I was planning to wait until Motorola announced the Moto G6. And I even considered getting the Moto G5 Plus since it's on sale. But with everything happening to Motorola recently, who knows what their future is. Huawei did launch the Mate SE out of no where recently, but the extra $50 for the exact same specs other than the extra gig of ram and doubled storage isn't worth it for me since it still launched with Nougat, still uses micro usb, and I use a 64GB micro SD card anyways. Back to the 7X, I did have this phone originally in black, but due to a hardware defect, I sent it back and ordered it in blue since it was the only color that was in stock. And to be honest, I should have went with the blue color in the first place, it's so nice! And blue's not even my favorite color! It's darker than what's pictured, almost like a navy blue. Having owned the black version of the 7X prior as well as many other black devices previously, the blue definitely adds more style to the device, along with the gray lines on the back. If you're undecided on which color to get, I recommend the blue color! It's a very nice and unique color for a smartphone. The screen is big and crisp, audio is clear, and build quality is definitely a step up from the older Honor 6X. The battery lasts me a full day and I still have about 40% left before the day ends, even with normal usage (facebook, youtube, chrome, reddit, 9GAG, etc.). I don't really play resource hungry games on my phone. And I do like my screen rather bright, so the battery is very good. The camera also got a noticeable upgrade. The camera features and aperture effect are great as they were in the 6X! The downloadable themes and customizable LED notification light are also always pluses for me. I have had zero issues with performance or touch responsiveness on my 7X. There are however, a couple of issues that I would like to address about the Honor 7X. First, the device seems to make a rattle noise when it is tapped or knocked on in the upper half on the back. Now that I've owned 2 of these devices, I am certain that this is normal and nothing is loose inside the phone. Nothing major, just a minor annoyance. Second, the current update B140 has an issue where the screen dims automatically whenever you open an app with a white background. Even with auto brightness disabled. The only way to remedy that issue is turning up the brightness to about 90%, which is what I run mine at anyways. I am unsure if Honor knows about this issue and if they will fix it. A lot of users though, have this same issue. It even occurs in the new Mate SE. So it's definitely a EMUI bug that needs to be addressed and fixed. I owned the Honor 6X just 4 months before getting this new version, the 7X. But I definitely should have waited. If you have a 6X and are happy with it, hold off until the 7X gets the official Oreo and EMUI 8 updates. If you need a new phone though, I'd say go ahead and grab the 7X, it's hard to beat for $200!
reviews.review_header: A decent upgrade with some flaws. If you have the Honor 6X, hold off on this one for a while.

reviews.review_text: It is a perfect phone ever. I have briefly used honor 6x preciously, but not impressed that time because of the low end body and laggy performance. This time I decided to give it another try due to the shiny body and ovehemeingly good review. It really didn't dispoint me this time. The display is even better than I thought when I got the phone. I have heard view angle issue of phone but I don't see anything noticeable. Clarity of display are top notch!! Even feel better than iPhone 7 or 8. The performance is greatly improved from last generation. What is even better is it flies after I turned on developer option and limit the background process. I haven't tried the camera seriously, it is ok. But if care about camera, it is not the phone for you. I don't really have too much cons for it. The micro USB ports, lack of fast charge don't seem like a problem because I have plenty of old cable and battery is well enough for serious one day use. One con I have is that edge of the screen is not very sensitive , but not a big issue to me. So seriously, even without considering the fact of price, it is still a perfect daily driver phone.
reviews.review_header: It is a perfect phone ever

reviews.review_text: I absolutely love this phone. The value is tremendous. Phone is very quick and I've only experienced lag on poorly optimized apps (not the phone's fault). This is actually my first Android phone, and switched because I couldn't afford Apple anymore. I always enjoyed the iPhone look so EMUI is very nice. All of the default apps are great. Battery is great and usually lasts a little under a day and a half for me. The camera isn't amazing, but good for the price point. With such a low price I could always buy a professional camera and still spend less than I would if I were to purchase a flagship phone from Samsung or Apple.
reviews.review_header: Great phone for a great price.

reviews.review_text: I bought this phone after finally having to give up on my iPhone 6's battery life. That thing barely lasted half a day and if I used something heavy like maps, it would be instant death. I wasn't sure what to expect from this phone, but I couldn't afford a pricey iPhone X or Google Pixel. I have been so far pleasantly surprised. I'd say this phone works better and faster than my old iPhone ever did. I can now open apps and type words into search bars without it having to think about it and my battery lasts all day long. It's also extremely touch sensitive, something I had to get used to after my less touch sensitive iPhone. I can't say good enough things about this phone. The only downside is the screen will be less crisp than a more expensive one and the camera isn't top of the line crystal clear. I've added a photo to give you an idea. Still this phone is great and definitely is an exception to you get what you pay for. More phones should be this reasonably priced. I will recommend to everyone who wants a new phone that feels like an expensive top of the line one but can't afford it. Also I had cricket and switching over was as easy as taking my SIM card out of my iPhone and putting it in this one.
reviews.review_header: Great phone, great price, well worth it!

reviews.review_text: Been awaiting delivery of the Honor 7x for a couple weeks now. Just for comparison sake, I owned a OnePlus 3T prior to picking up this phone. The OnePlus was slowing down quite a bit, so I sold it and took a portion of the proceeds and gave the Honor 7x a try. I owned the Honor 5x a few years ago, and had a decent experience with it. Like I said, so far, so great. I'm only 6 hours into the experience, but I can say that this is one impressive phone for the price. I did quite a bit of homework before purchasing and was between a few devices, but this was the only one under $300 that I was considering. The screen ratio is one of the best aspects of the phone. The build is solid and the software layer is pretty usable. I haven't yet needed to go to Nova. If you put this in front of anyone with a bit of knowledge about the landscape of phones out there, I would bet they would guess that this phone is priced between $300-$400. Will update after a week of use. Don't hesitate...buy, buy, buy!

Great phone, so my experience with phones has been around the budget area since I previously owned a Asus Zenphone 2 and a Samsung galaxy mini. So what you want to know are the Cons of the phone since everyone else has already explained all the Pros. However one thing that did shock me was how good the fingerprint reader was 10/10 so fast. So onto Cons. Cons- VIBRATION SUCKS, like damn this motor is weak af, good thing the sound is loud enough Lot of bloat with the phone Camera is fine not great not bad Heavy skin of Emui but its not too in your face (Micro usb is maybe a con for some but I have a ton of old cables so its nice not having to buy new ones) Overall my second $200 dollar phone and compared to the zenphone out of the box, its not anything to blow your mind performance wise but right away it feels and looks SO much more premium alike something that would cost $500 bucks. If your looking into this phone right now I definitely recommend getting it if your budget is similar to mine or if you need a cheap phone. Oh and i'm on T-mobile and it seems to work fine.
reviews.review_header: Great phone, so my experience with phones has been ...

reviews.review_text: Best budget phone out there no doubt, impossible to tell it's 200$

OVERALL - Great phone for the price. As of the date of this review, the phone is hard to beat in this price range. The mid-range processor can handle most app's and games without issue. However, there are some issues that'll be addressed below. SOFTWARE - The software, EMUI 5.1, will definitely leave you polarized. You'll either like it or you won't. It has an iOS look and feel to it. I bought Nova Launcher Prime and use that as the replacement launcher. The Honor 7x is set to receive Android Oreo updates sometime in Q2 2018. HARDWARE - The Honor 7x has Huawei Kirin 695 processor. It's mid-range spec and is definitely capable of handling the day in and day out's of your average consumer. I've been able to play each game I've downloaded flawlessly. My issue is that the phone gets very hot in the back right corner at the top after an hour or more of intensive use such as playing a game, and I'm assuming the processor throttles itself in response to the heat, which will cause a noticeable performance drop. There also seems to be random performance drops unrelated to what app's I'm using or how long I've been using the phone. They're rare but when they do occur, they're very noticeable and annoying. Sometimes app icons will disappear and will only reappear when the performance stabilizes. Other times there is a noticeable delay in starting apps after clicking them. I can't really explain how or why it's happening because I've been unable to recreate the issue intentionally other than when playing an intensive game for an hour or more and letting the phone get very hot. BUILD - The phone is beautiful and feels great in the hand. It's not slippery feeling but is very smooth. It feels very solid. I used to worry with my last phone that if I sat down with it in my back pocket, that I'd bend it. I've no concern of that with this phone. CAMERA - The camera's are average at best. They're not terrible. They're not great. The front-facing camera will get the job done for selfie's as long as you have good lighting. The dual-camera setup on the back is is also decent. With proper lighting and a steady hand, you can get some decent pictures. SCREEN - It's not an AMOLED but that's not really an issue for me. The black's aren't as deep or rich of course, but that's an acceptable loss for this price range. The screen does auto-brighten in day light, which makes it a little more easily used outside. My only complaint is that the screen is very, very sensitive to touch. So sensitive in fact that if I'm scrolling through the app drawer and barely touch the edge of an app icon for even a split second, it'll launch. Coming from an iPhone, the sensitivity difference is going to take getting used to.
reviews.review_header: Great phone, but has some performance issues after extended use.

reviews.review_text: Purchased this phone to replace my father's outdated SS Note 3, and he is quite happy with the upgrade. I've been an iPhone guy since the 3G back in 2008. I have to say this phone has sincerely WOW'd me for the price. I've looked up reviews and knew I was expecting a similar design to my current iPhone 7+, but for $200 I can say the display's quality is similar to my iPhone 7+, the build quality feels similar of an iPhone, the buttons for volume and lock are clicky and satisfying to press and overall better than my iPhone's buttons! (and Honor includes a FREE CLEAR CASE in box vs headphones which has more value to me imo) UMEI is a great skin, it is very iOS-like which felt very familiar out of the box, and great to have the app drawer enabled by default. Seriously the only drawback I can think of is the camera quality, for a dual lens system I was expecting a little more sharpness and color reproduction but I noticed most photos, were lacking in light/color. It gets the job done, but I highly recommend Honor/Huawei to spend the extra $ on their next model and increase the msrp by $20 to include an improved camera module and this would easily replace my iPhone next year. NO NFC so no Android Pay, but my father is very old school and could care less about it, but it could be a dealbreaker for those who frequent contactless payments. But most modern credit/debit cards are going contactless, so there's that. Anyways thanks for creating a great phone for the price Huawei you knocked it out of the park in almost every department in my book.

I am soooo impressed with this smartphone. My previous phone (Nexus 5X) bricked on me after a firmware update and I was need of a phone fast! So I went out looking for the best bang for the bucks but I didn't want to spend more then $250.. I came to the conclusion that whatever phone I buy at that price range will be a used or refurbished one. A little bit of research had me looking into this bad boy and I was truly amazed at the price point. However, I was worried that being a Chinese brand, the quality would suffer (sorry, this myth no longer holds true to me after purchasing this phone and a TCL smart TV). The final step of deciding to purchase this phone came in comparing what I can get instead for the same price range... Nothing came close after hours of research except the Samsung Galaxy S7.. the difference would be that the Galaxy S7 would cost way more for a brand new phone and a refurbished in most cases would also cost more!! Verdict after 2 Weeks with the phone: Truly amazing and I'm not exaggerating. I am actually constantly looking at the phone amazed that I got it at this price. It feels like I'm easily holding a phone that retails upwards of $400 but I got it for half that. If anyone else is on the fence like I was.. jump right over! the grass really is greener on the Honor 7X side ( =
reviews.review_header: So I went out looking for the best bang for the bucks but I didn't want to ...

reviews.review_text: After constantly buying crappy metro phones. I had enough and wanted a better phone that'd last me a while. I saw this phone while looking at the Sony Xperia. Phone looked beautiful but the bezel was too big. Then I saw the honor 7x. I drooled at the features this thing had. I watched videos. Read reviews. Even purposely looked at why you shouldn't buy it the reason weren't enough to make me not want to buy. It came 2-3 days than expected and the box itself looks extremely sexy. The way they have the tape at the bottom so you'll know of someone was in it. Then when it came to opening the box it came off like butter and seeing the phone was an instant nut. It was smooth, had a nice weight, and screen. Mmmamamia it was sleek. When turning it on the UI was amazing. It had an iPhone and Android mix. Forget team Android or iPhone, phone had both. Settings it up was a breeze. Downloading apps. Easy. Then I went to settings to turn on all the cool features. I went straight to looking for the option to expand the screen on any app. I tell you what, with this option my phone looks like any iPhone someone would have. You keep the back of the phone down and nobody would know the difference. This phone is more than awesome especially for only $200. All I have to say is to not download too many apps. It will take up all the Ram and it will start to slow down.
reviews.review_header: This phone will make you insta nut.

reviews.review_text: This is probably the best phone I have ever owned. Coming from a Samsung Galaxy S5 is like going from a Corolla to a Porshe!

For the price there are few cellphones with the amount of features this phone has, the screen is particularly nice as it covers much of the phone, on the back it looks like an Ipod, that may be a good or bad thing depending on the person, it has a real dual camera setup that's good, but not great as there are plenty phones that take better pictures but this one cost a fraction of those In summary this is a great phone specially considering the price and features it has, there is more good than bad Pros: * The Screen with the new Screen Ratio so popular in flagship phones * The Price * There is a clear rubber case included in the Phone * The software has alot of options and it feels quick * Dual Cameras are good but not flagship good * Good Battery Life * Metal Body Cons * No NFC * 5 Ghz Wifi * No Fast Charging
reviews.review_header: Nice Screen, Dual Cameras, Solid Construction

reviews.review_text: I've had this phone over a week now and like it more each day. I had been attached to my HTC One M9 but it had contracted degenerative terminal battery disease; symptoms include spontaneous power off and battery standby of an hour or less. As the disease ran it's inevitable course I knew I had to replace it. Investigation of possible battery transplant offered little hope. The new HTC U11 was way out of my price range also one thing I really wanted was offline FM radio and because wireless companies prefer that you use data it's frequently only on one-off brands and cheap phones. I kept running across the Huawei honor7x. While there are some scathing reviews, there are some scathing reviews for every phone so the percentage of good reviews must be taken into consideration. The screen quality, camera, battery, processor & GPU, my offline FM radio, and Tricorde-resque plethora of sensors, overall build tells me I've made the right decision. Since receiving it Wednesday I've charged it 3 times. I was charging my HTC 3-6 times per day and even that was insufficient. The complaints in the harsher reviews of the Huawei honor7x frequently indicate "lagging" but they also say it's resolved by a reboot, " only to return again at some point in the future. So for a $200 phone with premium features, occasionally one may have to turn it off then on again. THE HORROR!! Others dislike the micro USB vs USB-C. I personally am relieved I don't need to replace my numerous charging cables. Also, complaints about no Qualcomm quick charge. With light to moderate use, the H7X lasts me 3 days between charges. Also, it's 1/4 the price of a premium phone. If they are going to omit something I'm glad it's that. What else? Oh no wireless charging either. While inductive oscillating charging is kinda neat, it's slow, hard on circuitry due to heat and testy, if your device isn't right on the correct spot it doesn't charge so you just put your phone down for a while, which can be a good thing on its own, but it still needs changing. So again, it's$200, and if you feel that strongly about wireless charging you can buy a kit. Personally I think my $200 phone should go to work for me in the morning so I can sleep, keep me sexually gratified and cook my dinner, but that's not what phones do. Conversely, if you are not willing to spend close to $1000 on a phone there are some things that you are going to have to do without. That being said, the H7X isn't really a compromise, you are getting far more for your money in my book! Thank you Huawei! Excellent phone at an excellent value!

This is an awesome phone!!! The price is amazingly low for a high quality device. Performance is great and very fast. Connection to LTE is great as well too. And the screen looks very good. I don't game so i couldn't tell you how it does, but browsing, watching videos, and normal phone functions work flawlessly. This is the best phone in its category for the price by far.
Amazing phone for $200 this is my second one had the 5x now 7x is fast I don't need a$500 phone looks great feels great and fast
reviews.review_header: Amazing phone for $200 this is my second one had ...

reviews.review_text: This is the third Honor xX I have had. My wife and I each got a 5x, I got the 6x while she was still using the 5x. After a departure to other androud devices in the same price range I'm very happy to be back with the Honor brand. My last phone before this was the Revvl... By far the biggest pos I have ever had, and it cost $40 more then the 7x. The new phone is thinner, lighter and easier to use one handed. I'm 6'4' and have pretty big hands. My wife at 5'1" can also single habdes us the phone. I believe it has to do with the new aspect ratio. Seems taller and thinner than the old ones. Fast, bright and beautiful. Don't think you can do much better at the price.
reviews.review_header: After a departure to other androud devices in the same price range I'm very happy to be back with the Honor brand

reviews.review_text: This is a great low budget phone with lots of features. I replaced my Samsung Galaxy S7 Edge with this phone. Since I only use rooted phones, every time I rooted my Galaxy, I would start to experience severe lag times after about 1 month of use or less. I would then have to backup, factory reset and re-setup my phone with all of my hundreds of applications. I have rooted the Honor 7x and so far it is working flawlessly. The only reason for the 4 stars is because Honor has not provided the latest Android system available. I've seen rumors that an update is coming, but no official word from Honor regarding this. A great job to the folks at Honor for producing a great product.
reviews.review_header: This is a great low budget phone with lots of features

reviews.review_text: Just got it today, play with it a little bit,I think it is amazing phone
reviews.review_header: I think it is amazing phone

reviews.review_text: This is a wonderful phone. I'm a tech person and the phone works flawlessly with big ram the screen is very beautiful and big the battery is very large last me about
reviews.review_header: Excellent phone would pay 3-400$ dollars for it

reviews.review_text: This is my first android. I've had an iphone since they came out and I'm coming from a 5C to this 7x. I've had it for about 24 hours now and wow! For 200 bucks you couldn't get a better phone. The screen is huge and beautiful. This definitely isn't a 1 handed phone. I'm not a big gamer at all just some pokemon go. Android took some getting used to at first but I love this phone. My only gripe is the very very limited selection in cases (it does come with a flimsy clear one) but that's the price you pay for a cheap phone. Really though, nothing about this phone seems cheap. I threw on the IQ matte shield for the screen and if you can get phones like this for 200 bucks why would you ever pay 500+ again?
reviews.review_header: For 200 bucks you couldn't get a better phone. The screen is huge and beautiful
reviews.review_author: some other guy Honor Device USA

reviews.review_text: Great display, takes Micro Sd, has Gorilla Glass, & comes with clear case in the box. Very happy with my decision to buy the Honor 7X!

Here’s what I like about this phone: 1) Fingerprint reader - Awesome! It unlocks the phone instantly. Love this feature. 2) The metal casing and heft of the phone feel great on the hand. 3) The 16:9 screen is vibrant and pleasant to the eye. 4) The 16 MP camera - Takes great pictures ( see picture taken with phone) 5) Excellent battery life - I’ve been using it to watch videos, Pandora, taking photos, texting and the battery lasts for more than 1 day. Here are features I wish it had: 1) Fast charging - Although not a deal breaker but nice to have. 2) OLED screen - Perhaps is too much to ask but it would be a nice feature. At this price point, the phone is a great value for the features it has. I would definitely recommend this phone.

Pros: - Nice feel in a hand (like flagship smartphone) - battery life (around 6 hours screen on time - design - everything works great (expect notifications) Cons -notification center is lagging (I hope it will be fixed after updates) - camera lit bit slow and it look like paint, not photo. -no fast charging and USB C port But anyway I'm happy with this smartphone for 200$

Great phone for the price. I definitely miss a few thing about my old phone this one doesn't have. Like copy and paste drawer and it connectivity issue to WiFi and Bluetooth. But for $200 but deal out there

The phone is great quality. Has all the features of the newest phones. My only complaint is the keyboard. Maybe I will figure something out and it's my fault.... But seems like the letters on the edge of the keyboard are hard for it to recognize when I hit them. I do not regret buying the phone. It is amazing and the cost makes it #1 in my book.
I got my phone a day ago, am so in love with it my kids are giving me the wierd look😊
reviews.review_header: am so in love with it my kids are giving me the wierd ...

reviews.review_text: First of all build quality is on par with flagships. Fingerprint reader works great, screen is great and visible in direct sunlight. Battery holds up all day with plenty to spare with non gaming use and the processor is fast. The camera is excellent, it works well in low light and the dual cameras bokeh effect is spot-on. Zero regrets with this purchase.
reviews.review_header: Fingerprint reader works great, screen is great and visible in direct sunlight

reviews.review_text: This is the absolute best phone at the current price mark. If you like multitasking however, depending on the apps you are using, you might have some issues with speed. I used a remote desktop app to control numerous computers while on the phone, and noticed significant lagging. However most phones would be much slower under that kind of workload. For the everyday user, this phone is an amazing buy. Do not listen to people when they say that this phone does not take good pictures and video. Out of the box, it is great for pics and vids. There are plenty of apps that can take the camera to higher levels of quality as well. The only thing I do not like about having this phone is.....Huawei does not issue updates quickly or consistently for the US version of this phone. All other versions seem to get updates, but not the United States version. Outside of this small issue, the phone is a must buy for anyone on a budget. Huawei has the potential to take over the US market, provided our government allows them to make deals with the major phone carriers. Go ahead if you are thinking about this......and buy this phone. You will love it!
reviews.review_header: It's better than other Android phones, and is just as sexy as an iPhone.

reviews.review_text: So far so good. Had this phone for almost 2 weeks and I think it is a good phone. This is an upgrade from Samsung Galaxy S5. I am not a super techy person and am past the point in my life when I was willing to pay big $$ for a flagship phone. I researched phones for awhile and decided to take a chance on the Honor 7X since the predecessor did pretty well. Glad I did. No regrets so far.
reviews.review_header: Good upgrade and nice not to have to remortgage the house for a nice phone

reviews.review_text: Was a sweet pickup until it started having problems after two months. I bought and received the Honor7x in Feb, and writing this review in mid April. I was thinking of writing the review after using it for three months, but it's suddenly been problem after problem. First month went by fine. I enjoyed the camera and it ran fairly smooth. Fingerprint sensor is really quick.. Now for the cons; calls don't last more than 15 minutes before it disconnects and I have to recall. It wasn't a big problem, but now calls won't last a minute. I've been experiencing some strange stutter when switching between basic apps. My phone has also randomly crashed about 4-5 times and just rebooted by itself. Sadly, this is all within only two months. Who knows what else will random start malfunctioning. Nice phone in specs, but save your money and perhaps look elsewhere.
reviews.review_header: Nice for the first month, but money better spent elsewhere.

reviews.review_text: This is the best phone I've ever had, especially for the price. The high resolution makes it so clear. The fingerprint scanner works flawlessly. Haven't played too much with the camera, but with the two pictures I took, they seemed really good. Not the best picture quality obviously, but still really good considering it's a budget phone. The battery life is really good for me. I use it all day throughout work listening to music and podcasts, as well as get on facebook and such during breaks, and when I come home around 5:30pm, I'll stilll have about 50-60% battery left. Seriously, if you can afford the $200, get this phone. Especially if you use a lot apps. I use a lot of apps for school and social media and for digital books. This phone is great.
reviews.review_header: This is the best phone I've ever had

reviews.review_text: Combines a bunch of the newest features in the market and functions wonderfully. Works with Straight talk BYOP,
reviews.review_header: Good nuff for me, I like it

reviews.review_text: UPDATE (3/13/18) - After reluctantly returning to my iPhone 6s, I found the Huawei Mate SE. It has snappy performance and is a better fit for me. My iPhone has been officially retired. UPDATE (2/23/18) - Like this phone in so many ways but the laggy performance has convinced me to return it and keep looking. I've used some version of the iPhone for the past 10 years and never thought I'd switch, but the pricing of flagship models has become ridiculous. After reading several reviews of the Honor 7X, I took the plunge and am so happy I did. I'm definitely not an Android expert nor a power user, but the learning curve has been relatively painless and now that I've got everything set up, I couldn't be happier with my choice. The phone is well built and performs great in every way for my needs. I feel really good about choosing this brand and model... for me, it's perfect.

This is the best phone I have ever owned, comes with a case which is awesome because I'm still waiting for the one I ordered to come in. I have had this phone for two weeks now and I absolutely love it! I was a little concerned because of some of the one star reviews, but I have not experienced and software issues, and have even dropped it on a hard floor once and it did not crack. The case it comes with isn't amazing, but it certainly offers a light to moderate amount of protection against drops. If anyone else finds a great screen protector for this phone please comment below!

reviews.review_text: For the most part this is a nice phone. It looks great, and the fingerprint scanner is really nice and fast. The processor seems snappy so far, but the benchmarks show the GPU is pretty weak. The lack of fast charge and 5g WiFi is a bit of a bummer, but I knew that going in. What I didn't know was that the wifi speed is incredibly slow if you simply have Bluetooth enabled. Speed tests put it under 5 mb with bt on, and over 60 with it off. I'm not sure if it's just my unit, but the audio via Bluetooth is really bad. Tested across three devices and it just has a distorted sound through this one. Wired earbuds sound just fine though. All in all, it's a nice, attractive phone for $200, but the poor wifi with bt on, and the audio via bt makes it feel pretty disappointing for my needs.

I don't know how long it will survive, but the phone is perfect. when you watch video in this phone the quality is not so high. But for this price it is very nice phone. I order one for my mom, and I will order one more for my dad)

reviews.review_text: Great phone, extremely happy with it. Snappy performance for a "so called" budget phone that is borderline flagship quality. Camera takes amazing picture. Build quality is superb. It has some weight to it, you actually know when you are holding it in your hand. Compared to previous phones I have had in the past, this is the best one by far (Note 2, OnePlus One, Moto X Pure, Zenphone 3 Max). This phone still has a headphone jack, which nowadays is considered a premium feature IMHO. The sound quality from listening with headphones is amazing. The lack of NFC shouldn't steer you away since NFC payments aren't status quo yet. Definitely getting the most bang for my buck. Bought a second one for my Daughter

reviews.review_text: This phone is a great value for money. It has proven to very stable, smooth to operate and has great battery time. The camera is reasonable for the price and every other feature I need in a phone meets or exceeds my expectation. The phone feels and functions like a premium phone. I used this for while, gave it out as present to get the Huawei Mate SE Factory Unlocked, that has slightly higher ram and more memory. They exactly work and feel the same. I would be happy with either phone, except the increased 64Bit storage that helps with keeping more local files on phone.

This phone, although having great specs, is very slow. It crashes constantly with even simple applications (i.e. camera, video calling, messenger) and if you have over ten apps running in the background then you may have trouble receiving calls or instant messages as the phone takes too long to respond. Constantly I was unable to receive calls as the screen would freeze being unresponsive to touch. Switching applications is also problematic and forget trying to use maps to get anywhere. Thoroughly disappointed in this purchase. Pros: screen is great and high-quality.

My husband bought this phone for me thinking it would be faster than my last phone. Not only is it slow, but I continually have problems with receiving text messages especially group texts. They just hang up there forever until I go into my settings and put my phone on airplane mode and off for every message that is hung up. This is quite annoying and I hate it. Never had this problem on any other phone I owned. I wonder if it is too late to return it and ask for a refund? It also takes a long time to download long documents and send them. I guess you get what you pay for. Also, have issues with the camera getting hung up and takes awhile to get it set up to take picture, slow, slow, slow.

This phone is replacing a iPhone 6 and I am astounded at how good this 200$ phone is. The screen display is vivid and the size is perfect for youtube, calls/texting is easy and reliable, camera is quick and responsive, and the fingerprint sensor is faster than my girlfriend's Galaxy s8! This exceeded my expectations for a phone and I don't think I can ever go back to paying more than 500 bucks for a phone. Definitely recommend!

Either mine was defective or this has a 10 year old WiFi radio/receiver. I can't stream 480p or lower quality videos more than 10 feet from my router, more than 30 feet from my router websites take 1-2 minutes to load. I have devices hooked up all over my home that have no issues streaming video (Roku, game console, smart TV). I looked online for solutions thinking I have to be doing something wrong. Found a few (disable Bluetooth while streaming, software updates, etc.) but nothing made it better. The display, which reviews indicated was a high point, is bad. Colors look washed out and muted. It has some sharpness to it, but the colors on my 3 year old Samsung J7 look much more vibrant. I tried messing around with all the display settings to no avail, simply can't make it look as good. I give it an extra star because the design of the phone is sleek and the OS seemed snappy, but since it couldn't fulfill the basic promise of outperforming my outdated Samsung J7, it's hard to like much of anything.
reviews.review_header: WiFi signal strength is terrible (don't plan on streaming videos), display colors are washed out

reviews.review_text: Pros: From the software features, of which there are many (go look up videos of things you can do with this phone!), to the beautiful screen, and the lightning fast fingerprint scanner, this phone is the best bang for your buck on the market. It's durable, I've dropped it and had no issues, the aluminium back was scratched, but not very much, and that's to be expected. Cons: Low light environments do not fare well with the phone's camera, however at this price point you can only get so much camera wise. There isn't as much RAM as one would like, the processing power isn't particularly incredible, and not having USB-C is a bit annoying, but once again, you can only get so much at this price point. Overall: I will tentatively say that it is currently the best phone on the market for $200 or less.

reviews.review_text: Mine freezes from time to time but I run alot of big apps at the same time and I understand this is a budget phone. It looks and feels good and is very well built and its features always work. The camera is brings up alot of red but besides that it's amazing.

I'm holding off on giving this phone a 5 until I get more time with it, as it just arrived today. If you get blue, be aware it's a darker blue than the picture would suggest. It's more of a navy than a bright blue, but that's fine with me. I haven't tested the wifi as of yet, so I can't verify any claims about how good/bad it is. Pro's and Con's so far: Pros: - Contrary to some things I've been reading, we ordered two of these, one black and one blue, and both are getting 4g service through AT&T, so that hasn't been a problem for us. - The fingerprint sensor is SUPER snappy so far, by far the fastest way to unlock the phone, and to my pleasant surprise you can register up to 5 fingers in the settings, so multiple people can be given permissions to unlock the phone with that option if you so choose, which is incredibly nice. It's also good to note that out of the box the phone has the option to toggle on and off extra functions for that sensor, which lets you answer calls, pull down the notification menu, etc., which is quite convenient. -The phone feels well constructed, and the aluminum body makes it feel stout. It's been in my pocket (with thin rigid case and screen protector) through work and I've stopped worrying for the most part about accidentally cracking the screen. The phone is quite rigid and feels durable. -The camera is great. There's a plethora of features built in with Huawei's software, and it's given me some amazing shots (I'll include at least one with this updated review). It'll take some experimenting to get used to, and it will also take practice to learn what works best when, but overall I'm extremely happy. It won't do 4k or anything that great, but I hardly expected it to. -For a "cheap" phone the speakers are more than passable. You won't get amazing depth of sound or anything (these are phone speakers, after all) but audio is clear and loud enough for my uses. - I've yet to get this phone under %50 battery, but I'm not a power user. It's greatest test so far as been as a GPS device for about a 4hr round trip, with the screen on about 3/4 of that time along with my normal light use. Heavy users will likely have more problems with it, but if you manage how many things you have going on in the background it's not a problem. -I cannot complain at all about screen quality here. If anything I'm thoroughly impressed. Colors are true, lines are crisp, and it responds to touch without issue. It looks beautiful. Cons: -The first minor thing is that if you're ordering it for AT&T you might need to mess with some APN settings when you first set it up. It's an inconvenience but nothing serious that other phones don't also have to deal with. -I do have one mildly irritating issue with headphone audio, which honestly is barely worth mentioning. I think it's due to the phone turning off power to audio devices to conserve battery life, but when I have headphones in (and only then), a second or two after audio is stopped there's a squeak or pop. It's the same noise you would hear plugging headphones into the headphone jack or wiggling the wire on a dying pair of headphones to get it to reconnect and play sound. It's slightly irritating, but not enough to dampen my enjoyment of this phone. -Some will consider this a Con, but I don't mind it personally. As of now this phone is still running Android 7.0 Nougat, without an option to upgrade to the newest Oreo software. This is supposed to change, however I haven't found a solid date on when the update will roll out to this device. - The phone does not support USB type C. This doesn't bother me in the least, but some people prefer it for various (legitimate) reasons. Overall, this is an amazing device for the cost, and I can't recommend it enough. It doesn't help that I'm still getting a kick out of showing it to people and seeing the look of shocked disbelief on their faces when I inform them that this sleek, snappy device is a Huawei, which in my area has a reputation for being the bad end of cheap. Holding it up to a friend's Samsung Galaxy Note 8, it's nearly identical in size, and in brief comparison seemed just as high quality, and it's a surprise to people that it's not a flagship phone.
reviews.review_header: Updated 2/28: I've had this phone for about a month, and I can give it a solid 5 stars.

reviews.review_text: The best phone I have ever had. Love it!

A good inexpensive phone. It's a pity you have to choose between the second Sim and a memory card but for me the 32gig storage is fine so I use the 2 Sim cards. It has its quirks like any other phone but so far they have been minor. I like it.

reviews.review_text: I love it. Does everything as advertised if not better and It didn't take 30 months to pay for it or require financing. Beautiful screen resolution, long batter life, and it was easy to transfer data from my old phone to this new one with an app.
reviews.review_header: It's not a cheap phone. It's a good affordable phone.

reviews.review_text: This is truly a great phone, I love everything about it so far and have no complaints!

Based on reviews, I expected a good phone. At first it was, once I did a factory reset. Camera is okay, good considering the price range. The phone itself, not so much. Apps don't work properly, seems like they aren't compatible with software. In fact, apps that I had transferred from my old phone that were working fine were incompatible with the honor 7x, affecting the whole operation of this phone. So right after the initial setup I had to do a factory reset, upsetting but the phone was good to go. Then the problems started. Slow. Laggy. Freezing. Shutting down randomly. Kept having to restart which was very frustrating, couldn't even use the phone for a half hour sometimes. I honestly don't understand the rave reviews about the honor 7x! I am not a gamer or a heavy user. Calls, texts, light user of social media and camera - that's it. And this phone could not even handle that!
Had about a month now. Batttery is still great, phone is working flawlessly. Really enjoying this thing. Well worth the price.

Excellent mid range phone for the great price. It's well built, and has solid feeling no less than that of Mate 9 that I currently own. Only negatives that I can think of are the lack of NFC, slight more lags for switching applications (when compared with Mate 9), and narrower screen dimension that is relatively new to android devices. It supports LTE FDD band 17 (and several other bands), so it should work with AT&T, and NVMO using AT&T network like cricket mobile that I use. I feel that smart phones are quickly commoditized, and it's getting very hard to justify paying for the price the flagship phones ask these days. So this phone is a godsend for me.
reviews.review_header: Very functional phone for very good price.

I value reviews on products I intend to purchase. Typically, I don't do reviews but I felt obligated to do so on this phone. I consider myself to be tech savvy but not a tech snob when it comes to phones. That being said, I know what I'm looking for in a phone and I thought this phone had it. I had been patiently waiting on the Honor View 10 to come out (guess I should've waited a tad bit longer) but decided to bite the bullet and just buy this phone until its release. THE GOOD: Beautiful phone- solid build. Love the aluminum body and how it feels in the hand. Love the skins and themes you can download to customize the phone. Transferring all of my apps / accounts / etc from my previous phone was a breeze and only took about an hour or so. THE BAD: I'm coming from a ZTE Axon Mini 7 which has given me hell with performance issues. Watch Netflix on the Axon 7 Mini is a lot crisper than this phone (sure it has something to do with LCD vs AMOLED). THE UGLY: RAM RAM RAM! Imagine my heartbreak when this phone started to lag not even a week after owning it. Imagine my frustration when I realized there was a Mate SE model with more RAM that was available for $30 more. Needless to say I am in the process of returning the Honor 7X and purchasing the Mate SE. Totally worth the money in my opinion.

For $200.00, you can't beat the quality. Especially when you first setup the phone, the phone will be under a great deal of load. It's a no-brainer since your phone is usually installing all of your apps from your previous phone and the corresponding updates for the system as well. Still, even casual use will lock up the phone. This isn't a huge deal. Close your 4 million apps and try performing the same task again, it should work without issue. That being said, as someone who needs to use this phone for IT work, the lock up can be frustrating sometimes. If you're on a budget and you want a little better performance, plop down the extra $30 and go for the 4GB, 64GB version of this phone found here (trust me, I wish I had done the same but it's not worth the effort just yet): Huawei Mate SE Factory Unlocked 5.93" - 4GB/64GB Octa-core Processor| 16MP + 2MP Dual Camera| Grey (US Warranty) The 5.93" phone screen is AMAZING. I put it right next to my brother's iPhone X, who by the way had been bragging about his new iPhone X for months, and he went quiet before releasing a subtle "wow." When I told him how much money it cost, he shook his head in disbelief. Screen transitions can be customized, you can add 5x6 app tiles, and the stock backgrounds and lock screens are visually pleasing to look at. Sometimes I find myself waking my phone just to remind myself of how awesome the phone really is. Storage is a bit of a bust. The system takes about half the storage of the phone. If you buy a 32GB, be ready to have about 18GB of storage to actually use. Again, if you're on a budget but you need double the storage, check the link I posted earlier because that is the exact same phone with an extra GB of RAM and an extra 32GB of storage on top of what this phone currently has. My only regret is that I didn't upgrade for $30 to 4GB RAM and 64GB of storage but you can be assured that once you have this phone, you'll forget what a galaxy or iPhone is, or why they even exist.
reviews.review_header: For $200.00, you can't beat the quality.

Once again the Chinese have done an incredible job of giving flagship phone build quality with upper tier internal components as well as high end features like dual cameras all for 200 dollars. I ended up giving the my 6X to the misses as she really needed an upgrade while I'll preordered this 7X. They improved on the screen size as well as improving build quality and material feel. The slight curve towards the lateral edges of the device give it a pseudo S8 kind of feel in the hand. Side buttons have a good feel and click like a top notch device. The also went with protruding lenses in the back like Apple, possibly do to light restriction on the previous model when a case was used. Huawei also makes it super easy to put everything from your old phone to your new phone with their clone app that even a smart phone novice could do in less than ten minutes. Good job on making the best budget phone out there Huawei. You've got a lifelong American customer here.
