reviews.review_text: I've had an iPhone since Nov 2007, and my last was the 7s Plus. I love them however I can't justify the cost anymore. The honor 7X took me by surprise, the cost for what I received was excellent in my opinion. The interface look, and fill has some of the qualities my iPhones possessed. It might not have the specs of the iPhone, but it went above my means and more. The camera I've learned to tweak for optimum result, last photo from the 7X. Its fast with 4g from T-Mobile, as well as WIFI. The fingerprint ID is responsive and fast. Battery 🔋life is great, and charges relativly fast. The one thing I'm still tinkering with is the usb connect for my car radio, it charges I just have to use the Bluetooth for a music connection. I've had no serious glitches since received 3/12/18 as other reviews have stated. The reviews to the effect of the security concern, I understand the concern, however all my iPhones where made in China as well. The Honor 7X changed my opinion of android phone's.

reviews.review_text: It's a surprisingly good phone for it's price category. But not without flaws. One very annoying problem with the phone is that some apps can freeze and remain non-responsive for minutes. I have this problem quite often with the camera app and Google Maps. Just because of that I'm thinking of switching back to my Moto G5, which was performing flawlessly except that I wasn't happy with the quality of the photos. I got Honor 7X because it's supposed to have a very good picture quality. And the phone UI is very responsive and perfroms quite well except at times when the apps are frozen/stuck. The phone is very nice overall, good signal and call quality, no issues with bluetooth, nice, large screen, battery rarely drops to 50% at night. The speaker isn't as good as the one on Moto G5 (wow that thing can be loud), the phone ringing and notifications are much easier to miss on the Honor.

This is a truly unlocked phone. I love it. I got rid of an iPhone for a Samsung Galaxy. It was a good move. Now I got rid of the Galaxy S5 for this Honor 7x. I don't need a cleaner app, or an anti-virus app, or a launcher (because I didn't like the forced home screen, etc) - because these types of apps or functionality come standard in the phone. I can set the grid size of the screens, set how the screens transition, etc.; all the functionality I wanted in Nova Launcher. The response time is fast. The fingerprint access is faster than the Samsung. This is certainly a "flagship killer". I use it with Straight Talk and it works just fine. Even switching my number to the new sim (I was already on ST) was quick and painless to do myself online in my account. I would definitely recommend this phone to my friends and family.

I have always used iPhones and bought this just to try out an Android phone. My previous phone was an iPhone 6s. I have been using it for my main phone for a couple of days and I really like it. Pros: Screen - The 18:9 screen is big and easy to use. The text is much sharper than on my iPhone (407 ppi vs 326 ppi on my iPhone). The viewing angles are a bit worse than my iPhone, but not by much. The display gets just as bright as my iPhone. Batery life: It lasts quite a bit longer than my iPhone. Build quality: The phone feels like it cost way more than $200, however the matte black version is like a fingerprint magnet. Buttons: The power and volume buttons feel solid and not mushy. Fingerprint scanner: The fingerprint scanner is so fast and accurate. Opens in less than half a second. Much faster than Touch ID gen 2. Call quality: The sound from the earpiece is load and clear. Camera: The secondary 2MP camera for wide aperture mode does not do such a good job at blurring out the background, however the primary sensor can capture very nice images on its own, especially closeups. Cons: WiFi and Bluetooth issue: When bluetooth is on Wifi speed drops significantly. This is because they share the same antenna, but I was still able to play 1080p YT videos to a bluetooth speaker, for $200 I can't really complain. Main Speaker: It lacks mid and bass frequency and can easily be covered. My iPhones speaker was much better. No 4k recording: This is due to a chipset limitation. MicoUSB: At least you don't have to buy a bunch of new cables if you have a lot of microUSB cables. No fast chrging: It charges as fast as my iPhone with the 1 amp charger. --- After looking at my iPhone after using this, my iPhone just seems so ancient.
Having issues with bluetooth connecting in my car...except this, mobile is perfect

I've had this phone for a little over 2 months and up until this last week I was thrilled with it. The body design is sleek and looks on par with bigger brand phones, and the interface had all the customization I love with androids as well as being user friendly and streamlined like apple products. It was a little glitchy or laggy with some higher memory usage apps like Snapchat and it doesn't do "fast charging" like the bigger brand phones do now, but overall I was over the moon with the performance and design of this phone for the price. However, in the last week when I plug it in to charge I've been noticing it either isn't charging all the way or it seems like the charge has decreased. I thought maybe I was unplugging it without thinking about it and then forgetting to plug it back in. But today it has almost completely stopped charging. I've tried 4 different chargers, including the one it came with, and it does not even acknowledge being plugged in. I gave it 3 stars because while it took a charge, it was an awesome phone for the price. However, 2 months is a very short phone life. So if you're looking for a high quality-for-the-price phone for a short period of time, this phone would probably be perfect for you. But if you're looking for a phone to last and perform consistently for a long period of time, it's probably best to shell out a little more cash for higher quality.

The Honor 7x is handsome and stylishly thin, the screen is beautiful and has really thin bezels, the performance is snappy, fingerprint unlock is nearly instantaneous, the camera does the cool defocused backgrounds, it comes with a nifty clear protective case, it's super-easy to set up, it comes with twice the internal memory of comparably priced competitors and one and a half times as much RAM, I mean, come on people. reviews.review_header: Amazing bargain in a great phone! Makes the $1000 iPhone people look silly.

reviews.review_text: Great value for money.

Update (4 days later after purchase) Unfortunately, I had to drop 2 stars after using the phone for 4 days. I started to hit serious lag. It seems like reviews you may find on youtube are reviewing the 4GB/64GB international version, because the US version with the 3GB/32GB is just not on par with the international version. Why I dropped 2 stars? - No 5ghz wifi connectivity. This is a serious bummer, since I only connect to the 5ghz frequency on my home wifi, since I had problems with other devices connecting and my wifi router routinely dropping some off the wifi-list,unless it's on the 5ghz freq. This is kinda interesting, since as far as I can remember, even phones from 2014 had ac 5ghz option. - Extremely slow charging. I just can't get around with this. I can see people charging their phones at night, but there are phones out now with the same $200+ price range that do fast charging. Micro USB is one thing, there are phones that fast-charge with it, but again, we are in 2018. - No NFC. Granted, there are only a few budget phones with NFC, but we need to look at from the point of view of the year 2018 just began and within a few months, more budget phones are coming out, packed with more features than ever before, even with NFC. Let this be the least of the problems, it's a compromise that most people can live with, if they don't use NFC (not using their phones with Google Play or transfer files etc. ) - Here is the worst. After several days, the phone began to lag. Whether it's from the new update, that popped up during setup, whether it's something to do with lesser memory than most phones or the interface itself, I don't know. I ended up disabling apps to gain some speed back, including disabling amazon apps, navigation apps and the built in Huawei apps. Then it continued. Browsing a webpage is like the scrolling acceleration is disabled or just the lag gets worse. Keep shutting down recently used apps won't help. Rebooting won't help, there is a constant lag while browsing in Chrome and in Facebook, something I don't experience in other budget phones for years now. Hopefully Huawei can address this in future updates, or could be just a few particular models effected, I don't know. It can get very annoying. There is something going on with the memory management, whatever, I am not an expert, but it just ruins the experience. Speaker is ok, but still very tiny sound. Again, we are talking about a $200 phone, but consider the trade-offs. In a nutshell, here is what to keep an eye out for when purchasing this phone: +Nice bright screen, small bezels, +Good camera for the price +notification LED (many people prefer it) +battery lasts a day for most people +fingerprint reader is lightning fast +Love/Hate heavy launcher skin over Android OS --------------------------------------------------------------- - Lag can creep up after a certain amount time, restart needed, apps needs to be disabled, /wait for more updates?/ - Still on Android Nougat, no confirmed date for Oreo update - Heavy launcher skin over Android OS - No dual band wifi -No NFC -US version : 3GB RAM/32GB of onboard space -Micro USB -No fast charging -No 4K recording capability -No image stabilization -tiny single speaker at the bottom ---------------------------------- At this point, I had luck to use the Honor 6X for 2 weeks last year and it was great. I would recommend that phone over this one.

reviews.review_text: Past phones: Moto droid, droid x, droid x2 droid razor, S5, V20, Note 5, Note 7, Moto G5, and some other low end phones. Nothing beats the note 7 before it was bricked though. I am really impressed with the phone for several reasons. PRO: The phone construction is great, camera is better than expected for a low level phone (about the same as the S5, but not as good as the Note7 or V20 and better than the others listed above), button feel is perfect, color is as advertised, screen looks good and the brightness level is way better than expected and much brighter than my Moto G4, speaker volume is very loud, but tonaly quality isn't that great but not as bad as others I have had. I really like the overlay of the gui and the options for customization are close to flagship level and equal or better than other big brands I have had. Response time of the processor is good and not a let down, the 3 gig ram seems fine for the phone also. Battery life is great and closely 30% longer lasting than the G4 I still have. The real surprise is the fingerprint sensor and how well it perfectly and instantly recognises several programed fingers. The Note7 was a joke in comparison . CONS: What I dislike is the fact the touch screen anywhere around the edges is kinda iffy, not really responsive at all. Using it as a hotspot is worthless as the speed is a joke and not even capable of playing youtube vids at a 240p setting. I still have 2 other working phones for a direct network comparo and this phone just sucks for use as a hotspot. My only SLIGHTLY MINOR COMPLAINT, is that this thing is slippery! lol Good thing they included the slim fitting, great quality cover/case for it. Given the battery life the last complaint is that it isn't a fast charging phone at all, but being that it needs charged less often that other phones I can still get a 12.5hr work day out of it before it dies. I have not charged it for 2 days on my days off, so the battery life is great in general, but having the turbo charge that other phones offer is still lacking on this phone. Again, just a minor con. Overall: I really like it and would buy it again if needed, but the lack of it being a hotspot is a big issue for me, as I used my last 2 phones a lot for this as my home wifi blows in some rooms and could use the phone to stream through the pc, smart tv, and the roku with ease for netflix movies. This phone just completely fails in that regard. Because of this I am wanting to give it 3 stars, but as it works so well in all other areas I will gift it an extra star and give it a 4.
reviews.review_header: The phone construction is great, camera is better than expected for a low ...

-EDIT- After exactly 1 month(Product arrived Jan 27, today is Feb 27), the phone is bricked. I was just listening to spotify, heard a notification go off, so I tried to unlock screen to view my message. The screen wouldn't cut on. I pressed the power button a few more times, eventually it cut on for a brief second and then just cut off again. I figured it was just being slow, so I opted to restart the phone. When the phone turned on, it constantly goes to the EMUI eRecovery page, which always fails to update to fix my phone. As of now, my phone is bricked and unusable. I've heard that flashing the stock firmware might work? I don't know much about that stuff, but from what I understand, Huawei doesn't normally make their stock firmware public for months after release and I cannot go months without a phone due to the nature of my work. I essentially just have a $200 paperweight now. --OLD REVIEW-- Absolutely love it. Phone lasts 3-4 days with light usage, day and a half with constant usage(Such as hours and hours of Netflix, or some light gaming) Only reason it isn't a 5-star, isn't necessarily a fault of the 7x, it's more-so a feature of theirs that doesn't like to work with Android well. The 18:9 screen, while excellent, imo, for viewing pleasures, the screen sometimes acts a little weird and doesn't register me pressing a button, so I have to double tap every once in a while. Not a huge problem, imo, however. I can live with that, overall, I love the phone.

reviews.review_text: Loved the Honor 5x. It was my first Honor phone. I expected the 7x to be at least as good. The Honor 7x had been nothing but problematic for me. To be clear the phone works great as an Android platform but is unreliable as an actual phone. After trying two att carriers h2o and straight talk and multiple days of tech support for each no one knows what's causing calls to be missed, calls straight to voicemail and delayed text messages. On top of this having Bluetooth on significantly slows wifi speeds. Unfortunately I cannot return the phone to Amazon. Update: Was able to get phone returned to Amazon for a partial refund. I was given a bit of a runaround but it worked out after a few hours on the phone and on chat. Topping off the bad experience was Honor stating that the defect fell under a non covered article of their limited warranty.
reviews.review_header: Great phone if you don't need a phone.

reviews.review_text: Great phone for the price, however, if you can get the Global version instead of the US version get it instead. You get one more gig of ram and more storage. Consider the Xiaomi MI A1 if you could afford a sightly higher phone. Honor 7x has a better screen, sightly bigger battery and a customizable ui skin but lacks due to having to charge via Micro Usb. The MI A1 has a smaller screen, smaller battery, but has usb c. The Honor also has a dedicated fm radio app unlike the the MI A1. The US version has 3gigs of ram, 32gb of storage for ~$199.99, and a 5.93" screen. While the Mi A1 has 4gigs of ram and 64gbs of storage while being around ~$250 with around 5" screen.
reviews.review_header: Consider the Xiaomi Mi A1 over the U.S. version of the Honor 7x
