reviews.review_text: The phone quality is top notch, everything about it screams premium phone. It can handle everything you throw at it. It has really great cameras, pictures are crisp and vibrant, also takes 4k video. Battery life is fair after heavy use, video streaming, social networking and heavy gaming. The phone does not over heat like previous ones I have owned. It is upgradeable to android 7.0. I came from Sony Xperia Z3 plus to this phone, pretty much same specs and quality. As I previously wrote, this is a great phone for the price. One year up date: The phone still works how it should. Updated to Oreo this week. Even bought my wife one 5 months ago she also loves the phone. Would buy it again. It a great budget phone.
reviews.review_header: Great budget phone with flagsship phone qualities.

reviews.review_text: Have had this phone for about 5 months now. The reason I bought it was because of the brand, Asus is a great company and always have fantastic quality products. Everything is great about this phone for the price; great cameras, build quality and look. I trusted Asus because I've bought motherboards from them before. Also one of the biggest things for me about this phone is that there is NO BLOATWARE, unlike Samsung phones. There are a few preinstalled apps but nothing that really gets in your face and pisses you off like other brands. The UI looks nice as well. Makes you feel kinda unique because you're using a phone brand that barely anyone else uses, but I am so glad that I found this brand of phones. I will be sticking with Asus for phones from now on because of this phone.
reviews.review_header: Asus is a great company and always have fantastic quality products

reviews.review_text: This is a great phone it feels very premium with the metal body and curved glass on the front and on the back. The finger print scanner is as fast as the iPhone's, and it can be used for payments like on the Google play store. The camera has many great features like time lapse, slow motion (60fps), super resolution, panorama, and 16 others. What is really great is the manual mode which can allow you to have a "photographer's experience" where you can control iso, shutter speed, white balance, exposure value, and the focal length. I also enjoy 4k video recording and laser auto focusing. The screen is very vibrant and gets up to 600 nits of brightness which does well outside. Also if you have issues with phone's color temperature or saturation there is a great tool called Splendid which comes preinstalled where you can customize your screen. My issues are that the glass is fairly fragile. I would definitely recommend buying a case for it and definitely a screen protector. Also if you have used an apple phone, you may know that many apps just don't work as well on Android devices. This isn't an issue with this phone, Samsung has some issues with certain apps also. Overall, I would definitely recommend this device.
reviews.review_header: Great value, definetly better than Zenfone 2

reviews.review_text: Very good phone. It is an amazing upgrade from the Zenfone 2. It is TW from Taiwan but it's all in English since you configure on the first start up. It came in a original box with a really good earbuds, USB type C charger, manuals and an ejector tool. I thought I wouldnt come with earbuds as on a US version but it surprised me but it is in-ear and I decided to buy another one. The fingerprint sensor is super fast and precise. The camera upgrades were worthy. The 3 gb RAM is doing faster than my one-year Zenfone 2 4GB and the Zen UI 3.0 is clean and faster. I never needed a launcher and now it is better than ever. It is working with T-mobile 4g so it is really unlocked.
reviews.review_header: Very good phone. It is an amazing upgrade from the ...

reviews.review_text: Excellent phone, very high quality and bright screen, camera shoots in 4k is a huge plus, expandable memory and internal 32GB means I will never have to worry! Only down side is no Name Brand phone protectors yet so you'll have to trust some other company. 5.2'' screen is nice, hardly noticeable from my 5.5'' zenfone 2 i had before. The all glass / metal design makes me much more confident in its durability and it has proven true the past few months I've had it. Very quick phone as well, would highly recommend. Definitely worth the few extra dollars over the zenfone 2.
reviews.review_header: Excellent phone, very high quality and bright screen

reviews.review_text: Had to replace my iphone 6, but couldn't afford the 7 (or even a refurbished or used 6)... I wanted to find something with comparable processing power, hard drive space, and ram.... And try to stay around $200. After spending a couple of days looking around, comparing specs, and reading reviews, I came across the ASUS ZenFone 3.... It had more processing power, 32 gb hard drive with an expandable hard drive space (up to 1Tb according to the manufacturers website), and 3gb of ram (the iPhone 6 only had 1gb)... And as a bonus, the camera is also an upgrade from the 6.... Not to bad for $230! Over all I'm liking the phone itself. It's my first Android device, so the usual learning curve woes keep coming up- but I was expecting that. I'm with T-Mobile and live in central Washington... While it wasn't the best with the iphone, it did have Wi-Fi assist for making calls and texting... But the ZenFone 3, as far as I can tell so far, doesn't have that function, which means I'm limited to using 3rd party messaging apps (FB messenger) to be able to have any sort of communications with anyone while at work, and most places in town. After researching some it seems that is something ASUS is hopefully working on to make available in a future update (keeping my fingers crossed). Only other thing (so far) I'm struggling with is the voicemail. Either I can't figure where the visual voicemail option is, or it doesn't exist, so that I can pick which message I want to listen to, vs having to physically listen to each message be played all the way through before being prompted to delete or save the message before I can skip to the next one.... Suuuuuper tedious (especially for someone who already struggles with checking voice mail).

I love how well this phone holds on to a signal whenever I am in a call. Once I get connected to a call, I seem to be locked onto it. So far, zero dropped calls. Call clarity is better than my old iPhone 6s. Texting, using the phone's messaging app, is simple but functional though a tad boring. Battery life is very good and can last the whole day from 100% charge at 7AM with heavy wifi and data use, streaming videos, phone calls (2-3 hours total) and heavy texting and Ill still have around 55%-63% battery by 9PM. Camera is just ok and nothing special though the manual mode is fun to use! The ASUS ZenUi is actually pretty interesting and the so-called "bloatware" can easily be disabled or uninstalled. What I am nervous about is the glass on the back of the phone which is cool to look at but in my opinion, an unnecessary embellishment. Overall a solid phone if you're after speed, stability, and signal.
reviews.review_header: Solid phone, well-executed features, good price,

reviews.review_text: I love this phone. It has a very nice design to it. Aside from that, being an IT person myself, I like to have nice electronics. My usual phone is a Samsung Galaxy S8, and we bought this Asus ZenFone 3 as our travel phone for an upcoming trip. I can tell you right now, I'm liking it EVEN BETTER than my S8. It runs fast and smoothly. I have no complaints.

Very good phone, worth its price. Looks and design is attractive. If you want yet the best performance then, disable all Asus apps and enjoy more fluent experience. The camera is wonderful and it will amaze you the minute you try it.
reviews.review_header: Wonderful Camera, more than enough for daily use and the best among all midrangers.

reviews.review_text: I love this phone, so far it is been wonderful. The last phone that I had was a Chinese phone. I thought it was all right until I got this phone. The user interface on this phone is so much better than the Meizu Note 1. I had no idea what I was missing. The phones even have similar specs, but this one is soooo much better. The fingerprint sensor works wonderfully. It is so accurate that even my twin sister couldn't unlock it with her finger no matter how many times we tried. It does not come bogged down with a lot of useless apps, and the user interface has a program that lets you manage the programs and apps that are running so that your phone doesn't slow down. I got this phone because I bought the Asus zenwatch 3. They work very well together the phone itself is is very good quality. It is actually lighter and slimmer then my old meizu. But somehow feels like it has a better quality. It is running the latest version of Android right now (marshmallow) I am interested to see if they update it when the next version comes out. The camera is nice about the same quality as my old phone. However the photo software is really nice and fun to play with. It also came with free cloud storage for pictures or whatever. The 3gb /32 gb is more then enough. All the apps run smooth, and I have plenty of space. And if you think you need more, you can use the second sim card spot for a micro SD card and increase the storage space. All on all I am very impressed with Asus. This phone and the ZenWatch were my first Asus purchases. I am now a loyal customer. If anything goes wrong I will update this review. So if there is no update then you my assume I am blissfully enjoying my new phone.

The phone quality is top notch, everything about it screams premium phone. It can handle everything you throw at it. It has really great cameras, pictures are crisp and vibrant, also takes 4k video. Battery life is fair after heavy use, video streaming, social networking and heavy gaming. The phone does not over heat like previous ones I have owned. It is upgradeable to android 7.0. I came from Sony Xperia Z3 plus to this phone, pretty much same specs and quality. As I previously wrote, this is a great phone for the price. One year up date: The phone still works how it should. Updated to Oreo this week. Even bought my wife one 5 months ago she also loves the phone. Would buy it again. It a great budget phone.
reviews.review_header: Great budget phone with flagsship phone qualities.

reviews.review_text: Have had this phone for about 5 months now. The reason I bought it was because of the brand, Asus is a great company and always have fantastic quality products. Everything is great about this phone for the price; great cameras, build quality and look. I trusted Asus because I've bought motherboards from them before. Also one of the biggest things for me about this phone is that there is NO BLOATWARE, unlike Samsung phones. There are a few preinstalled apps but nothing that really gets in your face and pisses you off like other brands. The UI looks nice as well. Makes you feel kinda unique because you're using a phone brand that barely anyone else uses, but I am so glad that I found this brand of phones. I will be sticking with Asus for phones from now on because of this phone.
reviews.review_header: Asus is a great company and always have fantastic quality products

reviews.review_text: This is a great phone it feels very premium with the metal body and curved glass on the front and on the back. The finger print scanner is as fast as the iPhone's, and it can be used for payments like on the Google play store. The camera has many great features like time lapse, slow motion (60fps), super resolution, panorama, and 16 others. What is really great is the manual mode which can allow you to have a "photographer's experience" where you can control iso, shutter speed, white balance, exposure value, and the focal length. I also enjoy 4k video recording and laser auto focusing. The screen is very vibrant and gets up to 600 nits of brightness which does well outside. Also if you have issues with phone's color temperature or saturation there is a great tool called Splendid which comes preinstalled where you can customize your screen. My issues are that the glass is fairly fragile. I would definitely recommend buying a case for it and definitely a screen protector. Also if you have used an apple phone, you may know that many apps just don't work as well on Android devices. This isn't an issue with this phone, Samsung has some issues with certain apps also. Overall, I would definitely recommend this device.
reviews.review_header: Great value, definetly better than Zenfone 2

reviews.review_text: Very good phone. It is an amazing upgrade from the Zenfone 2. It is TW from Taiwan but it's all in English since you configure on the first start up. It came in a original box with a really good earbuds, USB type C charger, manuals and an ejector tool. I thought I wouldnt come with earbuds as on a US version but it surprised me but it is in-ear and I decided to buy another one. The fingerprint sensor is super fast and precise. The camera upgrades were worthy. The 3 gb RAM is doing faster than my one-year Zenfone 2 4GB and the Zen UI 3.0 is clean and faster. I never needed a launcher and now it is better than ever. It is working with T-mobile 4g so it is really unlocked.

The all glass / metal design makes me much more confident in its durability and it has proven true the past few months I've had it. Very quick phone as well, would highly recommend. Definitely worth the few extra dollars over the zenfone 2.

I love how well this phone holds on to a signal whenever I am in a call. Once I get connected to a call, I seem to be locked onto it. So far, zero dropped calls. reviews.review_text: This phone is just magical ' for the price, its an absolute steal and I HIGHLY recommend it. The very first thing I noticed when I pulled it out of the box was the quality weight and feel of the metal rim and glass back. It feels like a luxury. But flashy-ness aside, it was everything I wanted it to be android wise and functionality wise. EXCEPT FOR THE FACT that you cannot move your apps to the SD card! Now that was a big nono for me. Everything but Asia can be moved to the sd card which helps, but it's not as good as having that feeling of unlimited storage. 8gb of storage IS reserved for system but that's okay. I've learned to accept that 22gb of apps is actually okay and enough. The camera is definitely up to par with the Galaxy S6 and S7! It's fast shutter and laser auto focus really allows for ease of use with stunning results! ZenUI is really something else on this device, I honestly thought it would come across as some sort of Chinese weird UI that tries to be relevant but I was impressed with the crazy amount of customization and over all ease of use. I was able to get used to this thing in less than a day and fell in love with it! It's processor is very very handy for keeping multiple apps open at once and still be able to get that lightning fast response time. The only time it ever kind of chugged was when I downloaded 244 selfies of mine at once! Haha I'm super happy with my purchase (I got it used and it came in looking BRAND NEW) and I recommend you to look into getting this phone if you're getting one to last a long time '

Lightning-fast phone, great camera, easy activation, user-friendly, sleek... MAN! I have been a fan of ASUS products for several years now and the ZenFone 3 does NOT disappoint. I am a prepaid phone user but often, Cricket and BoostMobile have a range of technically limited, unreasonably expensive phones for sale. Still, I have purchased phones through them in the past so as to avoid the contract B.S. Verizon and others put their customers through--of this, I have no regrets. Still! I did not know much about unlocked phones and was intimidated about making the leap. Will service be spotty? Will the activation process be a pain? Are there extra fees and hidden costs?... So far, the answer to each question is a resounding NO. Service is better than ever before, and the device itself runs sooooo smoothly. The 16mp camera is gorgeous. The activation process was as follows: 1) remove sim card from old phone, and 2) insert sim card into new phone. Voila! Immediately, I was able to receive calls, texts, and 4G--all to the same phone number as my previous device. To those of you who are familiar with unlocked phones and perhaps travel internationally, this comes as no surprise but to those of us with little to no experience with unlocked phones, the activation process is often a huge source of anxiety. Activation does not always go so smoothly. If the sim card from my previous device did not fit into the new phone, I would have had to buy a new sim card and transfer the old data to it (you can do this online or in person with most service providers). Also, MAKE SURE that your cell provider uses the GSM networks and others listed to ensure that your new phone will be eligible for service. Make absolutely sure before purchasing any unlocked phone. I did my research into this product and into the guidelines set out by my cell provider before buying and that greatly contributed to the seamless transition I experience in switching to the ASUS ZenFone 3. That's really all it takes to make the switch! I could have bought into a contract for a $1000 phone, I could have bought a $300 phone with weaker specs than the ASUS ZenFone 3, but this time I took a chance on a trustworthy brand (paid about $150) and came out with a device that easily competes with products from Apple and Samsung. Don't sign another contract--buy the ZenFone!
reviews.review_header: DON'T SIGN ANOTHER CONTRACT--GO PREPAID AND BUY THIS PHONE!

This phone is very well-constructed and beautiful. I'm a long-time Windows Phone user and just made the switch back to Android as Windows Phone is finally losing its steam and becoming less viable. I originally switched from Android five years ago because of ugly UI and excessive bugs. No more! This OS is beautiful and I haven't encountered a bug yet! It's also swayed at least one of my iPhone friends to switch back to Android. My only two gripes are that the phone defaults to Korean (must press a different button in setup to switch) and displays a lot of unnecessary notifications, but both of these are easy to remedy. If you're curious about how to set this up on your mobile carrier, I'd urge you to read up on it online, but it was very simple for me. I'm on T-Mobile, and I just popped the SIM card out of my old phone and put it into this one. Done. No set up with the carrier over the phone, no online activation--I was able to start using it immediately. The only real catch is to make sure the SIM card in your current phone is supported by this one. I think there are three different kinds of SIM cards. The ZenFone 3 has slots for two of them, so chances are you'll be alright--just check first.

reviews.review_text: This phone feels as slick and well-made as the Samsung S6 and less plastic-toy like than the iPhone 6 which we have used in our family. The one we have has the Snapdragon 625 which clocks in faster than my flagship LG V10, which is one generation of processors behind it. He doesn't feel the "lagginess" that his HTC One M9 had on a couple of the video heavy games. (The M9 is an excellent device, BTW. It has good speakers, a crisp display, and is not very expensive.) It doesn't get all the bands for AT&T LTE, but he has had no trouble eating up our data streaming video. It is a bit tricky to get the SIM card to work because you have to configure the APN settings by getting them from the ATT website. My ATT store had unprofessional staff there who told me to send the phone back because they didn't know how to admit that they didn't know the answers I needed. It's not that hard, once you get to the right page.

For the money, the build quality and feature set are amazing. When i first bought the phone i was amazed at how quickly the battery was going from full charge, to dead. Like 3 hours with no talking and minimal internet activity. I was about to return the thing, but a system update came up and there was a technical note that there was a specific fix in the update for the battery drain issue. Sure enough, when the update was done, the battery issue was completely handled and enjoyed decent battery life until now. Just the other day, there was another system update. While not as bad as before, now the battery is dying after 5 or 6 hours of moderate use, when before the update i was getting 12 or so. Not only that, now the phone will not recognize my laptop when i connect via usb to transfer pictures. There is no place in setting where i can select to make it a media storage device or in anyway affect the usb. And Asus is absolutely zeroville when it comes to technical support. reviews.review_text: Okay first of all let me get this out of the way. Do not worry about the chinese government spying on you lol Huawei is there to make money by selling phones, period. If you ask me I believe Samsung and apple had something to do with that spying rumor because they want to keep the competition down in America and Chinese phones pose a threat. After all why buy a phone for 1000 dollars when you can get one almost just as good for less than 300. So with that being said, this phone is amazing. Super fast fingerprint scanner, camera quality is amazing, if you handed this phone to someone who didn't know huawei, they would think you paid three times the amount that you actually did. I asked Huawei about a update to Android 8.0 and they said it is confirmed and should be released in April or May at the latest. The software is well optimized and I can get about 6 hours of screen on time with casual use such as calling, texting, and social media. You can zoom in the screen on apps to take advantage of the 5.9 inch screen. The speakers are not the loudest but the quality is good and clear. The audio through the headphones is really good and it also has a mode to improve it even further giving it a bit more bass. The only downside to me is it isn't USB type c, but with how great this phone is all the pros definitely make up for it having micro USB. With phones like this, from Huawei and xaomi, the days of paying 600 to 1200 for a good for are over.
reviews.review_header: After all why buy a phone for 1000 dollars when you can get one almost just as good for less than 300

reviews.review_text: I've been using the Mate SE for the past few days and thought I'd leave a review to help others decide when considering this phone. I've been a Google Nexus (5, 5X, 6P) user for the past several years, so leaving Google devices was a leap of faith for me, but my 6P was experiencing the cold battery shutoff at 40+% issue so it was time to try something new. I want to add a disclaimer that I am including the price point as a major part of my decision to give the phone 4 (really 4.5) stars. I mean, THIS PHONE IS $229!!! A second disclaimer is that I am by no means a power user. My typical uses for my phone are texting, web browsing, watching youtube videos, navigation, some social media, and taking photos. I do not game on my phones, so my review is not evaluating gaming performance. The Pros: -Smooth operation. For my everyday use, the speed of opening apps and switching between apps is great and I have no major complaints. There are occasional times when scrolling isn't quite as smooth as on my 6P or my girlfriends S8+, but this is also being nit picky. Again, 95% of the time its great. -Great screen. The screen is big, the bezels are small, the picture is clear and sharp and the colors are accurate to my eyes. The auto brightness feature also works quickly and seems to adjust to a comfortable level based on the surrounding lighting. -Premium feel. I've been using the phone without a case since I got it and I like how the aluminum body feels in my hand, although it is a little slippery. The buttons feel nice and solid -Fast fingerprint scanner. The finger print scanner is at least as fast as the 6P if not faster, and is quite accurate. I've only had it miss my finger print a handful of times and it was likely my fault for bad placement -Slim design. Because of the small bezels and the thinness of the phone, the mate SE is easier to carry in my pocket than the 6P. -Headphone jack! It has a damn headphone jack for those of us that haven't cut the cord on our headphones yet. -Availability of themes. Having used stock android for the last few years, I didn't particularly like the stock EMUI theme that ships with the phone, but there are theme packs available for download on the play store that allow you to change the theme to pixel, oreo, etc. -Battery performance. Again I'm not a power user, but I have been consistently making it through the day with 60% battery remaining when I plug my phone in before going to sleep. -VALUE!!! During my research for a new phone, this phone offered the best features for the price. Hands down. -Camera IN GOOD LIGHT. In daylight or bright light the camera is actually pretty good if you have a steady hand. The pro mode on the camera allows for pretty decent picture taking if you are willing to adjust some settings. I also like the bokeh/low aperature mode for taking macro shots. Its not as good as the pixel camera, s8/s9 or iphone but its pretty decent IN GOOD LIGHTING. The Mehs: -Bloatware. There isn't a ton of bloatware, but it is a bit annoying that you can't uninstall most of the apps that ship with the phone. I prefer to use the google apps, and I can't delete the stock email app, calendar app, etc. Not a huge deal, but meh. -Nougat. the Mate SE ships with nougat, although a google search will show that Huawei is beta testing Oreo for the 7X and an updated EMUI. Hopefully the stable version is released this spring or summer. -Typing mistakes. I seem to make more mistakes typing on this phone than my 6P for some reason. Perhaps it is the screen protector I have on it which isn't the best. just something to note, not a huge deal. The Bads: -Camera in low light. I'm just going to be honest here, the camera is terrible in low light compared to my 6P. Google is king of image processing and the Mate SE is no where close to any google device in low light camera performance. Keep in mind though, that this phone is also 1/3rd the price of the Pixel 2 and almost a 1/4 the price of the Pixel 2 XL, so a worse camera in some situations is expected at this price point. Overall, if you are in the market for a new phone, and don't want to spend close to $1000 for a new flagship, the Mate SE is definitely a phone to consider if you don't mind the poor low light camera performance. Everything else with the phone feels on par with other big name phones, for a fraction of the price!

bought the GOLD version of this Huawei Mate SE for $229 + sales tax from here on amazon. as an iPhone person who recently turned to Huawei, this is a fabulous great phone from Huawei. my iPhone was flaking out because of apple's horrible battery shutdown/slowdown problems. apple jumped the shark trying to fool people about what was really happening with iPhone batteries. anyways, previously got a nice AT&T-branded Huawei Ascend XT2 which was like my training-wheels version to get me ready for this much more powerful unlocked Huawei Mate SE. Huawei got me hooked with its EMUI 5.1 (based on Android 7.0) that is designed to kinda be reminiscent of the iPhone iOS, particularly when you turn off the app drawer, but still a powerful android. so switching to the new Huawei Mate SE was easy peasy. and having 4GB RAM and 64GB storage really helped a lot to make the phone much more comfortable to use without worrying about lack of memory or lack of space. oh, in comparison, looking at the Huawei Honor 7x here on amazon, but for a little bit more in price, the Huawei Mate SE is the definite better buy. both the Huawei Honor 7x and the Huawei Mate SE look the same but the major difference is the Huawei Mate SE is more powerful with the 4GB RAM and 64GB storage. and the Huawei Mate SE is available in a GOLD version. my preferred phone gold color version. yea! definite no brainer. got the Huawei Mate SE. myself originally coming from iPhone, my suggestion to others regarding apps to make the transition in finding very good equivalent apps to iPhone's iMessages, Find My iPhone, and Find My Friends, is to go to the Google Play Store to download WhatsApp, Find My Device (from google), and Family Locator GPS Tracker (from Life360). and if you are like me thinking the android app drawer is a bit bothersome, well, you can turn it off in the settings on this Huawei phone. hopefully this advice should get you started if you want to have a more iphone-like experience on a Huawei phone. my journey is complete moving from iPhone to android where this Huawei Mate SE has become my primary phone. using this phone on AT&T and have 4G LTE. the Wi-Fi is only regular 2.5GHz wifi -- without the 5GHz wifi option (the Huawei Ascend XT2 has both 2.5GHz wifi and 5GHz wifi) but that's just fine if all your WiFi access is mostly to regular 2.5GHz wifi wherever you go and wherever you happen to be. personally still carry an iPhone as a backup phone in my go bag, but this Huawei Mate SE is my main phone now. went through other android phones, then recently got the aforementioned Huawei Ascend XT2, and now have this absolutely beautiful gorgeous Huawei Mate SE. physically very iphone-like and almost similar to the iPhone 7+ with the metal body plus with the dual camera on the back in the top corner like on the iPhone 8+ and then with the more modern 18:9 size front screen like on the iPhone X but without the iPhoneX ugly notch. also this Huawei Mate SE has a real must-have earphone jack. and this absolutely beautiful powerful phone performs smoothly with no lag. and Huawei seems to be hinting that Android 8 and most likely a newer EMUI are on the way for this and other Huawei phones for sometime during March 2018 or whenever. [edit: Honor 7x beta testing Android 8 and EMUI 8 began March 15. with maybe possible full release in April? (because news also reports Honor India says April for official release.) Huawei Mate SE should presumedly also get the android8 upgrade in the same timeframe sometime soonish whenever thereabouts is my guess....] so this phone will get even better with huawei support. yes, this Huawei Mate SE is very satisfactory. very happy with this phone. PS: people have commented in other reviews that if you turn on bluetooth, then the Wi-Fi slows down. this has particularly been reported in amazon reviews for the Honor 7x, and at least one other person mentioned it in a review here for the Huawei Mate SE. so, did a speed test to see what happens with my Huawei Mate SE on my home wifi internet: (1) wifi + no bluetooth had 47Mbps wifi internet speed; but (2) wifi + bluetooth turned on had 31Mbps wifi internet speed. this was tested using the Fast dot com website (which is reportedly owned by Netflix). okay this is with an ARRIS TG2472G cable modem with built-in WiFi that can handle both 2.5GHz and 5GHz, but only 2.5GHz is relevant for the Huawei Mate SE, where my home internet is on the Cox Internet Preferred 100 Plan, and so my plan's internet speed can be as high as 100Mbps on the 5GHz side but typically half that on the 2.5GHz side. of course, we are only concerned with the 2.5GHz wifi. turning on bluetooth and getting 30+ Mbps wifi internet speed doesn't matter in a noticeable way to me on my home internet plan. however, if your home internet is much slower like on a basic starter plan with a maximum speed of 10Mbps or less, then proportionally any decreased wifi speed with bluetooth turned on could possibly be noticeable to you. sorry, if you are a big bluetooth user. me not use an android gear watch or bluetooth earphones. if you really don't use bluetooth, then keep the BT off and this issue won't matter to you when you are on wifi. but if you are out away from home trying to use free wifi which can be congested or which may have throttled speeds already, then this BT issue could affect you -- and so maybe just use cellular data in that situation if you really need your BT. personally, this BT issue is not a deal killer for me. this is a great phone imho. PSS: okay maybe the bluetooth-wifi issue is a load of hooey. tried testing wifi internet speed with the bluetooth turned on while on the Wi-Fi at my parents' home where they have a DLink 2.5GHz wifi router and where my folks are on the Cox basic starter internet plan that has an advertised max speed of 10Mbps: (1) wifi + no bluetooth had wifi internet speeds of 9.8Mbps and 11Mbps; but (2) wifi + bluetooth turned on had wifi internet speeds of 8.4Mbps and 10Mbps. this was tested using the Fast dot com website (which is owned by Netflix). it's like no difference whether bluetooth is turn on or off as to the effect on wifi. but other real life factors could be involved -- that's for any picky bluetooth users to test, such as also using their particular bluetooth devices, because at this point, this so-called bluetooth-wifi issue is a non-issue for me. but my guess is if there is any effect, then it's a combination of your wifi router and/or your bluetooth device(s). (yeah, have previously seen differences in using a bluetooth speaker on my macbook versus on my iphone.) in other words, YMMV. bottomline as far as the Huawei Mate SE goes, get the phone, and if you are like me then you'll most likely love the phone. Another PS: (03/29/2018) just got the latest android security patch dated March 1, 2018 for the android 7 on this Huawei Mate SE. this is update version B130. it's not android 8 yet. comments elsewhere over on the xda-developer forum indicate that testing for android 8 (and also presumedly emui 8) on Huawei Mate SE may occur after testing is finished for the Honor7x. my guess at this point is to expect beta testing in April(?) or May(?) with official final distribution sometime soonish afterwards?? just have to wait and see. okay yeah would love to right now have android 8 (with treble to allow for more timely updates?), but this Huawei Mate SE, with android 7.0 and EMUI 5.1, plus with the latest android security update, is a very good reasonably up-to-date secure phone. my bottomline recommendation still stands to say this Huawei Mate SE is definitely a great phone very much worth getting. Yet Another PS (04/17/2018): GSMARENA indicates that Huawei Honor 7x to get EMUI 8, based on Android 8, to officially roll out with final release in May 2018. so maybe beta testing of Android 8 & EMUI 8 for Huawei Mate SE will occur sometime thereafter? could be looking at June/July for official final release on Huawei Mate SE is my current guess?? we'll see.... meanwhile, me currently still very happy with my Huawei Mate SE. oh, an app tip for those who use their Huawei Mate SE in the car: if you need a car app for playing your music and handling your calls & texts while driving, myself using the DRIVEMODE free app (found in the google play store). imho, it's better than Android Auto. can activate & turn off Drivemode from notifications, and overlay Drivemode on top of the music app, plus easy swipes & taps to control my tunes, and big buttons for answering calls & texts as well as voice control to answer calls and to read/answer texts. (oh, with the overlay, you may want to fully increase screen brightness & turn off the eye comfort.) drivemode works great with my whatsapp also. and particularly, the bigger controls (swipe or tap anywhere on the screen) makes it easy to manage my music tunes while driving, kinda sorta like on my old iphone, but different & better on my Huawei Mate SE which is usually docked on the dashboard of my car when me out driving. hope you all are enjoying your Huawei Mate SE (or soon will be if you are looking to get one).
reviews.review_header: Beautiful Powerful Huawei Mate SE is the phone to get

reviews.review_text: I have experience with both flagships (iPhone, Galaxy, Nexud) and "VFM" phones (OPO 3T, LG G4) - but I've got to admit that this phone managed to surprise me by surpassing my expectations, BY FAR! For $229 I expected to get something that will be decent, this is a price of a cheap phone so I guessed that it'll show - but the reality is quite different. If you ignore the Huawei brand name and judge the device by its looks & performance, you'll be left with an easy buy for a $400-500 price tag. So for $229 this is a definite no brainer, especially when purchasing directly from Amazon. PROs: + S-C-R-E-E-N (+design) feels high end. They managed to squeeze 6" into a 5.5" frame by reducing the edges, the result is extremely good looking. This is by far the best selling point from a user perspective, and it makes most of its competitors look quite bad when comparing side-by-side. + Price + VFM: You're getting about x2-3 what you pay for, that's a crazy bargain. + Battery: 3340 mA/h is big enough for more than a day of use. + SPECs + Performance: 64GB of memory + expendable SD mem slot (or dual sim support), 4GB of RAM, no lag whatsoever (including gaming). I'm amazed of how much they managed to squeeze in for a "budget" phone + Day-light camera: way better than my previous OPO 3T (that cost double in time of purchase), dual lens with a stable performance. This is not flag-ship level but it's definitely not "budget"-level either. + Finger-tip sensor is working flawlessly and very easy to use. CONs: - Speaker sounds cheap - No USB Type-C, previous generation USB connectivity - No quick-charging capabilities, I also think that it cannot be charged wirelessly (didn't check it though) - Camera performance in the dark isn't too good - Front-facing camera isn't too good - Not the latest android, EMUI GUI isn't for the "purists" (but I must admit - it isn't bad at all neither!) The unknowns: ? how will it perform over time, I'll update this review in a couple of months. Bottom line: I believe that the pros outweigh the cons by a long shot. I'd say that this is a nice bargain for $400, so for $229 - with respect - it crushes the competition. I payed for a cheap budget phone and received a great product that could dominate devices that cost x2 MSRP. Big koodos to Huawei for this product, glad that Amazon is selling it (since I wouldn't have the guts to order it without their backup).
reviews.review_header: Value for money is OFF the chart!

reviews.review_text: Don't even hesitate. This is a great phone for the price. I have several phones from xiaomi, samsung, motorola and apple. This is at the top of the list. I like it even better than my mi a1. Don't listen to all the foolishness.

I love this phone!! I swear, this is totally the best phone I've ever had! I just bought this phone a few days ago to replace my Huawei Honor 5X. It arrived yesterday and I'm very pleased with it! The speed is amazing and light-years faster than the older model (Honor 5X) and the fingerprint scanner is excellent. A quick touch to the back of the phone and it's immediately unlocked. I love that! The camera works great and is very responsive. There is hardly any delay when taking pictures. The Honor 5X I had before this one lasted a long time. I had it well over a year at least and I had dropped it numerous times on hard floors and concrete without it ever breaking the screen. I expect this one will be just as durable. If you're looking for a phone with great features, durability, and a high quality feel, this is by far the the best phone for the price.

First impressions are really great. It's fast. Ample memory. Great battery. Nice camera. Got this phone for the kid, an upgrade from a much-beloved but no longer supported Amazon FirePhone (itself maligned for all the wrong reasons, a story for another day). The camera has many features popular with the younger crowd (think: filters, background swap, beautify mode, AR ears etc). Android 7, while older, really doesn't bother me, since the latest security updates are available for this phone. We actually like the EMUI interface. May get another one for myself because it blows my older Note 4 out of the water. If anything negative arises, I will update this review. For now... highly recommended. PS Worried about spyware claims from US intelligence services and random senators? How interesting that most of these came about once Huawei surpassed Apple in terms of units sold worldwide. Politicized protectionist nonsense, if you ask me. I am really glad that Amazon didn't cave to the misinformation campaigns, unlike BestBuy, AT&T et al. I'm not buying another overpriced $900+ Apple/Sammy.
reviews.review_header: Received today. Fast. Ample storage. Great battery. Ignore the spy talk.

reviews.review_text: I bought this phone because it has a legit specs under $250 price tag and it didn't disappoint indeed. The phone is impressive compare to samsung's pricy android phones. I've been a Samsung user for years and i would choose this phone over it. The reason I give this phone 4 stars out of 5 is, it doesn't support NFC, a tool for android pay which the latest Samsung phones have. Aside from that, I don't see any advantage the pricy Samsung Galaxy phones have over this great budget phone. Lastly, with regard about the spying allegations on it's makers, I think it's ridiculous! For sure the pricy competetors out there has a real reason to get nervous about how good this company from China make their phone with a budget price tag. Samsung's phone for example is 4x more expensive. Established company phone makers here in the US doesn't want this product getting noticed I think. Spying concerns? Come on! We all know they've been doing it for years already. It's about $ concerns in my opinion. Peace!

Yes, there is something missing or not as good, but, for this price tag and what it offers, it is an excellent phone. Highly recommended. It has everything you really need. No NFC (Near Field Communications): You cannot "Google Pay" wirelessly, period; No 5Ghz WiFi (You have to stay at crowded 2.4Ghz. It is fine. You really don't feel you miss anything); No replaceable battery; No wireless/fast charging; No water-proof; No high speed USB 3.0; No stereo speakers; No gyroscope (do you really need it?); No native WiFi Calling (if you are a T-Mobile customer, you can use "T-Mobile DIGITS" doing WiFi Calling); Camera is not as good at Low Light condition, and without Image Stabilizer (but it is not bad at all and the built-in Camera app has a lot functions.16+2M dual main at f2.2 and 8M front at f2.0); Use old micro-USB port without Type-C (which I like the "old" micro-USB that I can use all my chargers and power banks.); And, it has FM radio (yes, good) using 3.5 mm audio (I like the 3.5 mm) headset (not provided) as its antenna; Great 5.93 inch 18:9 display at 1080p x 2160p, 407 ppi (though it is not OLED, great display); Beautiful metal case with clear-color soft TPU protection case; 4GB RAM with 64GB storage (still not enough storage? you can insert in a micro-SD card up to 256GB); Dual-nano-SIM (2nd SIM only for 2G); Excellent finger print sensor with gesture controls; EMUI interface is actually pretty good. You can select between drawer or standard mode; not many "other" apps (if you don't use it, you can delete or disable it.)... and it is built by HUAWEI, a big brand in China and Europe.
reviews.review_header: Excellent cost/price value. It has everything you really need.

reviews.review_text: Even cell phone pros were impressed. I had my reservations, I have had quite a few smartphones over the years, and have only owned the Nexus 6p from Huawei. They had improved significantly from the 6p. Buttons have good feel, phone is snappy, software is decent. Camera quality is pretty good, but slightly overexposed in my short time with it. Bought for my mother in law, and there was no sense in getting a $1,000 phone that will mostly be used for calling. For what it is, I could genuinely see using this phone as a daily driver if I were short on cash. Obviously I prefer my Pixel 2 XL, but I can tell you this is one darn decent phone. Battery is above my expectations as well. Screen is bright, and big. Easier on older eyes with the Android software letter increase size. If you're looking for something "good enough", this phone is a hit. Politically, I don't care what Uncle Sam says about the espionage potential of Huawei. If you are worried about that, avoid smartphones in general. Could snag up a big roll o tin foil too....
reviews.review_header: Not easy to discern from phones twice or thrice as much!

reviews.review_text: Okay first of all let me get this out of the way. Do not worry about the chinese government spying on you lol Huawei is there to make money by selling phones, period. If you ask me I believe Samsung and apple had something to do with that spying rumor because they want to keep the competition down in America and Chinese phones pose a threat. After all why buy a phone for 1000 dollars when you can get one almost just as good for less than 300. So with that being said, this phone is amazing. Super fast fingerprint scanner, camera quality is amazing, if you handed this phone to someone who didn't know huawei, they would think you paid three times the amount that you actually did. I asked Huawei about a update to Android 8.0 and they said it is confirmed and should be released in April or May at the latest. The software is well optimized and I can get about 6 hours of screen on time with casual use such as calling, texting, and social media. You can zoom in the screen on apps to take advantage of the 5.9 inch screen. The speakers are not the loudest but the quality is good and clear. The audio through the headphones is really good and it also has a mode to improve it even further giving it a bit more bass. The only downside to me is it isn't USB type c, but with how great this phone is all the pros definitely make up for it having micro USB. With phones like this, from Huawei and xaomi, the days of paying 600 to 1200 for a good for are over.
reviews.review_header: After all why buy a phone for 1000 dollars when you can get one almost just as good for less than 300

reviews.review_text: I've been using the Mate SE for the past few days and thought I'd leave a review to help others decide when considering this phone. I've been a Google Nexus (5, 5X, 6P) user for the past several years, so leaving Google devices was a leap of faith for me, but my 6P was experiencing the cold battery shutoff at 40+% issue so it was time to try something new. I want to add a disclaimer that I am including the price point as a major part of my decision to give the phone 4 (really 4.5) stars. I mean, THIS PHONE IS $229!!! A second disclaimer is that I am by no means a power user. My typical uses for my phone are texting, web browsing, watching youtube videos, navigation, some social media, and taking photos. I do not game on my phones, so my review is not evaluating gaming performance. The Pros: -Smooth operation. For my everyday use, the speed of opening apps and switching between apps is great and I have no major complaints. There are occasional times when scrolling isn't quite as smooth as on my 6P or my girlfriends S8+, but this is also being nit picky. Again, 95% of the time its great. -Great screen. The screen is big, the bezels are small, the picture is clear and sharp and the colors are accurate to my eyes. The auto brightness feature also works quickly and seems to adjust to a comfortable level based on the surrounding lighting. -Premium feel. I've been using the phone without a case since I got it and I like how the aluminum body feels in my hand, although it is a little slippery. The buttons feel nice and solid -Fast fingerprint scanner. The finger print scanner is at least as fast as the 6P if not faster, and is quite accurate. I've only had it miss my finger print a handful of times and it was likely my fault for bad placement -Slim design. Because of the small bezels and the thinness of the phone, the mate SE is easier to carry in my pocket than the 6P. -Headphone jack! It has a damn headphone jack for those of us that haven't cut the cord on our headphones yet. -Availability of themes. Having used stock android for the last few years, I didn't particularly like the stock EMUI theme that ships with the phone, but there are theme packs available for download on the play store that allow you to change the theme to pixel, oreo, etc. -Battery performance. Again I'm not a power user, but I have been consistently making it through the day with 60% battery remaining when I plug my phone in before going to sleep. -VALUE!!! During my research for a new phone, this phone offered the best features for the price. Hands down. -Camera IN GOOD LIGHT. In daylight or bright light the camera is actually pretty good if you have a steady hand. The pro mode on the camera allows for pretty decent picture taking if you are willing to adjust some settings. I also like the bokeh/low aperature mode for taking macro shots. Its not as good as the pixel camera, s8/s9 or iphone but its pretty decent IN GOOD LIGHTING. The Mehs: -Bloatware. There isn't a ton of bloatware, but it is a bit annoying that you can't uninstall most of the apps that ship with the phone. I prefer to use the google apps, and I can't delete the stock email app, calendar app, etc. Not a huge deal, but meh. -Nougat. the Mate SE ships with nougat, although a google search will show that Huawei is beta testing Oreo for the 7X and an updated EMUI. Hopefully the stable version is released this spring or summer. -Typing mistakes. I seem to make more mistakes typing on this phone than my 6P for some reason. Perhaps it is the screen protector I have on it which isn't the best. just something to note, not a huge deal. The Bads: -Camera in low light. I'm just going to be honest here, the camera is terrible in low light compared to my 6P. Google is king of image processing and the Mate SE is no where close to any google device in low light camera performance. Keep in mind though, that this phone is also 1/3rd the price of the Pixel 2 and almost a 1/4 the price of the Pixel 2 XL, so a worse camera in some situations is expected at this price point. Overall, if you are in the market for a new phone, and don't want to spend close to $1000 for a new flagship, the Mate SE is definitely a phone to consider if you don't mind the poor low light camera performance. Everything else with the phone feels on par with other big name phones, for a fraction of the price!

bought the GOLD version of this Huawei Mate SE for $229 + sales tax from here on amazon. as an iPhone person who recently turned to Huawei, this is a fabulous great phone from Huawei. my iPhone was flaking out because of apple's horrible battery shutdown/slowdown problems. apple jumped the shark trying to fool people about what was really happening with iPhone batteries. anyways, previously got a nice AT&T-branded Huawei Ascend XT2 which was like my training-wheels version to get me ready for this much more powerful unlocked Huawei Mate SE. Huawei got me hooked with its EMUI 5.1 (based on Android 7.0) that is designed to kinda be reminiscent of the iPhone iOS, particularly when you turn off the app drawer, but still a powerful android. so switching to the new Huawei Mate SE was easy peasy. and having 4GB RAM and 64GB storage really helped a lot to make the phone much more comfortable to use without worrying about lack of memory or lack of space. oh, in comparison, looking at the Huawei Honor 7x here on amazon, but for a little bit more in price, the Huawei Mate SE is the definite better buy. both the Huawei Honor 7x and the Huawei Mate SE look the same but the major difference is the Huawei Mate SE is more powerful with the 4GB RAM and 64GB storage. and the Huawei Mate SE is available in a GOLD version. my preferred phone gold color version. yea! definite no brainer. got the Huawei Mate SE. myself originally coming from iPhone, my suggestion to others regarding apps to make the transition in finding very good equivalent apps to iPhone's iMessages, Find My iPhone, and Find My Friends, is to go to the Google Play Store to download WhatsApp, Find My Device (from google), and Family Locator GPS Tracker (from Life360). and if you are like me thinking the android app drawer is a bit bothersome, well, you can turn it off in the settings on this Huawei phone. hopefully this advice should get you started if you want to have a more iphone-like experience on a Huawei phone. my journey is complete moving from iPhone to android where this Huawei Mate SE has become my primary phone. using this phone on AT&T and have 4G LTE. the Wi-Fi is only regular 2.5GHz wifi -- without the 5GHz wifi option (the Huawei Ascend XT2 has both 2.5GHz wifi and 5GHz wifi) but that's just fine if all your WiFi access is mostly to regular 2.5GHz wifi wherever you go and wherever you happen to be. personally still carry an iPhone as a backup phone in my go bag, but this Huawei Mate SE is my main phone now. went through other android phones, then recently got the aforementioned Huawei Ascend XT2, and now have this absolutely beautiful gorgeous Huawei Mate SE. physically very iphone-like and almost similar to the iPhone 7+ with the metal body plus with the dual camera on the back in the top corner like on the iPhone 8+ and then with the more modern 18:9 size front screen like on the iPhone X but without the iPhoneX ugly notch. also this Huawei Mate SE has a real must-have earphone jack. and this absolutely beautiful powerful phone performs smoothly with no lag. and Huawei seems to be hinting that Android 8 and most likely a newer EMUI are on the way for this and other Huawei phones for sometime during March 2018 or whenever. [edit: Honor 7x beta testing Android 8 and EMUI 8 began March 15. with maybe possible full release in April? (because news also reports Honor India says April for official release.) Huawei Mate SE should presumedly also get the android8 upgrade in the same timeframe sometime soonish whenever thereabouts is my guess....] so this phone will get even better with huawei support. yes, this Huawei Mate SE is very satisfactory. very happy with this phone. PS: people have commented in other reviews that if you turn on bluetooth, then the Wi-Fi slows down. this has particularly been reported in amazon reviews for the Honor 7x, and at least one other person mentioned it in a review here for the Huawei Mate SE. so, did a speed test to see what happens with my Huawei Mate SE on my home wifi internet: (1) wifi + no bluetooth had 47Mbps wifi internet speed; but (2) wifi + bluetooth turned on had 31Mbps wifi internet speed. this was tested using the Fast dot com website (which is reportedly owned by Netflix). okay this is with an ARRIS TG2472G cable modem with built-in WiFi that can handle both 2.5GHz and 5GHz, but only 2.5GHz is relevant for the Huawei Mate SE, where my home internet is on the Cox Internet Preferred 100 Plan, and so my plan's internet speed can be as high as 100Mbps on the 5GHz side but typically half that on the 2.5GHz side. of course, we are only concerned with the 2.5GHz wifi. turning on bluetooth and getting 30+ Mbps wifi internet speed doesn't matter in a noticeable way to me on my home internet plan. however, if your home internet is much slower like on a basic starter plan with a maximum speed of 10Mbps or less, then proportionally any decreased wifi speed with bluetooth turned on could possibly be noticeable to you. sorry, if you are a big bluetooth user. me not use an android gear watch or bluetooth earphones. if you really don't use bluetooth, then keep the BT off and this issue won't matter to you when you are on wifi. but if you are out away from home trying to use free wifi which can be congested or which may have throttled speeds already, then this BT issue could affect you -- and so maybe just use cellular data in that situation if you really need your BT. personally, this BT issue is not a deal killer for me. this is a great phone imho. PSS: okay maybe the bluetooth-wifi issue is a load of hooey. tried testing wifi internet speed with the bluetooth turned on while on the Wi-Fi at my parents' home where they have a DLink 2.5GHz wifi router and where my folks are on the Cox basic starter internet plan that has an advertised max speed of 10Mbps: (1) wifi + no bluetooth had wifi internet speeds of 9.8Mbps and 11Mbps; but (2) wifi + bluetooth turned on had wifi internet speeds of 8.4Mbps and 10Mbps. this was tested using the Fast dot com website (which is owned by Netflix). it's like no difference whether bluetooth is turn on or off as to the effect on wifi. but other real life factors could be involved -- that's for any picky bluetooth users to test, such as also using their particular bluetooth devices, because at this point, this so-called bluetooth-wifi issue is a non-issue for me. but my guess is if there is any effect, then it's a combination of your wifi router and/or your bluetooth device(s). (yeah, have previously seen differences in using a bluetooth speaker on my macbook versus on my iphone.) in other words, YMMV. bottomline as far as the Huawei Mate SE goes, get the phone, and if you are like me then you'll most likely love the phone. Another PS: (03/29/2018) just got the latest android security patch dated March 1, 2018 for the android 7 on this Huawei Mate SE. this is update version B130. it's not android 8 yet. comments elsewhere over on the xda-developer forum indicate that testing for android 8 (and also presumedly emui 8) on Huawei Mate SE may occur after testing is finished for the Honor7x. my guess at this point is to expect beta testing in April(?) or May(?) with official final distribution sometime soonish afterwards?? just have to wait and see. okay yeah would love to right now have android 8 (with treble to allow for more timely updates?), but this Huawei Mate SE, with android 7.0 and EMUI 5.1, plus with the latest android security update, is a very good reasonably up-to-date secure phone. my bottomline recommendation still stands to say this Huawei Mate SE is definitely a great phone very much worth getting. Yet Another PS (04/17/2018): GSMARENA indicates that Huawei Honor 7x to get EMUI 8, based on Android 8, to officially roll out with final release in May 2018. so maybe beta testing of Android 8 & EMUI 8 for Huawei Mate SE will occur sometime thereafter? could be looking at June/July for official final release on Huawei Mate SE is my current guess?? we'll see.... meanwhile, me currently still very happy with my Huawei Mate SE. oh, an app tip for those who use their Huawei Mate SE in the car: if you need a car app for playing your music and handling your calls & texts while driving, myself using the DRIVEMODE free app (found in the google play store). imho, it's better than Android Auto. can activate & turn off Drivemode from notifications, and overlay Drivemode on top of the music app, plus easy swipes & taps to control my tunes, and big buttons for answering calls & texts as well as voice control to answer calls and to read/answer texts. (oh, with the overlay, you may want to fully increase screen brightness & turn off the eye comfort.) drivemode works great with my whatsapp also. and particularly, the bigger controls (swipe or tap anywhere on the screen) makes it easy to manage my music tunes while driving, kinda sorta like on my old iphone, but different & better on my Huawei Mate SE which is usually docked on the dashboard of my car when me out driving. hope you all are enjoying your Huawei Mate SE (or soon will be if you are looking to get one).
reviews.review_header: Beautiful Powerful Huawei Mate SE is the phone to get
