As a tmobile user wifi service is life. because Tmobile has no service anywhere but metropolitan areas. For a simple user this is great. Maybe the extra gb of ram would have helped, but it's too late now. great phone for basic needs. This phone has me in its clutch.
reviews.review_header: Almost the business phone I needed..

reviews.review_text: Bought this to replace my wifes HTC One M9 after it died. The camera was supposedly a big selling point for this phone, but honestly it's not very good. Overall the phone is ok, good enough for most things, lacking in others. It's inability to connect to a 5Ghz wi-fi for example was slightly annoying. It's a decent phone, just dont expect it to be great.

The phone is amazing! Everything worked just as fine! This was a great transition from iPhone to Android. The dual-camera was amazing, it catched deep details very well. As a photographer and gamer this phone was a perfect fit!

I love, love, love this phone. So easy to use! I was searching for a phone for a year . I did not want to give up my note 4. I have to say I could not be more happier.what a great phone and the price is awesome. This phone compares to my $600 Galaxy Note 4. And I highly recommend it.

I have had too many phones to count. In the short time I have had this one, I can find nothing negative about it!!! It is fast, easy to use, takes fabulous pictures and looks stunning! When I find something lacking I will update. Extremely impressed!!
reviews.review_header: Best phone I have ever purchased!!

reviews.review_text: No problems so far and for it's price, you can't go wrong with it! Seriously why spend $700 for a brand new phone when in 1 year it's price will drop to $250. You might as well purchase this as it does the same as other phones.
reviews.review_header: No problems so far and for it's price, you ...

reviews.review_text: This will be the most honest review of this phone on here. I never write reviews for any products that I purchase, but if I can keep ONE person from wasting their money on this jalopy of a phone, this time will be well spent. I switched to this phone from a Samsung Galaxy J3 (the bottom of the barrel $60 GoPhone). That phone was by no means a powerhouse, nor did I expect it to be at that price point, but it got basic tasks done well enough. So, when I dropped $180 on the Honor 6x, I expected a substantial upgrade in performance. BOY, WAS I WRONG. I researched the heck out of this ohine before I purchased. It came down to the Honor 6x or the Moto G5. Decided on this one because it was about $40 less, I was on a budget, and the tech/features were pretty close. 1. The camera is this phones main selling point. With its dual-lens, multi-setting camera, and other bullsh*t, this is supposed to be a top-notch camera (FALSE) The camera freezes every time you try to open it, and IF you can get it to open, it takes a solid 10-15 seconds to focus- which by that time whatever candid moment you were trying to capture has long passed. Not to mention, the quality is terrible, although I will say the front facing camera isnt half bad (if youcan get it to open) 2. Performance wise, its a joke. Apps constantly crash when you run them, browser freezes, etc. Its makes social media apps a nightmare that st I really just gave up on. 3. Only saving grace (hence the 2 stars), is battery life. The hr battery lasts forever, even as your closing apps and trying to restart it to get something done. I really wanted to like this phone, but I seriously regret buying. Will be replacing with a higher quality brand in the very near future. DON'T WASTE YOUR MONEY. -an angry consumer

Overall a fantastic phone. Battery life is better than any smartphone I've ever had. Often it lasts 2 days. Seems very fast. Fingerprint sensor works fine. No complaints about the camera either. My only negative is the display. As a few other's have said here, the "vibrancy" of the color seems rather poor. Compared to other phones I've owned, certain colors don't quite look right. Red is probably the worst: It actually looks halfway between red and black. Best I can describe the look is "washed out". Even some low end phones I've had recently have a better display. At first it really annoyed me, but truthfully, I've gotten used to it, and it certainly isn't terrible. There is a color temperature adjustment in settings, but I've messed with that a lot...it doesn't really help. I don't regret the purchase, given the very reasonable price, and that everything else is fantastic. Edit: Have had the phone for 4 months and still working fine. I am adding the fact that it doesn't connect to 5 Ghz WiFi. That's a little disappointing, but connecting to 2.4 is no problem at all. I'm still glad I bought it. BTW, I've gotten used to the colors. I don't even notice it anymore.
reviews.review_header: Overall fantastic. Display color vibrancy is on the poor side. No 5Ghz WiFi

reviews.review_text: Wow! For me a died in the wool Android fan (Apple disliker) I feel like this is the perfect phone. Every need of mine is met. Great finger print security immediate wake up on touch mid back sensor. Love it! Great battery life, all day, love it. and Essentially every other thing is perfect, every measure at every moment. Added Efie launcher to get close to stock Android Light, thin beautiful and fast. and I bought it used/refurbished $125.00 Great, Great, Great

This phone has blown me away! I would never go back to paying $600 for an iPhone or Samsung ever again. This phone easily matches the speed and quality of other premium phones at a way cheaper price. The camera is top notch!! I would definitely recommend this phone to family or friends.

I have owned PLENTY of phone's over the past 7yrs...from samsung to Windows phone... I've also owned Honor 8, recently.. and I'm here to tell u.. these are the BEST PHONES I have came across since Huawei windows phone from 2014.. I will never own another phone.... thank u Huawei..

Wow is all I have to say about this phone... Great bang for your buck and not to mention the phone is confirmed to be receiving Android Oreo with the latest emui... Great purchase... Oh yeah and it has a headphone jack lol.
reviews.review_header: Great Phone, Great Price, Great Bang For Your Buck

reviews.review_text: This was bought as a gift for my mother who wanted a phone with a good camera. After a little research, we decided to go for this phone since it looked sturdy, had decent specs and was fairly inexpensive; she is not the most careful with her phones, so we were expecting it to take a bit of a beating . This phone is great for its price. The camera is pretty decent under the right conditions, it has a nice big screen, the battery is great and the phone doesn't feel laggy or slow. Overall she is pretty happy with it and after a few months, and a couple of falls, it is still working as well as the first day.

Bought it as a gift for my daughter and she loves it. The device itself has a good build quality and so far performance is good. She is really enjoying. I also found that the Huawei software to be good and does not have a lot of junk apps and most of the apps that came with it can be un-installed. Phone has many features and camera is good for this price range.

With all the positive reviews of this phone, I thought I would give it a shot. After using, I quickly realized that the shape of the phone began to bend like a banana. I have not done anything that I would consider strenuous, so the only thing I can attribute this defect to is it cheapness in construction. I reached out to Huawei and they told me to pretty much go pound sand. Because this is a physical defect, they said it is not covered under their warranty. Pretty ridiculous in my opinion.

Super buggy camera app. Takes forever to open up and then lags constantly. App memory needs to be cleared about once a day or it runs super slow. Still though....can't complain too much given the price.

It's pretty and I wanted **so much** to like it but it's so sloooow. It lags, the apps freeze, and half the time when you want to open the camera it takes about 10-15 seconds for the camera to activate (meaning you often miss the thing you want to capture). I also had Bluetooth connectivity issues, lots of dropped calls, and found the screen-on button to be just a little to resistant to press. I am really bummed about it!

It's an improvement over my old Nexus 5. Faster, better sound and color. Excellent camera with manual control. Weak flash but low light pictures are pretty high quality. Much better battery life. Would easily compete with phones three times more expensive. I wish for a stronger camera flash and the Optimization feature is worthless; otherwise, this phone is a great value.
reviews.review_header: an improvement over my old Nexus 5

reviews.review_text: Bought this phone as birthday gift for my wife. She loves the speed of the unit, the camera takes very nice pictures and video. The 32G of onboard storage is great. the battery life is fabulous, she spends several hours binge watching netflix and bare used half the battery. this is a great phone.
reviews.review_header: the camera takes very nice pictures and video

reviews.review_text: Excellent phone!! My son was very happy as this was his Christmas gift. We have AT&T and this phone works perfectly, all you need is the NANO sim card and your ready to go!! The phone itself works awesome its a good sturdy well made android, it's fast and just as good as my Samsung. For an off brand phone you won't be disappointed it does everything any android phone does. The camera is amazing! I must admit that's my son's favorite feature, it takes great pictures! Highly recommended buy!

Ive been with BLU phone years and I got so tired of all their extra fluff with the phones and lack of features (for the price) that I had to jump ship, and Im so glad I did. Its so nice to have a phone that does something when you touch a button!

I've had it for a week now, and it is really a great device for what I do. I can get a whole lot of apps from the store and they work like a charm, the battery does last for 2 days, which is a pleasant surprise for me, most phone batteries barely lasts one day. Finger print ID is fast and accurate, The price is a whole lot lower than the i devices. No complaints so far!
reviews.review_header: and it is really a great device for what I do

reviews.review_text: I really love this phone. The battery is excellent. I charge it about once every 2-3 days. The camera is comparable to phones of much higher price. I have not had any glitches in the software or hardware and I almost never power it off. I am very happy with this phone and am glad I didn't have to pay an outrageous price to get a very reliable phone.

Had item for a month, and so far I have absolutely no issues, I mainly use phone for gaming and watching videos, everything runs smooth and fast, once you disable all the bloat apps phone overall is super fast, compared a 0.5 ram Blu I had before this phone is a huge step up, and the battery last really long, 20% gone it 2 hours playing Naruto x Boruto, for the price it's a steal! Totally recommend, the camera lags a bit sometimes, but I can definitely live with that, the quality is also really nice
reviews.review_header: once you disable all the bloat apps phone overall is super fast, compared a 0

reviews.review_text: Very good phone, I'm iPhone user and bought this phone for mom and everything amazing for this price. It has finger print unlock, great camera, fast processor and much more..that made me think that I'm Paying way too much for iPhones.
reviews.review_header: Very good phone, I'm iPhone user and bought this phone ...

reviews.review_text: Screen to body ratio is not as good as some of the premium phones, but it is a great value based on the price. Display is sharp and there is no noticeable lag in day-to-day use even though the processor in this phone is not fast by any means. Phone only connects to wifi at 2.4ghz; whereas most phones nowadays can also connect at 5ghz. The 2.4ghz wifi connection give you greater distance, but 5ghz can support higher speed. If you are in a location with public wifi, and they are transmitting on 5ghz, then you won't be able to connect. Not a big deal if you have a cellular data plan with high or unlimited data, but if you are trying to conserve cellular data usage, keep that in mind.

Great phone for the price point. Does everything I need, including the convenience of Dual SIM so I don't have to pull my USA provider's SIM when I travel internationally. The fingerprint reader is a real timesaver for apps that can utilize this method to log in rather than having to enter a password.

Serious bang for your buck. This really is an excellent device for a super low price. The only area that I would've loved a slight improvement is the camera, not that it's shoddy, just average. Some of the software is a little different from other Huawei devices I own, but nothing that would cause major irritation. Phone operates fantastically well, no hanging or delays, everything we've done on it has been snappy. Great to have a dual-sim device that isn't entry level.

I received this phone to an APO address about two weeks ago. I was initally pleased with the funtionality of the phone. However, I am starting notice the screen will freeze regularly while using Gmail and a few other apps (Amazon Music, Hangouts, Outlook, etc). I am disappointed, obviously. To have a new phone that begins to malfunction after 10 days of use make me feel that I got ripped out. Initially, I thought the screen was freezing because I wasn't connected to the internet, however that shouldn't mean other apps freeze, too. But, on the plus side, the battery holds a charge for quite some time and I like the interface- it's almost like a mix of andriod and apple. Good phone for the price but you get what you pay for.
My husband LOVES his new phone. This was the perfect Christmas gift and he cannot stop playing with it. It takes AWESOME photos - much better than my iPhone!!! I HIGHLY recommend this phone!!!
reviews.review_header: Great Phone/Camera, As Described, Fast Shipping & Reasonably Priced.

reviews.review_text: So far I love this phone! The battery life, charging time and camera are all superior to my Samsung S5. Not to mention double the storage! I just hope it will last a while. i have had this a little over 2 months now and just love this phone the longer I have it. My pictures are better too. Way happier than with my old Samsung.

I bought this for my daughter who is transitioning from Windows phone to Android and she really likes the phone. From what I can tell, it seems to be peppy, takes good pictures, and is a real bargain for the price. My other daughter has a Moto G5 and between them, I like the Honor 6X a lot better but they are roughly equivalent.
reviews.review_header: Seems to be a great phone for the price.

reviews.review_text: External speakers sound terrible and are barely loud enough for me to hear it ringing. They sound blown actually. My 3 stars are going to change depending on how customer service addresses it.
It says the phone come with Android 7.0 Nougat + Emui 5.0, but it came with Android 6.0 + Emui 4.0. Is not a problem but is not what they say.

I really like this phone, except for two features: I don't need the Dual phone option-- it always comes up when I receive a call, which prevents me from answering immediately. Second, not easy to switch to a downloaded new font.
reviews.review_header: Awesome camera, and clear phone connections.

reviews.review_text: This phone is wonderful....

Nice inexpensive Android phone. Get's the job done, just not fancifully. The graphics are decent, not up to current standards, but what a dependable phone. If you don't care about not having all the bells and whistles, this phone will perform well.

Great product for the cost. Great value and really fast (when running very few apps). Very nice camera and great interface. HOWEVER, THE PROBLEM IS... It is very slow when multi-tasking apps. The 3 GB of ram is half full just on the operating system alone. When opening more apps, it gets very slow and you constantly have to close all apps to get it running fast again.

I'm not a tech genius just an average person who doesn't blow my money but needs a good phone and this one fits the bill. I don't know why someone would plunk down $900 plus for an Iphone or Samsung whatever when I paid $160 and had enough left over to buy a 4K TV new softball bat and had change left over for dinner and a movie with my wife.
reviews.review_header: ... person who doesn't blow my money but needs a good phone and this one fits the bill

reviews.review_text: Love the phone. No need to buy expensive with bloatware Samsung.

This is a great phone! I needed a new phone as my LG G4 stopped working. I grabbed this phone while it was on sale. I was able to upgrade my phone to Nouget 7.0. The camera takes great pictures! The build quality on this phone is pretty sturdy and it has a nice feel when you hold it.

This is a jewelry, this phone is fancy and too many things to learn, only for some reason doesn't work with my Bluetooth of my Honda car for this reason I put 4 stars, but if someday I fix it, I would put 5 stars.
reviews.review_header: This is a jewelry, this phone is fancy and ...

reviews.review_text: awesome phone, no much to say, huawei emui really make it fast, no laggin. Excellent and nice price. I still have honor 5x so I can compare, you are not gonna find a phone like this at hits price.

Great the phone. The best part was that I can customize my on settings and permissions for all apps which most other phones won't allow you to do. I initially bought it for testing Android apps but now I use it as my main phone. You can put 2 Sims at the same time but only one sim can be active at a time unless ur network provider has 2g.
It is so crazy value for the price !!! Everything is almost perfect !!! Only con is CPU and GPU power is not good enough. So for some 3D games are going to lag below 30FPS. But it is acceptable.

Sooooo happy with this phone! All the good features of s Samsung without too many apps and some of the iPhone features I like on my daughter's phone plus some extras! Picks up 4g lte most of the time, awesome pics, a health app and a battery that lasts 2+ days! No need to buy an $800-$1000 phone !
Bluetooth fail. What is the point of having a smartphone with enough power to run all of your devices if it can't connect. No headphones, car or Fitbit.

Just got this phone and transferred it to my Tracfone account, upgrading from a 4.5" LG Optimus 2. So far, it is a dream. Beautiful phone to look at, functions fast, and clear, crisp screen, nice graphics and feels nice in my hand. What more can I ask for?

very usefull phone, I love it, batery last a lot watching Netflix, if you dont use high consuming apps it will last two days or more, it's so good that I buy one for my daughter and one for her boyfriend, highly recommended
reviews.review_header: I love it, batery last a lot watching Netflix

reviews.review_text: Probably one of the best phone thats going to be released in 2017. Labeled a budget phone but feels premium and has great specs of a mid range of 2016. I've had this phone for a week now and so far no glitches at all. Camera is actually surprisingly great and its actually got a lot of software for the camera to play around with. But as a photographer I can say the pictures are very pleasant. I'm not a fan of bottom firing speakers but the sound quality is also good. And lastly the battery life is extremely good. On a very heavy use day of gaming and live video streams I was able to get at least 10 hours without having to return to the charger and on a average to moderate day I have gone a full day without recharging. On a light day also a day and a half on a single charge. This is a great phone for anyone looking for a cheaper yet not lacking in tech primary or a very very strong back up.
I am pretty happy with my purchase so far!! the battery....oh wow... last forever!!! The quality of pictures its is pretty good. No complains!! It its oretty good phone.
reviews.review_header: I am pretty happy with my purchase so far

reviews.review_text: So I bought two of these and I really love them! And you can't beat the price. I bought phone cases because I would always break my iPhones and needed something different. Love the camera , and how big the screen is. Sound is pretty good and has some cool features as far as touch unlock and other things. Had it for 2 weeks now and no flaws so far! Beats paying 500$ plus for a different phone.

Amazing device. Very nice camera. The portrait mode is not as great as the iPhone x, but it works. Great display. speakers are ok but works. I cant believe this phone is so affordable. It's easily a 300.00 phone.
reviews.review_header: Amazing device. Especially for the price

reviews.review_text: This phone is being used with tmoble and is one of the best phones that I have ever had. Performes just as good as a flagship phone but at a fraction of the price.

So far, the best phone I've had. The only con I can mention would be the default keyboard....not having as easy of access to punctuation symbols as my last phone did, not having a settings shortcut within the keyboard, and not having navigation arrows. But I can download another keyboard app, so that's trivial. This phone is great. I very highly recommend it.

I bought this phone for my wife, because it seemed like a good deal. Now I'm completely jealous of my wife's phone. The performance is Snappy and quick and the camera is amazing. She also gets great battery life out of it charging it only once every other day. I will probably buy this phone as my next phone.

Long review to come, short version: my BLU blew up, I uncharacteristically did very little research, this phone matched my top five criteria, and I just grabbed it. Loved it, waited a month to hate it. Still love it. I researched it after the phone and realized I got lucky and stumbled onto an amazing phone. THE best camera, killer battery, clean Android interface. Best under $200 phone, hands down. If I could afford the next model up, I'd jump on it. But totally and perfectly happy with this.
reviews.review_header: Awesome camera, and best bang for your buck

reviews.review_text: For the price range ... this is phone is definitely an exceptional. The battery seems to last forever. The clarity of the camera is great. Selfie mode works well. The only thing i noticed was the speed when changing apps to apps... noticeably slower or delayed after you've installed a few social apps like line, Snapchat, FB, Instagram...etc. Overall, still satisfied.
reviews.review_header: The clarity of the camera is great. Selfie mode works well

reviews.review_text: Looks so beautiful. Got the rose gold and i am in love it with. However i got this as a gift for my mom and i am already thinking if i should get one too instead of new iphone 8 haha.
We needed a smart phone for use while out of the country. This phone takes great pictures, was easy to set up, and provided all the features we needed (and more).

This phone is beautiful. I have had it for a few months well and it works amazingly. I like it so much that I might not buy from another brand ever again and just stick with Huawei. The phone is fast, has plenty of space and takes amazing pictures. The phone has a sleek and smooth design and is cool to look at. The finger print scanner works well, I use it all the time. I heard that people had issues with the phone being fragile, so I bought a case and I haven't had issues. Overall, it is a great phone and I am excited to experience the features of newer models.
reviews.review_header: I won't go back to other brands!

reviews.review_text: Best part about this phone was the finger print sensor. It's super fast and accurate. The interface was very glitchy. I wasn't able to scroll back through text conversations; when I would try, it would just automatically go back to the end of the thread. Returned the phone and got the moto g5 plus instead.
reviews.review_header: Best part about this phone was the finger print sensor

reviews.review_text: Its a great Deal and Price I also have the HUAWEI Mate 9 and this is close to the same at half the cost. HUAWEI makes the honor 6x I don't know but seems like HUAWEI can compete with the big Dogs.
reviews.review_header: Its a great Deal , HUAWEI can compete with the big Dogs

reviews.review_text: This phone is horrible!!!!! We bought 5 before Christmas. 1/5 works properly. The others have many glitches. My fingerprint scanner stopped working after 3 weeks. You touch something on your screen and it'll bring up something completely different. The phone freezes all the time, and the screen will just go black. I do not recommend this phone. I saw so many great ratings and that's why I got it. I was completely disappointed in my entire family is as well. The phone that does work is because the person never uses social media. If you're a person who likes to get on social media I do not recommend this phone at all!
Amazing smartphone for the money. Really enjoy the speed and the dual camera.

Phone works great but some how I don't have the setting for me to setup my fingerprint, when I I called Huawei they said I could send it in but it would take about 2 weeks. I can't be w/o a phone for that long so I said no... Maybe I will change my mind later, other then that I love the phone and I'm so in love with how long this battery last.

Amazing phone for the price! Charges from 0 to 100 in 1 hour and has a good camera. I originally ordered it for 200 but a week later the price dropped to 150. So amazon told me I had to reorder the new priced one and send in the old one for a refund. It was not good to go out of my way but it was worth it! Great phone for the price!

Great value and concept. Not sure if settings issues are software or hardware related. Very nice phone. Responsive and functional. Problems may only be learning curve due to long history with previous phone. Some possible issues with carrier not respecting outside phone acquisition. (I'm not paranoid,are you?) LOL

Love this phone. So far is amazing for its value and what it can do. Better than I would of expected. I feel like it can top iPhone and Samsung. I have it for like 3 months now. The only thing that kind of sucks is I can only use the 2. Something gigahertz signal. But even with that, I wouldn't dock a star off this product.

Excellent phone for the price. Bought it to use as a home phone utilizing Google voice, Hangouts, and wifi. Works great. Although I'm not the biggest fan of EMUI, it runs well and, considering the price, I would consider better than the Samsung S6 that my wife has.

One of the best in fact the best phone in budget category. Perfect combination of battery life and performance. You will never notice any difference between this phone and a flagship if you just do normal usage and not in to crazy gaming.
As long as you don't mind giving up a few bells and whistles (nfc, usb 3.0, "fast charge" mode), this is a flagship phone for half the price! No complaints!
reviews.review_header: As long as you don't mind giving up a few ...

reviews.review_text: Neat design, solid build, good battery life, very high ROI phone!

I've had no problems with the phone so far and I'm loving it. The only thing about it I care for is that the metal back tends to get smudged fairly easy. But that can easily be fixed by just getting a case. The size of the phone is great and the cameras (though I don't take many pictures) are also great. Though I normally only use phones to browse the internet and of course make calls, this phone has a lot of useful features for a (at my time of purchase) $150 phone.

Love this phone! I purchased it because I simply can't afford the new Samsung or Apple phones. This is better! Don't spend hundreds on those brands when you can get this for a third of the cost. I like the ease of use ( user interface is simple), the space for an extra memory card and dual cameras. So far this phone is worth every penny!

I can't believe how nice this phone is! I thought one thousand reviews can't be wrong. I was right. The phone sets up easy. Is seemless. No bloatware that disrupts the simplicity and power of the phone. Bought it for 150 during black friday week. This phone is a darn good deal for 200 dollars. Must buy. Very happy.
reviews.review_header: I can't believe how nice this phone is

reviews.review_text: Such a great phone for the price. I have used Huawei before in China but was worried how it would work here in Canada. Works great here and I use Fido, as its one of the only options here. The phone is fast and I have had 0 complications using it. The fingerprint reader works great as well. I would recommend this phone to anyone looking for a budget phone but still wants bells and whistles to it. Videos look great on here if you like to stream Youtube or Netflix. Only issue I have found is that it only has 1 speaker and it is hard to hear sometimes when doing a call on speaker phone or watching movies.

The only good thing about this phone is the long battery life. The software that it runs on is very glitchy. Apps and camera froze constantly, and the worst part was that at least on T-Mobile, calls would go straight to voicemail 50% of the times, and forget about getting text messages on time. The volume on the speakers, even when plugging in external speakers or headphones is extremely low. I bought two of these and we only used them for 3 full months. Replaced them with a LG V30 and all reception problems went away. Maybe it has to do with not being a T-Mobile phone, though it's unlocked and GSM.
reviews.review_header: The only good thing about this phone is the long battery life

reviews.review_text: My husband recently got this phone and I'm seriously going to get myself one as soon as I can. He loves everything about it, like processing power and battery life. And the speakers on it are amazing. It look really nice too. We go through a lot of phones because we buy refurbished phones for the most part to save on money. We spend about this much on phones. A lot of them end up crapping out after a few months to a year, but their performance is nowhere near as good as this phone. I highly recommend it to anyone that wants to spend less than 200 on a phone.
reviews.review_header: Best phone we've purchased in the last few years.

reviews.review_text: I'm using this phone right now. I've screwed up typing several times because it freezes and the microphone button location sucks. The battery lasts less than half a day. The phone freezes and is slow, constantly. The camera is subpar. I don't recommend it.

Great Phone, works incredibly well. I've had the phone for about 6 months now and the headphone jack completely stopped working and eventually so did the bluetooth. The phone freezes a lot and become slower and slower the older it gets but overall, for a budget phone it is okay.

This is an excellent alternative to the top name brand phones people are going broke to lease every month. For $150, I own this one and it can do all the things my friends' $1000 phones can do and more. I love it!
reviews.review_header: This is an excellent alternative to the top name brand phones people are ...

reviews.review_text: Just received my new phone. Haven't use it yet but I went through it. I wanted to buy the 8x but didn't have enough, maybe later in the future. I love everything about the phone. It's just perfect and better than Samsung
reviews.review_header: I love everything about the phone

reviews.review_text: I wanted to LOVE this phone... I really did. Coming from a Nexus 6P, I love the fingerprint reader and the camera is pretty decent as well. The software UI is unbearable. How anyone uses this is beyond me. It's pathetic. I only bought this phone because Huawei had promised a EMUI 5 update with Android N. This isn't the case and I can't wait for it. EMUI 4.1 is not the worst thing in the world but it's close.

Great phone for a great price got it for my dad as he has never had a smartphone before. Very easy to use and well worth the price i bought it for ($150.00) highly recommend this phone if you are either transitioning from a flip phone to a smartphone or just would like smartphone features without the typical smartphone price tag.
reviews.review_header: Great phone for a great price got it for my ...

reviews.review_text: First, I previously owned the 5X. I bought it because I wanted an unlocked, dual-SIM phone with an option for an SD card. Here's the only downside to the 6X compared to the 5X: the 6X only allows you to have two SIM cards OR one SIM and one SD card... you can't have two SIM cards and an SD card in the 6X at the same time. Not a big deal, I'll just switch cards out when necessary but still.... I'm not entirely sure why this was changed. Besides this, the 6X is just better.... Faster, better screen, better camera, etc. It's more rounded than the 5X which is largely irrelevant considering it's in a case. For $249 it's a great value.
reviews.review_header: Better than the 5X in every way....except one

reviews.review_text: Brought 3 of these. Here's my quick review: Pros: Great product for the value Fast finger print reader decent screen Cons: Poor reception at certain areas resulting in dropped calls( calls didn't rang, just an indicator of missed calls afterwards) Oddly enough, i notice the color and brightness between two of the phones were different. One were brighter than the other( and yes i check the screen brightness)
reviews.review_header: Great product for the value but poor call reception and possibly screen brightness issues

reviews.review_text: I've had this phone for about 4 months now. The battery on this phone makes it worth while. Android is Android, apps are apps. If I'm not doing much of anything with it, besides calls and texts, and a few minutes of reading a day, it can go 3-4 days between charges. Add more app usage, media streaming, and you go down to 2-3 days.
reviews.review_header: Great phone at the price point.

reviews.review_text: Received this phone about a month ago- here's my diagnosis. Later on the first day I got the phone I noticed the screen would glitch or skip back and forth when scrolling every now and then. It's done it everyday since and tends to happen more when temperature drops. I also believe the speaker came to me as a dud. It's crackly and has to be the worst smartphone speaker I've ever heard. Called both Honor and Amazon reps several weeks ago to resolve this and neither could resolve my issues without further inconveniencing me. That's why my rating is a 2/5. Aside from my screen doing this annoying glitch 30% of the time and my speaker music being garbage it's a great phone.

This phone and software has multiple issues. In the beginning it was fine. With updates it got worse. One thing that aggravates me is when I click on my messages app it takes me to another location such as photos. It also needs to have the option to select multiple messages at once to delete. That saves lots of time. I'm not satisfied enough to buy another phone made by this company.
reviews.review_header: In the beginning it was fine. With updates it got worse

reviews.review_text: UPDATE after one week: I love this phone!!! Every day I like it better! Upgrading my stars from 4 to 5 ORIGINAL REVIEW: Ordered one for myself and one for my wife. She has an Honor 5X and loves it, so I thought I'd give this a try for myself. Wife uses hers for constant conversations and facebook/youtube. I use mine only for phone/text and to play music from my SD cards, played into my Sennheiser PXC 550 headphones. Both phones work very well indeed for our needs. Though the 6X does drain its battery faster than my old phone (5000 ma/h battery) it is still better than phones I've had previously and it doesn't really affect me since I can charge from anywhere using my battery pack. What IS noticeable, however, is the SPEED of this phone compared to ANY I've had before, the fast octacore CPU and the 3gb RAM do their job very nicely. It does not stall, freeze, hesitate in any way for me. The fingerprint reader unlocks the phone instantly... so fast, in fact that I tried opening it with every fingerprint I have, just to see if they're faking it. Nope, it's for real. I set it for BOTH of my index fingerprints to make it simpler to grab and open with either hand. Cameras: For my purpose, this is far better than expected. My previous phones had "adequate" cameras that I'd use if I didn't care about quality (I have a Canon and a Panasonic Lumix G7 for high quality photos and videos)... but this little phone rivals those in its quality once you learn how to use it. The video does not have the stabilization feature that the high priced cellphones have, or my dedicated cameras... so panning slowly is a bit jittery... but nobody notices it but me so far. HOWEVER, my phone had difficulties in setting up. The wife's did not. Then suddenly they decided to update to a better EMUI (the user interface that is Android but looks like an iPhone)... and all of the difficulties ended. We are happy with the phones, but it would have saved me several hours if the full updated EMUI was originally installed.
Awesome phone. Upgraded to 7.0 by itself no computer. Am very happy with my new phone!! Awesome 📷

I've gone back and forth with Samsung, Huawei two times and I'm back with Huawei with the Honor 6X and am very happy with this phone. For the price you get pretty much a Samsung but without the Samsung price, actually think the Mates and Honor's might even be better? All in all we never really own a phone for more than a couple of years so why not try these fantastic Huawei phones.
reviews.review_header: Huawei two times and I'm back with Huawei with the Honor 6X and am very happy with this phone

reviews.review_text: Beautiful pictures, love the large screen, first time battery use battery lasted 24 hours with a lot of use. Easily the best phone I've ever had.
I bought Honor 6x two weeks ago. The product work so well that I bought another one for my wife. My carrier is T Mobile. If you want to save your hard earned money, this is the way to go.
reviews.review_header: I bought Honor 6x two weeks ago. The product ...

reviews.review_text: I have both 5X and 6X. I am not seeing that much of an improvement on performance in 6x compared to its predecessor. To me it looks like the performance is worse :(. The camera lag is extremely bad. That said, the pictures are a little bit better than 5x. Huawei has given a bigger screen and 2 cameras for an affordable price range. However, when it comes to performance its thumbs down from me. My advice would be to shell out some more dollars for a better phone unless you are ok with waiting forever to take a picture and constantly close apps to reduce phone lag.
reviews.review_header: To me it looks like the performance is worse

reviews.review_text: One of the best phones I've ever had. Love how fast it is and the fingerprint scanner is really responsive. Had it for about a month right now unlocked.
Overall very good for the money. Nice photos, responsive. A word of warning, wifi calling is not possible with TMobile service! If that is something that you need, look elsewhere!
Good product, but I'm having a problem moving apps from inturnel memory to the SD card. It would be 5 🌟 if weren't for the SD card problem.Help elcliff@aol.com
reviews.review_header: Good product, but I'm having a problem moving apps ...

reviews.review_text: So far I am enjoying my new phone. I love the feel of the phone. I am not very technology inclined, but I had no problem setting up this phone. I did have to purchase a new sim card from T-Mobile, because my old one was outdated. The guy at T-Mobile liked the phone also.

This phone has very weak reception with T-Mobile, which I can hardly make a clear phone call; and it can hardly get 3G or 4G data. When I insert the same SIM card to another phone, it gets strong reception. I asked the seller for this question, he just gave me a HuaWei customer service number and let me to call them. When I called them, they were like knowing nothing. Do NOT waste your money on this phone.

reviews.review_text: I switched to this phone from a Samsung Galaxy Edge S6. This may seem like a massive downgrade for some folks, but I am actually enjoying the Honor 6X more than the Edge S6, which I'll explain below in my comprehensive review. Body/Form-Factor (4/5): The Honor 6X isn't anything really spectacular to look at, but it feels durable and nice in the hand. It's aesthetic is decently pleasing to me. I do not enjoy phones that are trying to be overly flashy or fancy (mainly because I put a case on them anyway). It fits well in the hand and I love that all the buttons are on the right-side. The S6 has the volume buttons on the left-hand side which was annoying for one-handed use. The placement of the fingerprint reader is amazing, I have seen it on the back in other phones, but I think Huawei found the sweet-spot for me. It's in the PERFECT place for my long fingers. Otherwise, the build-quality is solid, it doesn't feel like it would explode on impact if I dropped it. On the other hand, the S6 was nasty-feeling without a case with all the glass and was so thin I feared shattering it. Display (4/5): For a mid-range budget phone the display is very attractive. There is some slight saturation on blacks, and reds seem to POP with intensity. This is especially noticeable using the camera. However, I am fond of black-themed UIs, so I have black on black and it actually looks very nice without too much saturation. You're not going to get the intense color-ranges you will with Samsung's AMOLED screen. The Honor 6X is a standard IPS LCD screen, coming in at 1080x1920 with a ~403 PPI density. Better than other mid-range devices, and you really can't beat that for the price. The screen is crisp and clear, if you're comparing it to a high-range phone, you're going to be disappointed. However, remembering you only paid ~$250 (as of this review) then you'll be pleasantly surprised! I have used the phone in bright light and darkest night, with no issues. Screen is amazing for the price, but there are better screens on higher-end phones (if you want to pay for them, that is). Screen, Physical (2/5): I had to say something about the actual GLASS that comes with the device. It comes with a pre-installed screen protector, it doesn't look like a factory film, it literally looks like a SCREEN PROTECTOR (however it's really not, it's just a cheap plastic thing that doesn't like to come off). If you're buying this phone do yourself a favor and GET A SCREEN PROTECTOR ASAP. I always protect my devices with either a glass or the "liquid" screen protectors (the gel-like kind) and this phone absolutely has to have one. I did a screen stress-test and it received several small scratches just by being in my pocket for a day without a protector, something a phone with any kind of tempered glass or gorilla glass would not do. It's not super bad, you're not going to encounter any massive scrapes from daily use if you carry it without anything else in your pocket, but you WILL get a lot of small, annoying scratches. The good news is any glass or gel screen protector will cover those right up! Launcher, Emotion UI (3/5): EMUI get's a pretty bad rap, but it's honestly not THAT bad. My biggest gripe is the lack of an app drawer, it forces everything to the main screen, which can get pretty cluttered even if you're using the folders. Alas, this is not a heavily weighing factor for me, because third-party launchers exist. Other than that it's a fairly standard launcher, it's actually very snappy and fast. If you can get over the no app drawer, then it shouldn't be an issue at all. Speed/Snappiness/Responsiveness (5/5): The Honor 6X is sporting a Kirin 655, 2.1GHz Cortex-A53 (with a Mali-T830MP2 GPU), which is an impressive chip for the price. I did a stress test with YouTube, a 3D game, Facebook, Chrome (with multiple windows), Google Maps, and Google Music all in the background of the device at once and saw only a minimal amount of device lag. Albeit, in reality, I wouldn't have all those things open at once anyway. Standard use sees absolutely no lag and the device is always incredibly responsive. One of the biggest issues I have had with trying out mid-tier budget phones is that after a couple of apps open they DRAGGGGG to almost a halt before closing something. This phone handles it like a bloody champ! External SD Card Slot (5/5): Thought I'd just add this here, most expensive phones these days are sorely lacking this, and I do love to download everything and anything. Especially since I use my device everyday as a music player, so I require a lot of space! You can add a 256 GB SD card for all your HD videos and music on the go! Camera (5/5): This is really where this phone SHINES. All the other mid-tier phones I have tried all have a terribad camera. I mean, it's normally VERY bad. If you're in the market for a budget phone and want a nice camera, look no further. This camera rivals my Edge S6 (which I have touted as the best camera on any smartphone, when it came out). The camera app has a bunch of awesome built-in features and you can tell they spent some time here. The Pro Photo mode really lets you change anything you want to get that AWESOME shot. HDR works as intended. The "Good Food" option seems to be some sort of macro setting, accentuating the warm tones. The "Light Painting" feature is actually really cool, it mimics and recreates those cool light-shots you can get from moving cars or spelling stuff out with lights! I had great fun with the "Slo-Mo" mode, where you can make things slow motion and even edit whatever is slow motion at the end of it. The "Document Scan" mode works AMAZINGLY. It will auto-snap and crop any document you're currently trying to take a picture of and then auto-edit it for readability. I used it at work to take a lazy-screencap of a document on my computer monitor and it worked GREAT! The secondary camera is actually very, very nice. Coming in at 8MP, and an auto-beauty mode for those flawless selfies! It has all the same features as the standard camera so they didn't skimp on all the features just because it's a secondary. I'd also like to add that Huawei integrated a classic Gallery instead of incorporating Photos like almost every other phone has done. I really miss the old-school gallery, and I thank Huawei for actually including one instead of me having to pay for a decent one through Google Play. Sound (2/5): The headset speaker is decent, you can definitely hear people. They're not particularity crisp or mega-clear. You can certainly hear them just fine, the loudness isn't a big issue. The call quality is varying, it might be my service, who knows. The speaker is sorely lacking, it's not loud and at it's max volume it kind of sounds like a muffled room noise. It's not AMAZINGLY bad, but if you're an audiophile looking for a decent speaker, this is not the budget phone for you (I don't think audiophile and budget should be used in the same sentence). It gets the job done, I usually carry headphones or a bluetooth speaker with my anyway so this didn't shy me away from the phone at all, so I don't weight very heavily on this part. Ports/Comms (3/5): The ONLY reason I'm giving this a 3/5 is because it lacks 5 GHz Wi-fi. Something that seemingly every other mid-tier phone has incorporated, Huawei decided to just not on the Honor 6X. This is a bit annoying to me because I was seriously spoiled on my 5 GHz wi-fi at my house. No NFC, so if you're looking to use Android Pay, you'll probably have to sync a smartwatch to the phone! Other than that, there's v4.1 bluetooth chip with all the trimmings, it works flawlessly and amazingly. It doesn't seem to use any power at all! MicroUSB. Really Huawei? C'mon you could of scored a 5/5 with me with USB-C and 5 GHz wi-fi! With almost every other phone moving over now to USB-C (sans Samsung) it would seem natural that Hauwei would do this. They're already using it on all their other flagship phones. I guess it was to save on the price, which I can totally get. However I really, really love USB-C. Fingerprint Reader (5/5): Thought I'd throw this in here because most fingerprint readers are just awful. Not in terms of functionality, but in positioning. The reader on the Honor 6X is AMAZINGLY places for actual use. The S6 Edge has it on the front of the phone which is useless for me, because I normally place my phone face-down or it's in my pocket with the screen toward me. The response time on the reader is insane! One micro-second tap and BAM you're in. At first I thought it was fake, so I had several buddies try it and NOPE! Wouldn't let them in. Way to put an awesome reader that definitely rivals the high-end phones Huawei! Battery (5/5): Wow, my S6 Edge had a terrible battery life if you compare it to the Honor 6X. I use data, bluetooth, wi-fi and max screen brightness everyday. I'm a Reddit and YouTube lover so I'm constantly on those throughout the day. With all that on, using a Reddit app probably ~20 times a day and watching about ~30 minutes of YouTube everyday I still get home after a 12 hour work-day with about 40% battery left. With my S6 I ALWAYS had to plug it in mid-day because it would be at 10% at 3 PM. With the Honor 6X I just plug it in once a night and leave it there. On my days off I don't even have to charge it at night, it's normally sitting at about 80% without heavy use. There's also a "Phone Optimizer" built in that helps extend battery life. It will even tell you how much battery life it might save if you turn off X feature. Overall (5/5): Despite the small downsides, the Honor 6X comes in swinging at a $250 price point. If you're looking for a feature-packed phone that has an awesome camera and amazing battery life, LOOK NO FURTHER! I am currently using this device as my main device. I have NEVER used a mid-tier budget phone as a main device, but this one really bit me! Great job Huawei, the Honor 6X is awesome!
reviews.review_header: Awesome Camera, Amazing Battery Life, and overall Top-Tier Budget Device!

reviews.review_text: Better than average specs mean faster response time and good storage for photos at an affordable price. I especially appreciate the robust battery, which gives me four days before recharge.

reviews.review_text: Good bang for your dollar. If you want performance but don't want to cough up $500 for a brand name like Samsung, go with this one.

Pros: Fingerprint scanner works great, fast processor, lots of memory, long battery life and fast charging (if you use the huawei charger) Cons: A bit bigger than I expected (my fault though, the size is listed on in the description) I've had this phone for a little over 3 months and I freakin love it. I'm not a super tech savvy user. I just wanted something cheap that compared well to the previous gen Samsung Galaxy and iPhone. First of all the fingerprint scanner. This is my first phone with a fingerprint scanner. When I ordered this phone I didn't really think much about this feature. Now that I have it I can't imagine going back to a phone that doesn't have one. It makes unlocking the phone so effortless. Also putting the fingerprint on the back of the phone, just below the camera lenses, was a brilliantly elegant engineering idea. Seriously, I've showed this to my friends with iPhones and they've all said they wish Apple had put the finger scanner on the back too. Basically the difference is I can pick up my phone and unlock it in one motion, because all I have to do is place either my right or left index finger on the scanner. I'm cradling the phone in my hand anyway, it's so easy to just press my finger against the scanner in the fraction of a second it takes me to pick up my phone. Some people have complained about the UI. It's not that bad, or wasn't anyway. Huawei just rolled out a new UI with a new update. The new one is ok. It's very similar to Samsung's. I didn't mind the old one, and I don't mind the new one either. My only complaint is that the phone is bigger than my old Samsung Galaxy, but that's on me for not paying attention to the size in the description. I wish it were a bit smaller, but honestly I've grown to live with the size. It's not ridiculously big, but it's big. At this point it's just something I tolerate because I love everything else about the phone. The camera is pretty good, but not great. Not as good as my Dad's Galaxy 8, but then again that phone is a lot more expensive. I don't care that much about camera quality anyway.
reviews.review_header: Fingerprint scanner works great, fast processor

reviews.review_text: UPDATE 4/15/18 - After finally receiving my Oreo update from Sprint, I can say all the problems I had been having with this phone (dropped calls, freezing 3-4 times per day, etc) are all fixed. Now this phone is, at last, a fantastic device agian. Essential has been quick and consistent with the updates. However, I highly suggest you buy it unlocked so you don't have to deal with the frustration of carrier delays to updates. First off—the tech site reviews for this phone range from lukewarm to horrible, which almost caused me to do an immediate exchange without even opening the box, but I decided to give the Essential phone a shot for a day or two. I am glad I did because I can honestly see no reason why this phone has received the kinds of reviews that have littered the online tech websites. The Essential PH-1 is an elegant, powerful, and smooth-working device that is as well designed, physically, as any phone I have ever held in my hands. Now that its price has been cut down to $499, it's a complete no-brainer. Hardware Simply put, the Essential phone is an eye-catcher. The ceramic back is clean and beautiful, though it does attract fingerprints like crazy—of course, which phone doesn't, these days? The titanium frame offers a high-end feel to it, and the front screen is made of Gorilla Glass 5. It is a heavy, substantial phone, given its relative size. Essential claims it needs no protective case, and indeed if you look for one, you are hard-pressed to find a case anywhere. Amazon pretty much only offers skins, which is somewhat frightening to consider. However, the ceramic back is comfortable to hold onto, though it does tend to slide off surfaces if they’re not flat. It comes with a speaker on the bottom side that is just OK. You will not be listening to music through this speaker unless you have no other choice. That is a non-issue for me, but it is something you might consider. Also, going with what seems to be a trend in smartphones, the Essential phone does not have a headphone jack, though it does come with an adapter dongle which fits into the USB-C port. Personally, I almost never use headphones, so it’s another non-issue for me. There is a powerful Snapdragon 835 processor under the hood and 4GB of memory, which is more than enough for just about anyone. There is 128 gig of storage that comes standard...that's right, standard. Given that most phones charge you a lot more for that much storage, it's a great deal--especially at the currently reduced prices. The fingerprint sensor works every time, perfectly, and very quickly. It’s the fastest fingerprint scanner I’ve ever used, and unlike the S8, the sensor sits in a convenient place on the back. The PH-1 is not water-proof. It’s rated only to withstand a light sprinkle or splash, and that’s about it. Screen The screen is not OLED, which is something that has stirred up some controversy, at least among reviewers and phone junkies. However, Essential’s LCD screen is crisp and quite bright—it renders colors beautifully. Comparing it to the Galaxy S8, side by side, the difference was not as stark as one might believe. Colors pop and blacks are particularly rich for a non-OLED screen. The bezel-less design looks gorgeous, and the little camera notch at the top seems to disappear almost immediately. No, this screen is not as flashy as the one on the Galaxy S8, but it’s not too far behind. I find Essential’s screen is not as saturated as Samsung’s and is much easier on the eyes for long periods of viewing. Battery So far, the battery pretty much lasts the day. I usually have to charge when I get home in the evening, which is disappointing but typical of every phone I've used. The phone also comes with a fast charging and a USB-c cable with a high end braided design. It charges up really fast. Software The Essential PH-1 comes loaded with stock Android and almost nothing else. This lack of bloatware is refreshing, especially after using Samsung’s software. The phone zips along, and I have so far encountered no glitches or stutters at all. Recent updates have cleared up some glitches and shutdowns that were plaguing the phone’s early release. Now, it’s smooth and consistent with an experience much like what you would find with iOS. In fact, iPhone users thinking of switching to Android might want to consider the Essential, as it would be an easier transition than having to figure out a whole lot of bloatware. Unlike most other Android phones, Essential doesn’t have any of the redundancies that cause so many switchers to run back to Apple—no double notifications for two different email clients or three separate weather apps. It’s basically like a Pixel phone, but with a better screen and more impressive physical design. Camera Here is where the controversy with this phone actually lies, and where I feel the need to clear up a whole lot of misconceptions. Many phone reviewers have trashed the camera, probably because they were using a version that Essential should never have sent out. Just remember that when you’re reading those reviews, most of them were written in July or August, which is light years away from where this phone currently sits. In short, this phone’s camera is good in its current state. I see very little difference between photos taken with this camera and the iPhone 7 Plus I used this past year. It’s true there had been some software issues with the onboard camera app, but they seem to have been fixed over the course of several recent updates. This camera produces true colors that sometimes can still be slightly dark in less than ideal lighting conditions. However, I tried a side by side test with a Galaxy S8+, and I found each camera had strengths and weaknesses when it came to shooting in low light. The Galaxy tended to overexpose the photo, washing out the colors, or oversaturating the shot. The Essential tended to replicate a truer version of the room, which meant some parts were slightly dark, but the subject was closer to its actual color. The Essential camera operates with one color camera and one black and white camera, using software to combine the two images to provide truer colors and more clarity. When it first shipped (especially the versions sent to tech reviewers), the software was a mess, causing the camera to lag, shut down, freeze, and take horrible shots, especially in low lighting. However, these deficiencies were not caused by the cameras themselves, but the software. That’s a good thing because software can be sorted out and fixed, which is what Essential has done—and what they continue to do. In fact, a significant software update came just two nights ago, fixing the speed with which the app combines the color and black and white images. By the way, I've been having A LOT of fun using the mono-mode black and white camera. It takes some of the sharpest images I've ever taken on a phone camera. So, what’s the verdict on this supposedly terrible camera? After the recent updates, it’s a good camera with the potential to be great, if Essential continues to make incremental adjustments, which they do seem to be committed to. Conclusion Are there drawbacks? Sure! There are drawbacks to virtually any phone you buy. The lack of waterproofing and no headphone jack might turn some people away, understandably. Also, the fact that you cannot buy a protective case for this phone is highly worrisome. I am not sure I trust them when they say the titanium is so strong it does not need a case. One drop straight to that Gorilla Glass and… However, the strengths of the Essential phone far outweigh those drawbacks, at least for me, and the PH-1 should at least warrant more consideration than it’s gotten from the tech media. If you’ve lusted after this phone, please don’t be frightened away by the bad publicity. Give it a shot and I think you will be pleasantly surprised. UPDATE 12/4/17 After two months of use, I still think this is a very good phone with smooth, fast, reliable performance. The recent updates have been great. Essential continues to release consistent updates, especially to the camera app which has had some amazing improvements lately--including a portrait mode that rivals that on the iPhone and Pixel. And I have to say, as a fan of black and white photography, the mono mode camera is one of my favorite things ever. There has been one hiccup--once in a while it freezes and I have to do a hard reset. It's not a big deal and hasn't happened too often, and thankfully the phone powers up fast, but I do hope they sort this issue out soon. Sprint has been very slow to release the latest build, so perhaps it will be handled in that update. Plus, Oreo looks to be coming in the relatively near future! UPDATE 11/4/17 - After a month of use, I can comfortably say this is a fantastic device and Essential continues to support it with bi-monthly updates. The latest update fixed some touch issues that some people were having (I didn't) and introduced a few gestures to the fingerprint sensor, like those on the Pixel phone. There is now a case available on Amazon...I bought it and it's not too bad. Personally, I like going without the case because the phone is really easy to grip. I've heard that soon Essential will be adding a "portrait mode" to the camera app, which is exciting, and of course, Oreo is supposed to be on its way before long too. I have been using the camera a lot and I feel they are getting close to just right under low light conditions. In normal lighting, there's no problem at all. And the mono mode black and white camera takes some of the best photos I have ever taken on a phone. The verdict remains the same...only with some increased vehemence. If you're a fan of stock android, fast smooth performance, and beautifully designed devices, there shouldn't be much of a debate. Buy this phone!

[Nov update: adding one star (4 all in all) given $200 price drop] [See Oct 18 update including Pixel 2 comparison] I was not expecting to love the Essential Phone. “Kudos to Essential for what they are trying to achieve, but no way they can compete with the incumbents” … Or so I thought! Press reviews got me intrigued enough to give it a try (after checking the return policy). I have now been using the Essential Phone as my primary device for 3 days and I LOVE IT. I’ll update this review as things progress. Other reviews are doing a great job going into many aspects so I’ll just add my perspective as a user (see the kind of user I am at the bottom). DESIGN is a WINNER ( + ) Beautiful (look at it) ( + ) Simple/ergonomic (stock Android + no bloatware) ( + ) Different (people ask me about it) yet not quirky It JUST WORKS ( + ) A LOT of screen in a truly one-handed form factor, ( + ) Touch input works great ( + ) Great call quality, ( + ) Fast camera, ( + ) All day battery, ( + ) Fast and accurate fingerprint sensor (I tried many & they aren’t all the same, this one is the real deal) ( + ) “Accidental drop” resilient (accidentally tested already) meaning I don’t need a case (at long last a beautiful phone that doesn’t need a case) The PRICE is RIGHT (~$300 below similarly spec’d premium phones). At $500, it is a great value (but still an expensive phone — premium materials etc.)! The “flaws” I don’t care much about (I call them SMART TRADE-OFFS) ( + / — ) Camera/Picture quality (good enough for me), ( + / — ) Not for VR (still a “niche” use case), ( + / — ) Not waterproof (I don’t swim with my phone), ( + / — ) No headphone jack (I love USB-C), ( + / — ) Weak built-in speaker (I use a headset or an actual high quality speaker when I need good/loud sound), ( + / — ) Unclear whether front facing camera will enable advanced face recognition use cases (the future is coming but I live in the present) The things I wish it did better (or “Why not a 5 star rating”) ( — ) I’d like the screen to be brighter / colors to be more vivid. Those with the current generation of iPhones won’t necessarily mind, but for folks used to premium (AM)OLED phones (e.g. Samsung, Google Pixel, LG, etc.), it might very well be a deal breaker. ( — ) I’d like the camera app to be better, starting with “manual” mode (like what Motorola does). I am confident Andy’s team will improve the camera app though, they already have in the past month as per the press. This phone is right for me, but is it right for you? The kind of user I am - I live in the cloud. I love Google services (and Amazon’s too!). I appreciate Apple’s “less is more” design principles and the superb quality and durability of their products, but I don’t like that it is often “their way or no way”. - I use my phone a lot, mostly as a work tool (+ videos, and a few games for my kids). - I have 121 apps installed (for those who care to know, I included my home screen with the 30 or so that I use daily). - I am on T-Mobile. - I am “cheap” (or to put it nicely: “savvy”). I don’t like to pay for the brand premium or the fanciness I don’t need. I am fine paying for quality or “fair trade / eco friendliness”, but I have found that “high quality on the basics” and “inexpensive” actually align * Oct 18 update: 50 days in, I am sticking with the Essential Phone. But I confirm my "not for everyone" comment. I think for most people, the Pixel 2 is a better choice (congrats team Google!) * Day 50: new pros and new cons (+) It still looks like new despite my having used it without a case. That is very impressive (I tend to bend my phones, or scratch them, or both)! (+) The charger Andy's team included is AMAZING (it must have been pricey). I can easily charge my laptop with it (USB C) (-) The camera is starting to bother me. I downloaded another camera app... (-) The power button below the volume button seems suboptimal to me (-) That phone is slippery... I haven't found an elegant solution (I really dont want to add a skin or a case, but I'll keep looking (ideas?) Comparison with Pixel 2 If you want stock Android, and a phone that just works, the default choice is Google's Pixel. So I got the Pixel 2 (disclosure: I know and admire the team who built it) *Where PH1 wins* - It has a much bigger screen despite being slightly smaller than the Pixel 2, which means a better browsing experience, more apps on the home screen. You just see more (see the pictures). - PH1 seems more durable to me. Pixel 2's coating looks like a great improvement over last year's metallic paint (that tended to chip off quickly), but I don't think it will beat ceramic and titanium. * Where Pixel 2 wins * - Pixel's camera is AWESOME. Even I became an ok photographer. It is incredibly fast, and the pictures turn out super sharp, with great colors, etc. The movies are amazing as well. - much better speaker (and there are 2 of them) - UI significantly more responsive - Water proof - Squeezable assistant is cute and may create a warm emotional bond... we shall see *One more thing* I now have the 360 degree camera and I must say I really like it
reviews.review_header: Perfect for me (4.7 stars), arguably not for everyone (4 stars all in all?)

reviews.review_text: I've been using the Essential Phone for close to a month now, and am currently reviewing it after receiving my Pixel 2 phone a few days ago to test both. After playing around with the controversial camera on both devices, I am happy with returning my Pixel 2 in a few days. Make no mistake, the Pixel 2 has a wonderful camera. Even after sideloading the Google Camera app on to the Essential Phone, there were still noticeable differences in the low-light picture quality and the camera speed. I even compared them both with the iPhone X, and the Pixel 2 still arguably came out on top. But aside from that, I can't say that the Pixel 2 has anything else that I don't get with the Essential Phone, personally. Waterproofing is nice, but I've never dropped my phone in any body of water in the 10 years I've been owning a cellphone. Stereo speakers are also nice, but I use them about once a week at highest frequency. Google's timely updates do sound very tempting, but I'm very happy that Essential has just rolled out their Oreo beta a week ago, with the final build coming this year. This leaves the physical build, price, screen and battery life as the determining factors. The build quality and aesthetics of the Essential wins hands-down for me. No contest there. So is the price. I got my Essential for $400 (after taking advantage of Amazon's additional $50 gift card promo). And the Pixel 2 is priced at $740 (after the $115 trade-in credit I'd get with my old Nexus). The $300 difference is quite stark at this point. OLED is nice. Sure. But after using the 5.7in display on the Essential, I don't think I can go back to the meager 5in display found in the Pixel 2. The higher contrast attributed to the OLED panel found in the Pixel 2 is nice, but the difference is barely noticeable. The main beneficiary of this technology would be the lower power usage. Which brings me to the battery. The 3000mah battery found in the Essential should make up for the extra juice required to run the LCD panel. After testing both for the past few days, I can't say if there's a clear winner between the two. The Pixel 2's smaller battery can be compensated by the better software optimization by Google to ensure one full day of use. Essential might still have a few kinks to iron out with their software to ensure they don't unintentionally drain the battery life through poor software optimization. Both have been giving me full-day use with more than enough to spare (25%-50% left in the tank on a good day). In the end, I feel like the Essential is a better match for me. Your opinion and needs might differ, but I hope this review gave you some additional peace of mind before taking the lunge. Cheers!
reviews.review_header: I am happy with returning my Pixel 2 in a few days

reviews.review_text: Oh what to say? Disappointment? I researched this phone a lot. I work in tech. It came down to this or the pixel 2. I prefer small phones and not phablets. I chose essential because it's different, it's a small form factor, the large screen real estate relative to size of phone, and flagship specs. The recent discount was the tipping point. Go with the essential, right? Who cares it doesn't have an sd card slot, an aux input for audio, or amoled display. This actually looks very good in the sun. Fact it's LCD is ok. So why 3 stars? Bugs...freaking bugs! How else do you explain after four days of use pretty consistent freezing and lack of touch recognition with very light use? My phone has updated twice since it arrived from amazon last Saturday, Oct. 28. Nothing has improved. I was texting today...texting..and my phone froze for a good 3 seconds while I tried to text a response back. Really? I'm not playing games on this. I'm texting, surfing the web, using gps, pretty much "essential" stuff, right? Imagine this phone in a year, or two years, with these issues. I visited the android forums to find out why. Turns out these are hit and miss issues and certainly they exist for many buyers. I'm giving this a week before sending it back and buying a pixel 2. I like underdogs. I support start ups. This phone, though, needs to be fixed soon or I'm sending it back. Even at 500...I can't recall the last time I,spent this much and has similar issues. Essential, fix this phone! I want to support you.
reviews.review_header: Disappointment? I researched this phone a lot

reviews.review_text: DISCLAIMER: This is purely my experience, your opinion and experience will vary, naturally. With most of my smartphone experience being on Android, I was letdown to say the least with all the typical inconsistencies and experiences I had over the years. The last year or so I was using an iPhone and pretty much got used to iOS and incorporating the features and nuances to my workflow day in and day out but missed the freedom of Android dearly. Being an avid Android enthusiast and devouring any bit of Essential phone news I can find since it was initially announced, it was hard to resist at least trying it before committing to the iPhone further with the recent iPhone 8 Plus. Going into the Sprint store and seeing the Essential phone their and having some quick hands-on time with it, I was immediately impressed with the hand-in feel. Having read countless reviews with so much high praise going to the build quality, I was in complete agreement after my time with it. The thought of such a high end Android phone and with the backing of Andy Rubin as the project's leader, it was very hard to pass up and I am so glad I didn't pass on it. It was definitely an Ahhh moment when I opened to box, I probably put too much emphasis on presentation but I am so glad I'm not the only one that obsesses over small details. The unboxing tells you that this is a special device and Essential took extra care in making sure you know that they thought so too. The build quality is unlike any other phone I've held and I have about a dozen high end phones from every smartphone era dating back to 2007 and smartphone platform. Also details like the beautiful braided USB-C charging cable with metal end caps and the metal 27W charging brick, you rarely if ever see such attention being paid to the included accessories. Build quality, presentation aside, focusing on the phone and how it is to use. For me for the most part, it is a joy to use. Running as pure Android as you will find (Pixel isn't pure AOSP Android anymore like Nexus was), everything is generally smooth and fast. Having the latest Snapdragon 835 will do that and a 2017 standard for RAM at 4GB is also good enough for most anything you wanna throw at it. Those who have complained about camera quality and camera speed, I will say first off that I am not a heavy camera user on a smartphone, only taking pictures on occasion so the best camera isn't a high requirement for me, if it is to you, you may want to look at the LG V30 or the S8/S8+, Pixel or iPhone. Overall usability to me is far more important and being able to quickly transition between apps/screens is a joy to experience on a device with no bloatware to speak of, just clean Android as Andy Rubin intended with this device. If build quality, up to date Android releases, a fast, fluid UI experience are things you value then you can't go wrong with the Essential.

tl;dr 1. This phone is amazing in many ways 2. Most reviews from pre-November were based on at least 3 software updates behind the current version and much has improved. 3. When you get this phone and it asks you to install one update, you are not done: you must go to to settings->about phone->system update and check for another one. You must repeat this process until it tells you that "Your system is up to date". If you don't do this then you are likely still on old, buggier versions of the software. I'm guessing that some of the recent reviewers here have not done this. My moto x pure had been a great phone, but I needed to replace it for two reasons: the battery was never great and getting worse as it aged, and I was getting tired of carrying this giant thing in my pocket. If not for those things I would have hung on to it. What I wanted in a new phone: everything that was great about the moto x pure: runs Android; great looking, large, and very bright screen; great audio from the front facing stereo speakers; great camera; no bloatware; a quick way to launch the camera which was the same whether locked or unlocked; fast and smooth; durable and scratch-resistant; a headphone jack. To that list I added some things that the moto was not good at or never had: long battery life, being small enough to use one-handed and not be bursting out of my pocket, and a fast, accurate fingerprint reader. I looked at and rejected lots of phones, none of them had everything I wanted. Does the essential phone have everything I wanted? No way, but it's better than the rest for me for the following reasons. Pros ------ * Screen: A large, beautiful, responsive screen in the smallest size. When you pull this phone out of your pocket, hold it in your hand, reach across the screen with one hand, and look at the great screen, you'll probably get what I'm saying. * Speed: Very fast and smooth operation. No stuttering or other slowdowns. Runs the fastest Android processor currently available, same as on the S8 and others costing much more. * Camera launch: Can launch the camera quickly and easily, the same way, regardless of whether it's locked, screen off, or I'm using it. * Speaker: Very loud and clear *Battery: amazing battery life, looks like it will allow for 2-3x the screen on time of the moto x which ranged from 2 to 3 hours. * Bloatware: Android on the Essential is even more pure than that of my moto x pure edition * Fingerprint sensor: this one is very fast and accurate, it's great to have one finally. The one small problem is that it's not recessed very far into the body, so it can be slightly tricky to find sometimes. But it's so fast and accurate that usually getting in the vicinity of the center works for me. * Ambient light sensor: works perfectly, always at a good level for me no matter where I am. * GPS: perfect * Updates: Supported by a small, hungry startup which cares so much about the success of their product that they will push out multiple updates in a month. The larger companies and the carriers don't seem to care that much. Oreo should be coming soon, and unlike with other companies, I believe it. * Security: 3 years promised monthly security updates (My moto x pure went for almost a year without a security update, and I don't think that's unusual). * Storage: Huge amount of storage, 128GB * Price: And, perhaps best of all, the price. I was lucky enough to get this phone at what was probably the lowest price it will ever see, less than half the price of a similarly equipped pixel 2 XL or Galaxy S8 plus. The price has already gone up a bit, I recommend that you get it before it goes higher. OK ----- * Speaker: I was hoping to get front facing speakers like I had in the moto, but those days are over, I think, and it's well worth losing that for the small size. Despite the lack of front facing speakers, the single downward facing speaker on this phone is louder than the moto and seems just as clear. But you can cover it somewhat easily with your hand, as in any other phone with this type of speaker. * Camera: You've probably heard many complaints about the camera.
