Maybe it's just me, but I find this counter-intuitive, and find myself hitting the power volume button instead of the power button, or vice-versa. You should also know that the phone FORCES you to do an update when you first set it up. The update is a almost 900mb big, and takes about 20-30 minutes to download and install. Just a FYI: You'll want to be on good wireless and have some time before you start. On the whole, I find a lot to like about this phone, and some things--like the elegant high quality build and no bezel screen--to love. The Android OS runs very smoothly, apps install and launch fast, and call quality is good. Have they built one phone to rule them all, turn over all the cards, just buy it? No, not in my opinion. It's a good option at the flagship price point, but there are other good options at that price point, and construction and design aside, I am not sure this phone has sufficiently differentiated itself to say you shouldn't carefully consider your options. If Essential ultimately provides timely updates for a longer horizon than their competitors that would be a HUGE incentive to buy into their ecosystem. Heck, if I knew that they'd support Android updates until the hardware simply can't handle them, I'd say that all other caveats aside, this IS the phone to get. (I've got a drawer full of hardware-willing Android phones that were abandoned way too soon by their manufacturers). But that remains to be seen, even if the company us being run by the father of Android itself. ░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░ ░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░ ░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░ ░░░░░░░░░░░░░ UPDATE (10/04/17): ░░░░░░░░░░░░░ OK, so I've owned this phone for about a month. I just received the third major firmware update, and these three updates have fixed some of the earlier bugaboos, particularly with respect to general functioning of apps. They have also improved the camera (though it's still a work in progress, it's generally good enough). The design choices that I hated up front I still find terribly annoying: No headphone jack; USB-C; no wireless charging built in. I have tons of wired headphone/micro-USB/Qi wireless charging infrastructure around my house and in my car, and this phone takes those away without any real benefit. But even with a just-good-enough camera and with the design choice headaches, in the past month I've come to love certain things about this phone: The form factor; the feel in my hand; the glassy smooth performance; the super fast booting; the lovely edge-to-edge display; and the (surprisingly) consistently excellent battery life. I WANT to love this phone, warts and all. Sadly, I can't. And beyond the more modest annoyances noted above, the fundamental reason is this: Unreliable cellular data service. I'm on Verizon, and this phone was properly provisioned on Verizon shortly after it was released. But the phone has a horrible tendency to lose its data connection. I'll have a four bar solid data connection. Then I'll enter a location with a recognized WiFi connection. The phone will switch to WiFi, but when I leave the WiFi area it doesn't properly return to cellular data. Sometimes it will even show a good strength data connection, but won't be able to connect to it. The only way to fix this is to reboot the phone. (Sometimes taking the phone into and out of airplane mode will also fix things, but sometimes it won't). The phone also has a tendency to get stuck on dirt-slow 3G even when there's a LTE connection available, and again the only way to force it to properly connect is to reboot the phone. As of the time of this update, this phone has the WORST ability to find and hold a solid data connection of any phone I have used on Verizon since the advent of LTE. I've tried to switch to this phone as my daily driver, but the issues with lost data connection when I'm moving around are so common and so aggravating that ultimately I find myself switching back to other phones whenever I will be in a situation where using my phone is mission critical. I keep hoping a firmware update will fix things, and that's why I waited to write this update until the just released update of today, but it didn't fix anything in this regard and so...well, I really do want to love this phone. But if the phone isn't going to love me back...well, you know...stay tuned...
reviews.review_header: High end phone with terrific build quality worth considering, but hits & misses in the feature set and iffy cellular performance

reviews.review_text: Alright. I have been a part of the whole Apple extended family which seems like forever until Apple released a $1000 iPhone X. That's just too much money. So I bought the Essential Phone after reading about it and frankly for $399 (BF Deal) to get a Smartphone with snap-on camera and128 gb worth of space is a steal. The phone itself comes with: 1. Charger. 2. Dongle to connect earphones. Additional package: 1. Snap-on camera, 360 deg. I was able to download all the build updates/apps/sync my contacts etc in no time. However, porting my ringtones over from iPhone was a huge challenge. Since being a newbie on Andoird platform, I failed to understand why a file management system does not come pre-packaged with Android. However, I was able to get past it by downloading Android File Transfer on my mac and realizing that my ringtones were m4r format so spent some time converting them over to MP3 and boom had my ringtones appear on my Essential phone. Pros: 1. Camera: I like it. Nothing wrong with the native camera. I read so much about people complaining about crashes etc, but I had no issues so far. The quality is great although I have not installed the Google Camera APK and hence cannot compare the native camera functionality vs the Google Camera APK. 2. The Phone: Its super fast, simple to adapt to. Storage is great. I love the design. 3. Battery: This is definitely a selling point. The battery life is super long. Much much much better than any iPhone I have owned in the past 10 years. Cons: 1. No slot for earphones: I don't get the argument that the industry is heading this way hence we ought to accept it. No sorry, I have had issues with Bluetooth connectivity and worst yet, if the battery needs to be charged and you have an important work-related call that can't wait, then your screwed. The Type c - earphone dongle is all cute and sh*t but it just doesn't make up for a lost earphone slot. 2. Essential Phone: Looks like it was built for Android enthusiasts only hence I cannot find any starter kit or anything for non-Android users to hop on and know what to expect. Like how would you back up over wifi vs connected to a computer, just to name a few? Luckily I was able to find the XDA forums, which is a life saver for all issues relating to Essential phone: https://forum.xda-developers.com/essential-phone/help 3. A type c to USB cable: This is hardly a deal breaker since you can get one for $5 on Amazon but you would assume that the package would have a USB - Type c connector but there isn't one. I get that Essential is future proofing but many many existing laptops/macs do not have Type c input. Overall, at the moment I love the product. I have seen many people complain (perhaps their experience was bad) but the price point and the features that you get are great. I will update this comment in 3 weeks and hopefully, I could still associate the word love with this phone. ~Peace

I've come from a OnePlus 3T to the Essential Phone and am dumbfounded! The build is so impressive. I can't put the phone down! This is noticeably smaller than my previous phones, but the screen ratio more than makes me enjoy looking at and holding the phone. It just feels right, both with the physical hardware as well as the software. My usage so far has left me nothing short of impressed. After installing my apps, setting up my accounts, and testing things out I am confident that this phone will still be my daily driver for the next few years. Essential really has stepped up their game from what I have to compare with early reviews of the phone. The camera app works! There is a slight lag after a picture is taken to when it is added to your gallery, assuming this is just the software processing the image which seems like something that can be fixed with more updates. Speaking of updates, I'm still running Android 7.1 and haven't opted to join the 8.0 beta, but I really think this phone will be amazing with the latest version of Android! Anxiously awaiting! One other thing I wanted to note is network coverage; on the T-Mobile network I've never experienced any hiccups as others have reported. Network signal is strong, stronger than my previous 3T, and reliable. Wi-Fi speeds are impressive, staying consistent, which I've had nothing but trouble with other phones in the past. ***EDIT*** The battery life has been unbelievable! 7+ hours of screen on time, it can handle all my streaming needs (music and video!). By noon with my old 3T I would have had to charge my phone but with this wonderful slab I'm sitting pretty at 55-60% with just a few hours left of my day. I'm thrilled with this battery performance!! ***EDIT CONCLUDED*** At the current price point, current developer support, and hardware, there should be no second thoughts. This phone blew my expectations out of the water!
reviews.review_header: A few hours in and loving it!

reviews.review_text: Andy Rubin basically designed a super awesome hardware, slapped the barebone Android OS on it and called it a day. So you have to do a lot of tweaks to make it work, for example - Just by increasing the screen touch sensitivity, I made the phone feel much faster and less stuttery - The vibration strength is also too strong and you need to hunt down the setting and reduce it. - Camera app is absolutely crap, using third party apps make it much better, but still no match for Samsung Galaxy and Pixel. That being said, I loved it, why? - Firstly it just feels special. The hardware is amazing as said, and it's the perfect size and screen is huge for such a small phone. E.g. it has the highest screen to body ratio... beating iPhone X and Galaxy S8/Note 8. - And most importantly, it's not a Samsung or Apple where everyone has one - from the millionaire driving a Ferrari to the homeless guy on the street. - After you make so much effort tweaking it, it makes the phone feel closer to you lol. Also after the latest perf fixes from Essential, stock Android already feels faster and more crisp than my S8+.
reviews.review_header: A "special" phone if you make the effort

reviews.review_text: The reviews were a little daunting at first. But after seeing a promising phone with no bloatware, and specs like this with a $500 pricetag I dug deeper. Most people were complaining about the camera/software which I have to say is now very smooth after the updates. The guy made android, you know he'll squash the bugs! I was upset with the camera, even with the updates I'll be honest. But with the latest releases as of writing (12/28/2017) it is the best pic quality you can get from a 13MP camera that I've witnessed and I'm extremely relieved. This phone is so smooth and for $500 I was relieved to get away from the bloated s6 that was starting to slow down to unbearable speeds. This phone feels so smooth and slick I was inclined to download a few games and I have to say if you like gaming on your mobile then this cant be beat for the price, only matched at best. I am big into encryption and security and I wanted the bloatware gone for less points of attack, and more room for active apps such as VPN. Anyways before the most recent camera polish this phone gets a 4/5. I'm happy to say it's a 5/5 now and if you're on the fence you will not regret it.
reviews.review_header: Camera was still lame for a bit, seems polished now and is GREAT

reviews.review_text: I was hesitant to purchase this phone due to some mixed reviews, most of which dealt with the camera issues, but I am glad I didn't let those stop me. For you average picture taker, which I am, I don't notice a difference between the camera on this phone and any other phone I've tried. The issue is non-existent for me. The display looks great and the phone is incredibly fast and responsive. I'm using Project Fi with this phone and do have an issue with MMS messages, but changing my default texting app to Hangouts resolved the issue for me (and isn't an issue with the phone itself from my understanding). I'm thrilled with the 128GB of storage, and the USB Type-C. I was moving from a Nexus 5x, briefly tried out the Moto E4, and was looking at getting a flagship phone such as a Pixel or Pixel 2, or Samsung Galaxy or Note, but I am glad that I went with the Essential Phone instead.
reviews.review_header: Fast, Smooth performance. Excellent display. No regrets.

reviews.review_text: Firstly, I came to the Essential from the Nexus 6P, which was a good phone, but it's battery couldn't really keep up, and after experiencing too many of the common early shutdowns, Google allowed me to return it for a full refund after over two years of owning it. My choice for a new phone was between the Pixel 2, the Essential, and the OP5T. I chose the Essential, since the Pixel 2 was too expensive for me (even more so in Germany), and OnePlus couldn't win me with their sometimes shady stuff going on and I also didn't like the design as much. Thus I imported the Essential PH-1 to Germany, and I so far I've been very happy with it. I flashed the Oreo beta onto it, and the performance is generally pretty good, I couldn't reproduce most of the common issues with this phone. I had a lot of random reboots on beta 1 (and also some on beta 2), but those were caused by me rooting the device. A recent Magisk (root) update fixed all issues for me. I only experienced the touch lag/freeze up twice so far on beta 1, but each time a simple reboot fixed them. I'm going to talk about the rest of the phone in a small list: PROS: - Build quality and design: The titanium frame and the glossy ceramic back looks absolutely stunning. The phone also has a relatively high heft to it, which you either like or don't, I think it makes the phone feel really premium. - The screen: Yes, it's only a LCD, but it's great with perfect sharpness, great colors and good viewing angles. I think I actually prefer it over the AMOLED of my previous 6P. The form factor of the screen with the camera cutout it unique and looks nice in my opinion, and the cutout itself bothers a lot less than you might imagine. - Software: It's a completely stock Android, the dream of every pure Android software enthusiast. - Updates and support: Essential proved recently that they stand behind their product. Even though it had a rough start and a lot of software issues at the beginning, they showed their dedication through continuous software and camera updates, bi-weekly AMAs on Reddit, and a general openness to the community. NEUTRAL: - No headphone jack: not an issue for me, but might be for some? CONS: - Camera. Yep, I had to say it. No, it's not as bad as some reviews make it seem, as it got a lot of updates, but sadly it's not that great either, even if you use the Google Camera port from e.g. B-S-G. The colors just don't feel right, the HDR on my previous 6P was a lot more stunning, and especially in dark lighting there's a lot of noise. Doesn't mean that you can't get really good pictures though from time to time. Definitely note I'm coming from the Nexus 6P, which had an outstanding camera, so my perception might be flawed. I hope my rather lengthy review could help you in your decision.. so, all in all, even with the small issues I had, I can wholeheartedly give the PH-1 5 stars. Another PSA on replacement parts availability: Currently, Essential doesn't sell any replacement parts for it's phone, so GET A CASE! The phone is rather slippery on the back, and tends to slide off flat, slightly angled surfaces (like a tiling ledge in the bath room..). I heard though that Essential is pretty nice on replacing the whole phone if you pay a small sum.
reviews.review_header: Great phone with small issues but great support

reviews.review_text: For the price (especially after the price drop and Black Friday sale) this is such an amazing phone. The software is a little buggy and the native camera app, while continually improving, is mediocre, but the form factor and the feel of the phone are the best. I did have to return my first phone because I had Bluetooth problems (lost connection to smartwatch and Fitbit, reset all pairings, would randomly turn off) and even my second one has the Bluetooth randomly turn off, but I am in love with the physical feel of this phone. I previously had a Nexus 6p which ran great but the battery started wearing out. To hold them side by side, the screen on the PH1 is the same or bigger but the overall size is so much smaller than the 6p. For a female, this works so much better for me since the 6p didn't fit well in my pants pockets. Everyone I've shown the phone to, including my Apple-loving friends said how great the PH1 looked and felt. There's just something about the weight of it that it feels so great in your hand. They include a great charger and USB-C to headphone cable. The battery life on this seems to hold so much better than my 6p did and it charges super fast on the included charger. Despite my intermittent Bluetooth problems (which I hope get resolved with software updates) I am very satisfied with the phone. For half the cost, it has the same processor, RAM, and more standard storage (128 GB) than comparable Android flagship phones. The native camera app is the big drawback but besides the regular updates that have been improving the camera, it's easy to find instructions to load the Google camera app.
reviews.review_header: Not perfect, but top notch specs for a great price for unlocked phone

reviews.review_text: I have used the phone for almost a week now and have almost no complaints, although there are a few things I'm still getting used to, like the location of the power button.the phone is beautiful (I got it in white), but very slippery, so you will need a skin or case, unfortunately. I switched from a Nexus 5x and the transfer was super fast and easy. The o ly bad part is having to log back into your apps when you open them for the first time. The screen is huge but the phone is not, which is a super feature for me with smallish hands. The portrait mode has given me some beautiful photos of my daughter. My Nexus was running out of storage, so having massive storage feels really luxurious. The software problems that people had at the beginning are non-existent for me. The phone updated to Oreo on first update and has run perfectly. I'll update if I have problems. For now, 100% recommend!

I had been looking to move away from the Apple walled garden for some time and kept looking at what were quality alternatives to yet another new iPhone - I had looked at all the usual suspects and just felt that there was no reason to take the plunge. That is, until I came across the Essential PH-1, a genuinely premium phone made from ultra-premium materials that feels as if it will easily last 2 - 3 years. It is very fast due to the lack of any bloatware, the fingerprint reader is superb with no false positive or false negative occurrences and instant when you actually touch it properly to open your phone. I had been wanting to purchase the Stellar Gray version and as I am also in the UK, there was no official way to purchase this (or the other colourways) until this, the Halo Gray Amazon exclusive, appeared on my amazon.com account (not my amazon.co.uk account!). This is still not a UK supported phone as the charger is a US two prong affair but the charger supports 110-240V and an adaptor plug works fine to bridge-the-gap so that it can be charged. This leads me neatly into the battery life - I'm not a heavy user but it is giving me 3 full days between charges. For example, I went to bed the other night with 49% and woke up 7.5 hours later with 46%! I am now resorting to letting it discharge to about 15-20% then charging it for about an hour which brings it back to ~80%. I am truly impressed with the battery life and also the 'rapid charge' capability of the supplied charger brick! Much of the negative press over this phone has been due to its camera which, as at Oreo 8.1, is now more than just acceptable, it is actually quite good. I particularly like the 'Mono' mode for true black & white photo's which are beautifully sharp and atmospheric and which no other phone offers, to my knowledge. Also, if you want all the bells & whistles, just get the Google Camera App, although this is not quite as straightforward as you would want - visit xda-developers.com. To sum up, I am blown away with the premium feel of this phone, from the feel in the hand, through the superfast performance and specs, to the company ethos - your phone, no logos, no bloat/crippleware. I love this colourway, size and screen/size ratio and at $499 (£450 inc. import duties!) I believe that it represents phenomenal value compared to any other phone. (It blows away my wife's iPhone X which she hates despite 8 years of Apple products - she has even bought a Samsung Galaxy S9 plus to replace it!) The only negative has to be those people who are shipped a dud. I am sure that they exist and perhaps in numbers that are above average. But if you are buying via Amazon, just return it and I feel sure that your replacement will be every bit as good as mine is.... which is Absobloodylutely fantastic!
reviews.review_header: Much, much better than the online reviews imply!

reviews.review_text: I seriously don't understand why this phone has such biased reviews online. I love my essential phone. It's slick, smooth, fast, pure Android experience. Absolutely 0 bloatware. Camera takes great pics. Yes there has been many updates but that's the best part. I didn't pay the price of a new S8 or X and I got great performance. I cannot complain. I love this phone. It's a highly underrated flagship phone. Update: After a few weeks of use, battery performance is amazing. Lasts more than a full day. Updated to Oreo 8.1 beta and I can't say it's a beta. No crash reboots.. performance is amazing. I love this phone!
reviews.review_header: This is the best most underrated smart phone of 2017

reviews.review_text: I've had this phone for a few days and with the updates and the price drop I got it at 450 this was a steal I had the pixel 2 xl I sent it back after the plague of issues with 2 RMAs best choice I've made the speaker on this is loud as hell for a bottom firing single speaker the LCD screen is honestly very nice looks better than the pixel 2 xl the design is very sleek I've gotten complements and people asking what phone it is. The camera is ok I definitely won't give it any awards but it definitely isn't terrible with more updates it can be even better it looks like he software of the camera holds it back. The battery so far has been great for a 3040 it lasts me the whole day but I am an average user. This design is honestly amazing and it feels great 10/10 the weight feels great and it's easy to handle and I have baby hands. I'm excited to see what they do with the second generation.
reviews.review_header: This is a steal at this price!

reviews.review_text: Great bloat-ware free OS. Stunning beauty! Work of art! Absolutely LOVE everything about this phone except for one major issue: The screen is very fragile! A phone should be able to withstand a "gentle" drop from under 2' without the screen cracking. I was on one knee bending over to look under my truck bumper and it slid out of my shirt pocket onto the pavement. This is my second PH-1. I loved the first one so much I bought another after sending it in on an insurance claim for a cracked screen! Thank goodness for insurance! I am not rough on phones, but I'm also not a big fan of hiding my phone inside a case either. I had Skinomi screen protectors on both, but it's the very edge of the glass at the corners that is delicate. I know I take my chances without a case but only sometimes. I only take off the case when I want to show it off. My last 2 phones were the Motorolas with shatterproof screens and they worked as advertised. Why aren't all screens shatterproof since the technology exists? Not only is the screen fragile, it is irreplaceable! Try a search on Amazon or eBay or the entire internet for a replacement screen and you will not find one anywhere. Contacted Essential and they informed that IT CAN NOT BE REPAIRED! Yes, you heard that right. Why hasn't some Chinese company mass-produced a knock-off replacement screen yet? I could be rich! Buy this phone if you don't care about the screen. It is an awesome phone otherwise. I just can't give it anything more than 4 stars. I wanted to give it 3, but decided one star for one flaw, however major, was fair.
reviews.review_header: GREAT PHONE WITH FRAGILE EXTINCT SCREEN

reviews.review_text: Perfect form factor (easy to hold) and top build quality (alas, skin and screen protector are still advisable, I know firsthand: scratches…). What really matters to me (other than the obvious price / performance / enough storage / connectivity): 1) Secure, clean, fast and up-to-date OS with timely security updates and firmware updates as needed. My previous phone (Honor 5X) was running Lineage OS. Essential OS meets my criteria but Lineage OS (with Pixel Launcher) is somewhat more rounded. Project treble (Oreo) looks promising, keep it up. 2) Easy to read display (approaching 50). Due to the high pixel density, some website font doesn’t scale well (bad implementation on their part, a lower resolution screen would actually work better in this scenario). Proper font scaling across the border is a big deal as presbyopia ensue. To be clear: essential phone screen is high quality and the max (ideal) size I’m willing to fit in my pocket. 3) A decent camera. Essential phone camera should be better for the price. My father Lumia 950XL (October 2015) is much better. HINT: Ideally Essential would release a quality camera accessory (28 -70 optical zoom) for $50. My 5 stars rating is based on the expectation of long term software updates and the hope that a quality camera accessory is on the way.
reviews.review_header: My 5 stars rating is based on the expectation...

reviews.review_text: After doing careful review of the PH-1 and taking considerable thought, I bought this phone. The reviews and images of it are often not being very just. The screen is gorgeous. It is apparently LCD and has a more warm feeling than OLED in my view. Text is crisp and being stock Android, it is able to easily be customized. As it is unlocked, it allows one to hotspot tether other devices as well. With the processor it has, it is very snappy. Games and videos load nearly instantly. Ingress is a game I play and is historically a slower to load game. I have never seen it load so fast. The makers website has basic instruction on transferring data, apps, contacts from your old phone to this one. As I am an android user, I had backed up my old phone to Google Drive and reloaded to this one. The only thing that did not transfer was my texts, but that may be my own issue. For iPhone users going to this phone, there are instructions to do that as well. essential.com/userguides I am one who has used Nokia, Blackberry, Motorola, and Samsung in the past and years ago found Android to be very good phone OS. My last phone before this was a Samsung Note 5. It too was unlocked, but had Samsung bloatware. This is a purist Android phone and needs to be seen on its own merits. It is elegant and simple and seeing nearly zero bezel is fantastic. I realize early reviews pointed out a few downsides and maybe they existed, but I see none now, at least in how I use a cell phone. In the very well boxed shipment, I received a somewhat short charge cord Type C on both sides. It has a charge block and a 3.5 adapter for headphones. One thing anyone should know is the optional accessories like the 360 camera and the prior mentioned 3.5 jack connect to the back of the phone by magnet. They just snap on. Pretty cool. Probably not the thing most would note as a thing to do, I took the phone this morning and stuck it to the refrigerator playing a video as I made coffee. To me an unexpected bonus. The magnet was strong enough to hold the phone to the door of the refrigerator but not be on there as if it were glued. My car has a metal mid console between the front seats and I was seeking a way to easily have my phone stay there. Voila.
reviews.review_header: Unconventional review of my PH-1 first impressions. First day.

reviews.review_text: I had the Nexus 6P beforehand and the Samsung S6 before that. I now have same size screen as the 6P on a much smaller device. Its a very well built and good looking phone. The other complaints I've read about this phone are imo insignificant. Only minor complaints I would have are 1) I would give the battery 4 stars, I use it heavily and battery only just lasts the day; 2) the camera is also probably 4 stars but appears to be just software related not hardware so I am confident this will improve with updates. This phone I think is comparable to the iphoneX at $1000 and Samsung S8 at $900 (both of which I have tried) so it is a bargain at $500. The 360 degree camera accessory is fantastic. I can watch 360 videos on the phone or upload to Momento360 to watch on VR goggles. I will almost definitely look to buy other accessories when they come out.
reviews.review_header: Awesome phone at a fantastic price

reviews.review_text: I'd been looking into this phone for a while, but was hesitant to pull the trigger at the original $699.00 price. When the price dropped to $499, plus getting the phone and 360 camera as a bundle deal for $499.00 I couldn't resist any longer. The phone is working very well. The build is top notch and the edge-to-edge screen is fantastic. I love stock Android and the company has been very responsive in releasing updates and addressing customers on Reddit with weekly "AMA". Can't wait to see what Essential comes up with next!
reviews.review_header: Fantastic Premium Phone at an Incredible Price!

reviews.review_text: Update - after 3 weeks of everyday use: The phone is performing flawlessly both before and after an update to Android 8.0.0 (Oreo beta 2). Yes I had to side load it, but that was a smooth and relatively quick process (about 15minutes), I'm sure Essential will be pushing the OTA soon. Reception is on par with other phones including iPhone which I carry for work along with my Essential phone. Battery life is good at approximately 28 hours of moderate mixed use (some streaming but no gaming). All features and apps have performed flawlessly since day one. Original review: The ONLY downside I've found is... This phone is very "slippery" and without a protective snap-case/shell the screen will crack if dropped! I cracked mine on the first day because I was too impatient to wait for the case to arrive. I ordered it the same day but the phone arrived first. I contacted Essential and they sent a replacement although it did cost me ( can't complain though...it was my mistake that caused the damage) For that reason I recommend buying insurance. Now for the good stuff... Updates are arriving like clock-work, It's still on android 7 although there is a beta of 8 available for the adventurous user. Best of all it is pure android...no bloat-ware istalled.... In my everyday use so far...this phone has been flawless. The battery life is great, but let me qualify that by saying I don't spend a lot of time watching video or playing games. The 360 degree camera is amazing even if you're only going to use it for speacial occasions. Scrolling is smooth as silk, touches are consistent even with the screen protector. The fingerprint reader hasn't given any problem and reads the finger instantly.

My favorite phone in 10 years of smartphones. Basic, clean and elegant as Android gets. Perfect form factor and not as heavy as one would think, given the materials. Might be a little big for some hands, but have had no issues with grasping or holding with one hand. Wish there were more third-party cases available, just to change up the look if nothing else. But the ceramic and titanium creates such a winning look, and the phone is so durable, I don't mind the lack of options in this area. Have banged the phone twice and no scratch or mark was left. None of the early issues with the camera people were reporting online. Photos have looked pretty good. A. Rubin and company really outdid themselves with this one. They obviously know the advantages of this platform and it shows. Unlike the bloat of the unnecessary "AI" features built into the Pixel line, this is streamlined perfection. Hopefully, the lack of mainstream interest and recent controversy with A. Rubin won't derail development on this line because they've really gone in the right direction on this one.
reviews.review_header: Probably the best Android phone ever and my personal favorite smartphone

reviews.review_text: I never had the freezing problem that others had. Neither did my friend that I bought one for. So far (I have had it for about 6-7 months), the phone worked perfectly fine. The camera takes pictures just fine. Can it be better? Yes! I put it right to the Samsung that was the latest in the store at the same time and the Samsung clearly did better...BUT...still the pictures are very good. I was actually asked a couple of times what did I use to take the pictures. To be honest, this is a phone, not a camera, so I do not expect perfection - I have a Cannon for that. It took a little bit if getting used to some of the features, but I honestly have no complaint. maybe I could mention that towards the edge the screen is not responding very well to the touch. However, my friend, who has very bulky fingers, says he does not experience that problem (he has the black one, I have the white one). I have already dropped it a few times and I only noticed a small scratch on the back of the phone, and I only have one of those "stickers" on the back since it seems impossible to find a case that is sleek and safe at the same time. I waited for 4 years for something different to come to the market - thank you, Essential!
reviews.review_header: the phone worked perfectly fine. The camera takes pictures just fine

reviews.review_text: The pros of this phone are many and far outweigh the very very few negatives. I will quickly list some of the main positives vs the small negatives. Pros: price, build quality (ceramic and titanium), speed, size, front camera, button placement and feel, display quality/resolution, OS (stock android), and usability. (These are not all of the positives just some important ones) Cons: The only real cons with this device are that there is no headphone jack, waterproofing, and the dual lens camera is not the best. (Perhaps these 3 things just weren't essential when they designed the phone?) The only other thing keeping this review from being 5 stars is that there are virtually no screen protectors or cases for this phone. What are available are essentially all the same, and for someone like me who is used to otterbox cases it is rather frustrating. Other then those small cons this phone is absolutely excellent. Very fast, very sleak, and for this price point it is essentially unmatched. I highly recommend it.
reviews.review_header: Great phone with only a couple small drawbacks. Highly recommended purchase.

reviews.review_text: There are many things I like so I will list them below. 1. Battery last for a whole day at least 12 hours playing non stop games or taking pictures and video. It should last 24 hours if you don't use it non stop. It also has a graph to show you how fast the battery drain and how soon will you be out of juice. 2. The speed, it is fast response, no slowing down. 3. It has everything inside including memory so it is a good value. 4. the screen is super big compare with the size of the phone 5. super fun with the 360 degree camera 6. Super fast recharge. Usually takes less than 1 hour. Maybe 1/2 hours if it is not fully depleted to recharge. Here comes the bad 1. Camera is about average. It takes worst picture than my S7 Galaxy 2. It is not water proof (This part is not as bad as the camera for me) 3. Having trouble connect to my computer through USB. (Not yet successful) 4. Using other charger with a USB C cable is extremely slow (Not a big concern to me since the battery last a whole day) 5. It is a little thicker than I expected but it feels like a solid build so it can take on scratch and dropping. 6. The phone locks up on me during my first week for a few times. Since then, it has stabilized. I just don't know how to reset the phone until I did some research. (If this happen to you, press the vol up button and the power button together and wait for 5 sec)
reviews.review_header: Make sure that you know what you like about the phone before buying it.

reviews.review_text: This phone is the best Android phone deal around. The recent camera updates seems to have solved most of the initial issues the camera had. From what I can tell it takes great pictures now. The hardware is second to none and very high quality. The software is practically stock Android. Very impressed with the build and no bloat software implementation. I was little nervous purchasing this based on the initial so-so reviews (mainly due to the camera), but I'm very happy with this phone after using it for a few days. It's an excellent deal at this discounted price point. Update 12/14/17: This phone received another camera update yesterday. I believe that's 4 or 5 camera updates since I've owned this phone since late November. The company is committed to fixing whatever camera problem the phone had. Takes great pictures. At this price point and with all the updates, this phone deserves another look by all the initial reviewers of this phone. The software has been stable for me. It's a great phone. Getting 128GB for $499 is a great deal compared to the competition.

Here's my 12-hour review as of 4-21-18. I'll update in a few weeks. I recommend this phone without reservation to anyone looking for an unlocked, affordable, high quality smartphone. At $400, you get more than you pay for with the Essential. This is an awesome phone! I jumped ship after using iPhones for the past 8 years. I have a MacBook and iPad Pro and now this. I'm an early adopter and did not find the switch to Android at all challenging. Make sure to turn off your iMessages before setting up your Android. I'm missing some of my texts but they are on my computer. The awesome: This phone is so much faster and more responsive than my iPhone 7. Using Chromecast with Android means you can cast nearly anything including Prime music, etc. This isn't possible from Apple. So it now feels like I'm getting my money worth from Prime membership, Spotify and more. The phone quickly updated to Oreo 8.1. The battery is amazing and charges so fast. There is a lot of snarking about the camera. I'm not a photographer but appreciate quality design. The camera feels responsive and snappy. The photos are much better than my iPhone 7. Maybe not iPhoneX or Pixel 2 camera but really great for my needs. The phone design is really cool. My iPhone 7 had rounded edges and was slippery. The Essential fits well in my hand with the square design. The fingerprint unlock works all the time. I have average hands and this phone does not feel like a phablet. Just the right size. The LCD screen has gotten some flack but it's so much better than my iPhone 7 that I have no complaints. The screen has an auto brightness function that is really nice on my eyes. Areas for Improvement: The speaker is ok. Could be better but I usually use headphones or a speaker. There are some reports of screen lag and this is true for me. It's not terrible but occasionally slower than the pace I'm going. I got the Halo Grey to avoid the fingerprint issue. To do over I'd get the white. Within 24 hours the back of my phone is stained from the oil on my hand. (I don't have sweaty or greasy hands). This makes the phone look a little ... gross. The SIM card slot hole is next to the mic hole. That was a bad design choice. Just make sure you put the SIM key in the right hole.

This phone is amazing. It's like a sports car--sleek, fast, streamlined, and fun to "drive." It feels sturdy--much more so than my old Samsung and the fragile iPhone--and it fits conveniently in one hand for easy maneuvering. An uncluttered phone has to be experienced; once you've enjoyed a device without the garbage, you can't go back. The screen is responsive, and the use of space on the screen is efficient. It allows users to set up different accounts with different apps on the screens, so you can keep business separate from personal accpunts, etc. Switching between them takes getting used to, but it's simple. In hope Essential keeps coming out with these lean, gorgeous technological works of art.

Essential Phone at $399 is a great deal! Bought 2 since wife and I are updating from Moto X Pure's and we're both happy! Wireless Carrier we use is Cricket. Reception is great, same reception quality as our previous phones which never had any problems. Had NO problem taking micro sim cards out and switch to new phones. Google transferred EVERYTHING over to our new phones from old phones, and we even were able to update to Oreo 8.1, all within 10 minutes! Phone is very quick, screen is bright, no rolling lag and camera works fine! Love the edge to edge screen and wife even felt the Essential screens were even clearer then previous. The display is approx the same size as our previous phones but the overall phone dimensions are smaller, making it better for handling. We have more memory left over in the Essential Phone (128 Gig) and without a Micro SD card, the phone appears faster than our Moto's with 64 Gig Micro SD cards. Instead of paying almost $1000 for the latest phone with a Snapdragon 845, I get 2 phones that "I feel" is just as fast for the same price of 1 with Snapdragon 835 on the Essential Phone, which we consider very fast! I read ALL the reviews but so far, we have been pleasantly surprised and incurred none of the problems others may speak of! If things change, I'll do an update.

After a bumpy start with buggy software essential have consistently improved particularly in regards to the camera. As I read some of the other reviews on this site it really seems that these people are not reviewing the phone in the context of the price. If you compare it to other phones in the same price range it is generally a very long way in front. Sure it may not be a premier phone if you compare to other manufacturers but I think it misses the point. Essential phone is just the essential features don't really well with brilliant manufacturing quality that makes Samsung feel cheap by comparison.
reviews.review_header: Essential phone is just the essential features don't really well with brilliant manufacturing quality that makes Samsung feel cheap by comparison

reviews.review_text: Update 1 month of use: Ok, so I've lowered my rating from 5 stars to 3 because out of nowhere my phone started to shutdown and reboot on its own, but would be stuck in a boot loop. I found holding the down volume and power buttons took me to the boot loader screen which allowed me to attempt a reboot, shutdown, or reset. I tried rebooting and resetting and neither worked, it would keep boot looping. Finally I shutdown and just as I ordered my return slip about an hour later I tried powering back on and it worked again. Within 10 minutes of being on though it started to do it again. I basically spent a solid weekend having to shutdown, wait, and power on just to get texts. It's very disappointing, I really liked this phone, there's really nothing else like it. I found that this has happened to several people on forums and I sent an email to Essential who basically told me to do what I did above, but it still would randomly shutdown and boot loop. I guess I'll go try the OnePlus. I've been looking for a replacement for my iPhone 6s. I've previously owned several different phones including a Blackberry Priv, iPhone SE, LG G4, LG G3, LG G2, Galaxy S6, several Blu models, Motorolas, etc.. Compared to all of those, this phone is a step above in nearly all aspects. If you're looking at this phone you've probably already looked up some specs so I won't bore you with those, bottom line, it has nearly the highest specs of high end phones in CPU, memory, etc.. Physically, this phone is smooth. It has a glassy feel all around, it is heavy and sturdy, though it seems like a drop would crack the front and back, I don't know that that's true though. The company's site has a demonstration showing how sturdy the phone is, especially against scuffs (titanium), not sure about cracks. It looks very modern and simple. The finish is prone to fingerprints and smudging, especially the back, but honestly, who cares. Performance is very good. The phone is snappy, no hang ups, which is why I left Android for a bit after having the Blackberry Priv. Its wireless performance is some of the fastest I've seen, when I download an app it takes a mere second or two to download 50mb, which none of my phones were ever able to do. So far the only gripes I have with the phone is the finger print reader's lack of accuracy, sometimes it won't read my fingerprint correctly after several tries. It happens rarely, but it's still annoying. The other gripe is the lack of cases. I've only seen a few on Amazon and no mention of accessories like that on the Essential website. If you're looking for a high end phone for under $500, this is about as good as it gets. I'm very happy with the phone, it is performing better than expected.
reviews.review_header: High quality phone without the crazy $900+ price, but something's wrong...

reviews.review_text: I Don't know were to begin on a review of this phone i have been using it now for 3 months, and it is a fantastic phone, couple of small complaints but to be expected. Still makes a 5 Star phone. So lets start with the obvious this is not a big box company phone, Samsung, LG, or Motorola. This phone is from a Small company Essential, a startup company who has released there very first phone, if you have not done any research on the company i would strongly recommend poking around there site and doing some research before buying this product. The short of it is this phone with plagued with issues after first release, making the original price tag on this phone almost unbearable due to the issues. But now, they have fixed most the issues are still developing and making the camera better with every update, they even had February, security patch updated to phone before the Google Pixel, released there update talk about quick. Down side to this phone as of Feb 18' They still having issues with T-mobile LTE apparently, from what i hear i have used it on both Verizon and ATT, Verizon they couldn't validate my IMEI, so i could only use it on the LTE network, however this is a hit or miss apparently, my father was able to activate his in store and works flawlessly. The camera is still arguably sub par, in low light still but they are still actively developing and trying to improve it. Upsides to this phone, it is just as powerful as a $1000 dollar phone at half the cost. Has all the features you really need or are Essential. 128gb Storage standard is fantastic and i don't think achievable in a new 500 dollar phone otherwise. The phone its self is just a beautiful phone from the edge to edge display to the ceramic back plate it is made with premium materials and it shows, I have gotten numerous compliments on just the way the phone looks. Software is quick and snappy, and plain. No carrier applications on this phone so its only the applications i want on this phone. So yes at this price it is a no brainier, i would buy it again. just keep in mind this is Essentials first phone and it may not be as smooth as a pixel but it is half the cost and still works well.

I love this phone! I was in search of a phone not made by some random Chinese company that bought the name of some well known cell company, (Nokia, Blackberry) or just started there own name (One Plus, and many many more...) Frankly I wanted the iPhone of Android phones, without paying iPhone prices, or having to deal with IOS, all I really wanted was the build quality Apple use to have. Now having said that I have only had this phone for a week, so I have no idea if it really that great, and if I will get more then the typical 18 months out of it before it starts to act up and need replacement, however my first impression is strong and I really think it will. Essential was started by the co-founder of Android, and while it had some road bumps at first launch, I have had zero issues buying this phone in mid December, it has been very stable. Essential promises to keep this phone up to date with security patches for 3 years, and up to date with Android OS for 2 years. Currently I have the security patch for December '17, which it downloaded immediately when I turned on the phone, and I know Android 8.0 is coming very soon. I use to buy the Nexus phones for years, and really only for the up to date security and OS, but with the Essential phone I firmly believe that may be a thing of the past. I am hoping I will not have to buy a $700+ phone just to stay up to date. And one last thing I will touch in on, I had a Nexus 5X for a long time, liked it overall (Horrible battery life) but the one thing I did like was the form factor of a 5" phone. I help the essential next to the 5X and they are near the exact same size, even though the essential has a 5.7" screen size. The battery life is good overall, it has up to date high end specs, a beautiful screen, amazing build quality, you just cannot go wrong for under $500. Things I would change -I want a headphone port -Even though it has 128GB of storage (Amazing!) expandable storage wouldn't hurt. -Eliminate the bottom lip -Removable battery -Some OEM cases/screen protectors would be nice along with more 3rd party cases/screen protectors
reviews.review_header: Coming from a Nexus/Pixel user, BUY IT!

reviews.review_text: The phone is solid in term of design, materials & quality: Impression: heavy, solid, a bit thicker than the most of the flagship phones out there with minimal bezel. If you have not got a chance play with the phone and you have an iPhone 4 in the past then here is the feeling: an iPhone 4 at the little bigger but the screen size ABOUT of iphone 7+. The phone is very responsive to my use. I am coming from user of iPhone since the first generation in 2007 until iPhone 8 & will be the X and the Samsung S8+.
reviews.review_header: The phone is solid in term of design, materials ...

reviews.review_text: With the Oreo beta the device has matured a ton over the past year. Will probably get even better. Great phone for someone who wants a device they can Fastboot and tinker with, not so much for consumers wanting an appliance to just use. Only caveat...my local Sprint store were idiots and refused to activate it...had to go to Sprint online, and it took 5 days for them to finally whitelist the IMEI number. Note this is a carrier problem due to how Sprint manages its network...not a device problem (which my fool local carrier store tried to tell me).
reviews.review_header: Great device for the tinkering enthusiast

reviews.review_text: Thought about this due to the mixed reviews but decided to take the plunge. When I opened the box and took it out I knew I had made the right decision. The fit in my hand and the feel of the case are excellent. I installed my SIM and after charging it up felt I was ready to go. I have had several phones so I am no stranger to the technology. When I started it I knew this was better than any phone I had been using in the past. The difference between driving an economy car and a top of the line luxury sedan. The screen is just the right size and is extremely clear and easy to read The Bluetooth connection is quick. The camera is fast and easy to use. I saw people complaining about the camera but it works well for the occasional use I have. If I am taking photos on a trip I use my Nikon. I don't know how they can improve on this phone other than have wireless charging. Would buy it again and have already recommended it to my friends.

I really really really, wanted to love it. I love the looks, people were amazed with the screen. I was amazed with the screen, but if you're a t-mobile user hard pass. LTE connection is so tempermental, i swear just staring at it wrong will cause it to drop connection with the t-mobile network, on WiFi it's great. I was running the 8.1 beta, which I heard is much better at connecting to the t-mobile network than 7.x. So sad, I really liked the look of the phone but I'm sending it back. Oh also the camera is still meh at best, esp compared to my pixel 2's cam. Though the B&W camera is cool.
reviews.review_header: I wanted to love it, but maybe wait for version 2 if you're a t-mobile user.

reviews.review_text: A little back story: my last phone was a Nexus 6 which I loved dearly. The Essential Phone, from a software perspective, fills the gap left in my heart by my beloved Shamu perfectly. I was able to port Google's (superior) camera app and Android 8.1 days after purchase. As far as looks go, it is a sharper looking phone than the glorious whale that was the Nexus 6. I think it looks better than the newest itouch or its brand newest Korean competitor. Even though this phone appears to be a slippery bar of soap, I actually haven't dropped it yet, a testament to how easy it is to hold onto. Ye ol' Nexus had bit the dust a dozen times by now. The screen. This thing is by far the easiest phone to see and use in direct sunlight. The tiny, tiny bezels are a revelation. It's sharp, the colors are true, and you can still see it in landscape mode if you wear polarized sunglasses. On to the elephant in the room, and no, I don't mean the Nexus 6 (God, what a phone that was), I mean the camera. Everyone needs to settle down about this. It works great. You'd think that people's lives depend on this camera going toe to toe with the world's highest priced DSLR, but let me assure you, no one's lives are at stake. The camera is fine. Perfect in fact. And you don't have an ugly camera bump! The stock "essential" camera app is a bit garbage, but that's easily remedied with a quick search of the inter-webs. Seriously now, at this price, you can't go wrong. It's nearly half as expensive as the newest phone by the Apple or the Samsung or even the Google (dirty traitors for killing the Nexus family) and I'll guarantee it's more bang for your buck. I'm now a loyal Essential customer. Have I mentioned how much I miss my Nexus 6?
reviews.review_header: This phone is a steal at this price

reviews.review_text: I've had this device for several months now and have been impressed. Essential has been incredibly fast to deliver monthly security updates for it, and this level of support is important to me. The stock Android Nougat OS operates with fluidity and the camera app continues to improve with every update. The first thing you'll be tempted to do upon opening your Essential Phone is to show it off without hiding it's premium appearance under a protective case. DON'T do this. No device is indestructable and the Essential is certainly not an exception. The vast majority of negative reviews for this product were rage-posted immediately after a clumsy drop onto a hard surface caused an uncased, unprotected device's screen to crack (as screens do). Grab one of several cases here on Amazon and protect your investment; this phone should provide years of service with just a minimum of care. However, I don't recommend this device if you are incredibly accident-prone or frequently clumsy, and insist on using it without some form of damage protection. For the rest of us, this device delivers outstanding value and a refreshing break from the mundane, overbranded crop from the usual smartphone manufacturers.
reviews.review_header: Ignore revenge reviews by the clumsy. It's a wonderful device.

reviews.review_text: I have had this phone for 3 days now and it has been great. The build is the best I have ever had on a phone and I have had a lot of phones. In general I swap phones every 10 months to a year. So I have had quite a few of them. I have seen many other video reviews and articles saying that the camera is bad on this phone. I think what people mean to say is the default camera app is bad. It is laggy but one update has been released since I have had the phone and it did improve it some. If you use the stock google camera app or probably any other camera app the pictures are great. I used my google pixel as a basis for comparison and I cant tell the which is which. Aside from the camera app everything else is great and it reminds me of the Nexus line of phones. In short, I love it.
reviews.review_header: ... phone for 3 days now and it has been great. The build is the best I have ever ...

reviews.review_text: This is the best phone I have ever had the opportunity to own. Amazing screen, the OS is CLEAN to an extreme, very very responsive, I have installed the official Oreo beta and its very stable. I moved from my Moto Z2 to the Essential, the screen is a bit bigger but the phone over all is smaller. Amazing. You don't need a $1k phone, the specs are equal or a cut above, the style is modern tech minimalist, and the user experience is almost flawless. You have to hold this phone to applicate it. But, I wish there were more options for screen protectors and cases, the phone feels great in the had but very slippery and v2 needs AMOLED.
reviews.review_header: The future is in my hand...

reviews.review_text: * Update * about a month later. Original review stays consistent. However there are a few quirk's that are problems. For one, periodically the messaging app crashes. I'm not sure if it's on Google's side or Essentials. But it shouldn't happen. The camera, absolutely terrible performance in low light. I missed a few moments just because of focus issues and the phone actually taking the picture. My kids would gather for a picture and I stood there so long trying to take the picture, that my kids thought I actually did. I was in a lit room but the camera just couldn't focus. Another instance is actually in very light situations. With full sun, the exposure is absolutely dark. I will add a picture to help explain. Colors were washed out and basically looking bland. Normal light situations with the camera is definitely acceptable. Infact pretty good with editing. I will add a picture with a editing from Snapseed. One excellent aspect that was impressive was that updates were on time and constant. I believe in a month I received two camera updates and a Oreo 8.1 security update. Well done. I just can't get over the camera. It's very important to me and I need something that clicks excellent photos and video. I'm not changing the 4 star review, I think the essential phone works, it's just not up to par. I plan on keeping it for a backup or for my kids to play games on or awaiting camera updates. I'm going back to iPhone 8 just on the camera and usable aspect. Im not a fanboy of either platforms, I simply want a phone that just works and does what it's supposed to do. Here is my original review. * The essential is enjoyable and frustrating at the same time. First off the premium feel and materials used are top notch. I love using this phone in my hand. It just feels like $. I take the phone case off at home it feels that good. Speaking of cases, there are some out there but nothing to actually enhance the premium feel of the phone itself. As far as screen protector, I haven't found one yet that actually sticks on the entire screen. (the ends are curved slightly). This is not Essentials fault by any means, I'm just saying what support is out there. It has a mono speaker. Sounds just fine(bass is slightly lacking) but this day and age it really should be stereo speakers. Speaker is loud. The screen is very sharp and bright. The camera notch it doesn't bother me one bit. The stock Android is great, it does everything I need it to do. The phone operates smoothly. I'm not really a gamer, just light games so I can't comment on graphical performance. Bluetooth works just fine, if I was to say the distance from say Bluetooth speaker is fairly a short distance before it starts to garble out of range. Calls sound clear and loud. Now the camera- I actually purchased the ph-1 when it was first released. I sold it the next day. The camera was absolutely terrible. However I really like phones that are different so I figured give it another shot with the price drop. I heard there were many camera updates so here we are. Camera is MUCH better in performance. Still not the greatest but definitely usable. It Excells in landscape photos. Sports terrible due to moving subjects, and night shots are iffy at best. However I like to support smaller companies and I'm hoping Andy Rubin will support us in return. Battery life is decent, definitely better than my iPhone 8 as far as lasting longer. I have only owned this phone for a couple days, but I will update my review if anything changes. One more thought, the ph-1 really "could" be one of the best phones made today, just needs some TLC and more updates. Looking forward to the next iteration. The halo grey by the way has a nice matte finish on the back. Much better than the glossy finish for fingerprints and smudges. The lack of Headphone jack really doesn't bother me at all. Can get Bluetooth earphones or use the included adapter. As long as this phone doesn't break or hardware failure. It will be my main phone to use.
reviews.review_header: Great phone, can be better with time. (I'm hoping)

reviews.review_text: I've been using my Essential phone for one month now. It gets lots of daily use streaming, shopping, calling, and writing this review. I LOVE THIS PHONE. Seriously the best value you can find. This baby is so well built and it looks amazing. My friends freaked when I told them I bought with a 360 camera for only $550. The early reviews mean zilch now. When you get your phone let it do all its updates. Mine just updated to Oreo 8.1 last week and it operates flawlessly. I'm on ATT, so can't vouch for other carriers but I have no reception issues. This phone is fast and pure Android goodness. And the camera? It's great! No issues with delay or color. The folks at Essential have done a great job at addressing the early release issues. I mean, look for yourself at these pics taken with the native camera app. Do you see anything wrong? No! It takes incredible shots. If you are on ATT and shopping for an unlocked phone that is truly great, look no further than the Essential PH 1. Nuff said.
Awesome piece of hardware, great screen and software. Problem was, it would not work for T Mobile, it would grab the signal, but it couldn't hold it.

Prior to my purchase, there were three major complaints I observed while researching this phone. None of these have affected me after a few months of use. 1. "It has a notch in the display." You're looking at the glass half empty. This phone is significantly smaller and lighter than my iPhone 8+ yet it has a much larger display. The notch isn't taking away from the screen, rather the screen space on each side of the notch is additional. If you want a phone with a smaller screen to body ratio, there are plenty of options with large bezels. 2. "No headphone jack." Again, there are always tradeoffs in life. This is a full screen phone. Like the iPhone X, there's just not enough space for a 3.5mm headphone jack. But guess what, Bluetooth tech has gotten very good. So has the battery life of very affordable Bluetooth headphones. The best part? No cords! Adapt. Additionally, it comes with a 3.5mm to usb C adapter for your beloved wired headphones so there's really no argument here. 3. "No sd card slot/expandable storage." This puppy comes with 128gb of onboard storage. Need to store your entire terrabite of photos and mp3s with you at all times? I sincerely get that. Personally, I live in the cloud for photos and music. Many people are unaware that streaming services allow you to move songs, albums, and playlists back and forth to local storage. For this purpose, 128gb seems more than adequate. The Essential Ph-1 is an amazing device that I would recommend to anyone with realistic expectations. If you want more than 128gb of storage and a headphone jack in lieu of a full screen display and nop notch build quality, there are many great options available for significantly more money.

I own 3 of these phones. The first I purchased from Best buy for myself to try it out before I committed to buying them for my family. I had originally started with a oneplus 5t to try out with T-Mobile. The phone was amazing, the coverage was not. My next logical move was the pixel 2 xl on vzw for a stock Android experience. Amazing camera, terrible hardware. It was bulky, washed out screen and just kind of ugly. Keep in mind I was coming off 4 consecutive Galaxy phones. I rolled the dice with the essential phone with a bag of mixed reviews. Pros: Build quality, nothing else like it on the market. Solid, hefty and really just sexy looking. Stock Android and unlocked bootloader. Use it stock, root it, use nougat, oreo, port in Google camera app, really do whatever you want. There is also a lot of support on xda forms for this phone. The screen although not oled, very crisp and blacks are not too washed out for led. I was impressed, especially coming from nothing but AMOLED screens for years. I even have an oled TV. The full face screen is also something you won't find anywhere else. Similar to the iPhone x but with just a small cutout for the front camera lenses and not a giant notch. Battery life is outstanding. 2 full days of use for me with a good mix of apps, streaming and email. Price. Paid 450 for my first one and 434 for the other two. Software updates from essential, I have had 4 build updates since my first purchase in November. 3 camera updates(it's getting almost good now) Cons: Camera needs more tlc. It's very good in good lighting, especially the portrait mode. It rivals the big names outside in daylight, however, the camera app is a bit slow and the pictures can get grainy in low light. Her needs work too. However the dedicated black and white sensor has taken some of the sharpest pictures I have ever seen on a cell phone. Thats really it. I hope essential keeps pushing forward with software support and building version 2. I will keep supporting this company as long as they listen to the consumer and continue improving their camera and software. Great phone! Also purchased 2 cases for my wife and son.
reviews.review_header: Great phone, that gets better with time.

reviews.review_text: After having a U11 break (both sides after sliding out of my cup holder in my car and into the seat rail) within 6 months of purchase, I wanted something other than a glass backed phone--really, why would essentially (no pun intended) every phone company start putting glass on the back of a phone so that it can break on both sides? The Essential PH-1 uses a ceramic back that is more durable than glass. It is also some amazingly new material that is even more slippery than Teflon. The phone slips off of everything. I having lunch with a friend and the table wasn't perfectly level and it was literally sliding toward the edge. We could both see it moving! I waited about 20-30 seconds and stopped it from falling off of the table but had to block it with my wallet. Fast forward to nearly two whole months of ownership and the thing fell out of my pocket while I was sitting at my desk and shattered the screen when it hit the floor--from a whole 17" off the ceramic tiles. I do like the finger reader on the back and the size. I do like the stripped down 7.1 interface but c'mon, you have exactly ONE LEGACY PHONE to support and 8.0 has been out for months—I’m not interested in the beta version that has been on their website for a dozen weeks. I will say that the guys gave me a replacement for a couple of hundred dollars and that was really cool of them. That’s 5 star service right there! The hardware could stand to be better though. I think the biggest issue with the screen is that it sticks about 0.015” of an inch above the titanium band that goes around the perimeter. It has a nice radius that makes the glass look really nice as it blends into the titanium but if it hits on the corner or on the screen--it shatters. it’s also infinitely thin on the edge as it meets the titanium frame and I'm sure that doesn't help maintain an intact screen. Hopefully we’ll see an improvement from these guys with the PH-2. I suppose most folks use a case but I refuse to do that. Let’s just go back to ugly plastic phones if we’re going to need a case huh? I REALLY wanted to love this phone and I do really appreciate the customer support. The U11 guys never responded when I tried to get it fixed. Essential was super helpful right away! That alone is reason to try them again and if they get the hardware right I certainly will. I'm between 2 and 3 stars on this guy: minus 1 for software and minus 2 for hardware but the support was outstanding and I'm going to give this a solid 3. I'm looking forward to a PH-2 review of 5 starts!
reviews.review_header: Great support, nice first pass on the hardware but could use some improvement

reviews.review_text: I absolutely love this phone. Not only is the phone beautiful but it is also fast. I sold my Oneplus 5 to cover most of the cost of buying this phone. I do not regret it. The phone has the fingerprint reader in an ideal spot and it is also fast and accurate. Not something I could say for the oneplus 5. It's fingerprint reader was in an odd spot, probably why they moved it to the back for the 5T. Another great point about this phone is if you do not want all the branding other phones have this phone has none. It also supports sprint and verizon networks not just GSM. Alot of people will complain about the camera on this phone but It takes pretty good photos for me. (Keep in mind I am not a photographer so I could care less what the pictures i take look like as long as I can make out what I was aiming at.) Only has 4GB of system ram but that is plenty for android now a days anyways, My oneplus 5 had 8GB but i seriously doubt that really made a difference in performance anyways. Doesn't feel like it did since this phone is just as fast from what I have seen. With the Oreo 8.1 release coming up this phone should only get better. If you want a no frills phone that runs like a flagship phone then I would highly recommend you get this phone. If you choose the moon black keep in mind that phone will be a fingerprint magnet. The white one the fingerprints don't show up as much on. And the gray version that is an amazon exclusive with alexa built right in is a matte finish. So go for that one if you don't want fingerprints on the phone.
reviews.review_header: Great phone. Has some flaws but not many.

reviews.review_text: I have been following the reviews of/for the Essential PH-1 ever since monthly updates stopped coming to my my favorite Nexus 6. Did not think any of the more expensive devices could ever do a better job with the items I use a phone for than the Nexus. However, the Essential PH-1 is a real deal. Just a tad slimmer that my Nexus, which is great and easier to hold. It updated very quick and fast, and I have not had any of the issues so far that many have complained about. Glad to have made this choice. The 360 camera works flawlessly, and Essential has done a great job in perfecting the external device attachment feature using a magnetic snap on. Added a clear TPU case for a better grip and a bit of protection. Update: I had to return the Essential PH-1 because the SIM card reader stopped working. I spent several hours with the AT&T store, new sim card and all. Then many phone calls and a lengthly e-chat with Essential customer service to no avail. I really liked this phone but was not comfortable with trying another one. Also, which was an error on my part, I returned the 360 degree camera in the same package with the cell phone not realizing it should be a separate return, and Amazon did not acknowledge the receipt of the additional accessory. Could not find any answers as to why phone did not see any SIM card. Is it a software or Hardware problem? I am now back to using my old reliable favorite Nexus 6 until whenever.

The good: 1. I have been pleasantly surprised at how good this phone really is. 2. Security updates have been distributed very quickly. Usually within a few days of release by Google. 3. Screen is good for an.LCD. 4. Battery life is very good. 5. I did a clean start so none of the problems experienced by those that tried the transfer method. The bad: 1. Camera, although greatly improved still has a way to go to truly be flagship quality. 2. No OIS and not even EIS. Some firm if stabilization should have been included. 3. I worry about future support in view of the lip reported sales volume. Hopefully this will not go the way of the Nexbit or Amazon phone - both good ideas that failed to gain any traction.
reviews.review_header: Essential PH-1 is much better (now) than early reviews

reviews.review_text: This for me despite all the negative press is the best phone for me in 2017. Is it the best for you? Maybe not. Hands down the best combination of design and build quality for 2017. Little wonder MKBHD gave it that award. Is it perfect? No. No device is these days. There is no headphone jack, well that's where the industry is headed. Is the camera great? It works for me. It's not Pixel 2 quality all the time but in most cases, it holds it's own when pitted against the pixel 2 and iphone X cameras. It has a mono mode which is best in class and cannot be replicated on other flagships. And yes, there's the 360 camera which is fun accessory to use this with. Phone is fast, I'm currently on the Oreo Beta and this device is a pleasure to use. The Essential support team is great and continue to listen to their users in providing incremental updates. Be sure to join Essential on Reddit r/essential if you will be picking this up.
reviews.review_header: Ignore the negative reviews, this phone deserves all of the praise it can possible get!

reviews.review_text: Love this phone! I have had it a little over a week. I have been following this phone for a long time and have been debating on getting it. oddly enough I have been an Apple Fanatic for years. I have a macbook pro, an ipad, few ipods, and iphones. I have an Iphone for my work phone and have not ever considered getting an android again. Was very hesitant because of reviews but boy should you not hesitate! I got a used one from Amazon for $345 and it had barely a scratch on it. The durability and craftsmanship on this phone is amazing! Side note, this phone does not work on US Cellular. I was going to use it to replace my work phone but they would not accept it as the phone is not on their List of "Unlocked Phones." No worries, decided to jump on my girlfriends Verizon plan and finally have my own personal phone. Can gladly put the work phone down and use this one when at home. People complain about the camera but really it seems to work just fine for me. Some photos are a little darker than usual but it sounds like they have sent out updates to the camera to make it better. Anyway's if you're on the fence for this phone, just get it! I wish I would have a few months ago.

I don't know what all the negative reviews in the media are about. I love my new phone. I've updated the software to the Oreo beta and although there are a few bugs it really isn't that bad. I'd say it was no worse in terms of app crashes etc... than my original Pixel XL that had been updated to Oreo. The camera also isn't as bad as the professional reviews make out. I have installed the Pixel Camera apk from XDA and tend to use that. The camera is fine for what I need it for. The screen is good, not OLED, but at least it's not plague by the burning in problem that's affecting the Pixel 2 XL. Battery life is excellent. Android Pay and NFC works, although not as well as it did on my Pixel. Sometimes it needs another tap on the reader. For the price you really can't go wrong. I live in the UK and paid the import duty to have it shipped over and still, it was ridiculously cheap compared to other flagship phones. I would recommend it to anyone who likes pure/stock Android and doesn't like the look of the new Pixel 2. And it looks really, really, good! I constantly have people asking me what phone I have! It's what the Pixel 2 should have looked like, not some ugly Samsung/LG crossbreed! It looks and feels classy like Apple products. It's just a shame that the launch wasn't a very smooth experience for Essential! Hopefully they'll be releasing the PH-2 next year but who knows?!

I purchased this phone based on many reviews. Upon arrival it was well packaged in a plain brown Amazon shipping box with packing pillows. The Essential PH-1 box itself is very simple, much like the phone. Almost solid black and very sturdy. Unboxing this phone is much like other high end phones. The phone itself is well presented and the accessories are prominently displayed. This phone boots up fairly quickly for the first time. If you already have a google ID the setup is very quick. If you have your settings and apps backed up with google then everything begins to download automatically. If you have multiple email accounts you will need to set those up after the initial setup is complete. ***the major negative review about this phone had been the camera*** The phone immediately prompts you to do system updates, DO THEM! These updates tremendously helped the camera quality. This phone also has portrait mode which is nearly on par with Apples on the 7+ and newer phones. Not quite as good, but for half the price you should be satisfied. The build quality of this phone is excellent. I ordered a case, but I am tempted to go naked. The Titanium frame feel good and grippy in your hand. The ceramic back looks beautiful but smudges easily. I find I am constantly wiping it off. The Gorilla glass did scratch with my keys though, so investing in a quality screen protector would be worth it. This has a flat display, so tempered glass protectors should look great on this phone. One of the unique features of this model is the magnetic attachments for accessories. This is a really neat method but be careful. the phone is a magnet, I accidentally grabbed a pile of paper clips on my desk. Overall I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this phone to anyone already in the Android ecosystem. If you are an iPhone user looking for a more affordable option you should have a fairly short learning curve, give it a shot!
reviews.review_header: Look out Samsung, Essential is nearly there!
