reviews.review_text: Essential is on to something with this first phone. Its design is unmatched. It feels so sturdy in the hand, Better feel than the S8 and I LOVED the way that phone felt. Unfortunately for as much as it gets right, It gets two things really....really wrong. The camera and the speaker. The camera on the essential phone is abysmal. It brings memories of the htc one m7. Great for the time but not ok today. Not even in the $500 price range. You have the oneplus 5 and the huawei honor 8 that give you a much better camera for the price. Pictures come out grainy and dynamic range is way off and leaves a lot to be desired. Next, and this may not be a big deal for everyone but it is for me, The speaker. It's really bad. Very tinny and oddly placed on the left side of the phone. I covered it SO many times with my pinky, by holding the phone upright to watch that I had to modify the way I held it. The screen is gorgeus and the colors are just right. The phone is just butter for everything. Extremely smooth and shouldn't slow down for years to come.... But with 2 huge shortcomings... I'm just not sure if it's a keeper.
reviews.review_header: Absolutely STUNNING Design but that camera...

reviews.review_text: I received this phone a few days ago and am very impressed so far. I know they had some issues with software at the beginning of the release but it's been very quick and smooth for me so I'm glad I waited. I'm coming from a Galaxy S6 which had an amazing camera for it's time two years ago and the pictures on this camera seem comparable, with more color accuracy. I did notice that pictures take a bit longer to take on the Essential Phone, which is a bit annoying, but the Essential developers have been constantly working to improve the camera and other parts of the software, and giving bi-weekly updates on reddit which I appreciate. I haven't installed the Android 8 Oreo beta and am planning on waiting until the official release. The battery life has been amazing compared to what I'm used to with the S6.

I am up grading my opinion of this phone, at first I was going to use it for a door stop but the budget wouldn't allow it. Lots of things to dislike, the Bluetooth is quirky, hard to pair with most of my stuff and it would drop out frequently. Another point is no headphone jack and it takes a specific one at that, I bought a two pack of headphone adapters and they didn't work, they didn't even cut the speaker off. The adapter that comes with it, works. Everything on the screen seemed so small compared to my previous one and the colors were kind of muted and the screen was slightly blurred. Those are the main things that bothered me I have worked through most of them, the screen problem was the pre-installed screen protector, took it off and color was good and the smallness was actually due to the high resolution. Now the good stuff is the large onboard memory 128gb, not having an expansion capability was not an issue for me. I found the camera to be ok and I'm going to give the 360 attachment camera a try. Another nice thing is that it charges fast! Less than an hour from o to 80% I think it's worth $ 400.and I'll be happy with it until its time for a new one.
reviews.review_header: Well not so bad after all :)

reviews.review_text: I normally don't leave reviews but I felt compelled to do so for this phone. I have to say starting off, I switch phones constantly. I am coming from an iPhone 7, which is a great phone but I find iOS to be really boring. I was hesitant to buy this phone at the original price but since it dropped 200 off, I picked it up immediately. I had to see what Andy Rubin's phone was all about and I gotta say, I like it more than I thought I would. The design is striking and the feel in the hand is great although it is a bit slippery. I like heavy, bricky phones. I always thought that it feels more sturdy and premium and this is the heaviest phone I've held but once again, it feels great. I purchased the Pure White and it looks beautiful. The stock Android experience on this phone is what you would expect: Fast, responsive and almost zero lag. I say almost because the RAM Management on here isn't the greatest. If you have a lot of apps open, it WILL bog this thing down but not by any grand amount, just enough to notice. Aside from Essential own Camera app, this thing is bare. It has 31 apps installed on it and it is all Google apps and YouTube. It really is a blank slate. The battery is better than most Android phones I've owned with the exception of the battery king, The Moto Z Play. I'm getting around 5.5 to 6 hours of SOT. I use GPS, LTE and listen to music and YouTube constantly. I start my day around 8AM and by 6PM, I'd still have around 30% in the tank, very respectable. Charging the phone is also very fast. The USB C cable with the 27watt brick is no joke, that thing can charge the phone from 0 to 100% in about an hour and 20 minutes. The display is an LCD panel, which might turn some off and understandably so. It definitely doesn't get as bright or vibrant as a Samsung S7 or 8, but it is very serviceable. I keep the brightness around 50-75 and I've never had a problem seeing or using this phone outside. The fingerprint sensor is just OK. The process is not very smooth. I've had to scan my index finger multiple times for it to register. And once it did register, it would only recognize it 6/10 times that I would try to unlock it. This goes for both fingers. If you try to unlock it and it does not work multiple times, it will lock you out until you press the power button. It will not provide any haptic feedback after that point until you do press the power button and try again. Major headache but I can live with it for now. The audio experience is not anything amazing. If you are looking for HTC style of experience, look elsewhere. It's no where close. It gets loud, sure. But it's also tinny and a bit distorted. Even the small iPhone 7 has better speakers than this. Is it tolerable? Yes, but also remember tolerable has a negative connotation and take that how you want but I wouldn't be listening to music on this without some headphones or earphones. The camera is actually as bad as they say. In good lighting, it takes OK pictures. But when it's bad, it's terrible. The app is slow and really bare. But hey, I'm not much of a camera guy but I did own an S7 and that thing was a champ in the camera department. I'll wait for Essential to continue to push out updates for it's camera app and see how it improves but software can only do so much. I'm on T-Mobile and I get data and service anywhere that I had with my iPhone 7. In fact, I get LTE+ in some areas, which is Cat 6 and higher so I am happy to report both quality of calls and data usage are on point. There are a few things I need in a phone: battery life, a nice display, stock and close to stock Android, preformance and build quality. I didn't mention storage as this has 128GB of storage on it. 116GB of that is usable. I don't need wireless charging. I don't really even need waterproofing. It does have an IP54 rating, which is a light misting but I'm cool with that. The headphone jack, I suppose I've become accustomed to using Bluetooth, so that isn't a deal breaker for me. All in all, this phone has everything I need but I would like improvements to the camera and fingerprint scanner. Is it worth 499? I'd say so! It depends on what the person uses it for and what that person defines as essential. I would not pay other 500 for this. You could get better phones with all or most of the features if you were into it. But for the price point, it's a solid built phone, great battery life, more than adequate display and stock Android is always a great preformer with zero bloat. I'll hang on to it for a little bit and update after a month.
reviews.review_header: A solid device but needs some work! Could be great!

reviews.review_text: This phone works amazing. I find I have about three times the battery life from my last Android phone. It's definitely a barebones OS but that is probably why my battery life is so great. One downside is if you want a case for the phone and you want to use the 360 camera you have to take the case off every time to use the camera which is not a big deal. The picture quality is about the same as my last Android but it has a lot better depth of field due to the dual camera system on the back. I have not yet tried out the 360 camera but my guess is it will be just fine for my purposes. I did notice that if you get a different camera app the depth of field goes away but that's probably due to the default camera app is built specifically for this phone. The phone feels very well built. I have large hands and it is very comfortable. The screen is a lot better than my last phone the quality is very nice.

Picked this up during the cyber monday sale. Came bundled with the 360 camera. The Good: 1. Very well built and feels like a quality product. 2. Top notch screen, plenty bright, good colors. The camera cut out is non intrusive IMO. 3. Plenty fast with no noticeable lag. Stock android at play here. 4. Unlocked- can be used practically anywhere in the world. 5. 128GB is plenty for almost anything. 6. Has already received a few updates to the software to make it more user friendly. 7. The size to screen ration is unbeatable. This is a very very compact phone with a large 5.7 inch screen. The usability factor is immense. What Could be Better: 1. Maybe the camera could be slightly better but my expectations from a phone camera are limited to start with . 2. It does miss on certain features like the Headphone Jack and the IP rating. But when you take 200$ off the sticker price its easy to forget the omissions. Frankly, for the price it is being retailing right now, I see nothing barring the 5T that can match it.And visually this is a far superior product. Give this one a shot. You should not be disappointed.

Needed a new phone, and am on Verizon. Didn't really like the options available through the carrier, especially since those phones tend to come with extra manufacturer and carrier bloatware. Finding phones that Verizon does not carry in their product line that still work with Verizon is really difficult. I was interested in the OnePlus phones, but they still are not supported on Verizon. Since I was unwilling to switch carriers due to my great experience with Verizon's coverage, I looked elsewhere. I ran into the Essential brand and found that they officially are supported by Verizon. On top of that, they were offering a good discount on Amazon. I thought I'd try it out. To my surprise, it was extremely easy to activate on Verizon. It only required a simple Sim card switch. I had to disable an advanced calling feature to get the calls to work properly, but that was the only hiccup. Pros: Fast with great battery life Beautiful design that seems resistant to damage Charges pretty quickly and lasts all day with decent to heavy use Lots of storage space No bugs or incompatibility yet Fingerprint reader and buttons in a great location. Very ergonomic for people with smaller hands due to minimized bezel Cons: A little slippery. Doesn't sit on an inclined surface well. Can be solved with a case No expandable memory - though 128GB helps with that problem No built-in headphone jack - my headphones are bluetooth anyway. Camera a little slow - I think it's a software issue Slightly heavy when compared to what is out on the market now. I like it - makes it feel luxurious, and not cheap. Overall: Fantastic phone for the price, especially in the US market.
reviews.review_header: Didn't really like the options available through the carrier

reviews.review_text: Took a risk on a small company based on the specs and curiosity. Have been using iPhones for years and concerned about the transition to Android / leaving the Apple ecosystem. In short, the experience with this phone, so far, has been almost flawless for my use patterns. In addition, it is just a lovely thing to hold, look at and use. What's best: - interface is smooth, deeply featured and an easy transition from Apple for me. In fact, I find Android more deeply featured (maybe to an unnecessary level, but the "extra" level of control does not bother me. So far, all the apps I have wanted (and it is not too many) are present and work very, very well. This phone is FAST. - the google ecosystem works very well. outlook works well, travel apps work well, and so on - no "extras" wasting space that I don't want to lose. - the display and form factor. Very well done. Much written about the "notch" at the top. Not an issue, that is well utilized. More important for me is the bottom of the phone, which is conveniently configured to permit easy 1 hand access to the launcher and the entire screen at the same time. Well thought out for a single hand pattern of use. Did not like the Samsung product in my hand nearly as much, or even the iPhone. Also, the display is gorgeous. - data / call quality on ATT, great - easy of activation on ATT, great - heft/feeling in hand - substantial, well built - best looking build quality I have yet seen. Looks/feels premium quality - like the more rectangular form with the radius corners on the screen - kudos to the industrial design team on this one - all the way around - google assistant - wow. superior to Siri. Did not expect that level of benefit to accrue that quickly - the 128GB and 4GB ram, standard - who will take the lower memory version of any Apple product? Nobody who has used one. - the extra $600 in my bank account - if this phone continues to perform as well as it has - I am gone from Apple, possibly forever. While I still have a risk with this small company, I feel that I have received a bargain. Heck, I could buy a OnePlus to back it up and still not be at the cost for iPhone X with the amount of memory I want. - company has been IMPRESSIVE with upgrade schedule - fingerprint reader, fast, well placed Like less - noticed only 1 bug that bothers me. The one I want fixed most of all is automatic bluetooth synching with my car. right now, I can get it synched with a verbal command to the google assistant. An extra step. The company was responsive within 24 hours explaining that the bug was being tracked and scheduled for the Oreo upgrade (in Jan?). - the camera app, which I don't use much - is less featured than other options. To be honest, that is not a feature I care much about on a phone. - the odd tricks that one has to go through to get one's stuff out of the Apple ecosystem. For example, getting rid of apple texting is a monumentally silly pain in the rear. That's all on Apple. I had to turn it off on my old "sim-less" phone. Then all my family friends still in Apple land could send me texts. Really ticked off my spouse, but I recognize that as ALL on Apple, and consider it a shady practice. Another reason to leave them behind. By the way, that has nothing to do with this phone - it is more about the transition. - the "slickness" of the phone - the ceramic side is so smooth it seems to actually floats on firm, smooth surfaces - this phone will slip off a slightly inclined notebook (but is very tough, I would venture it to be far more sturdy than the iPhone 8 and iPhone X!) - the limited number of cases available, but I was able to find one that is not too bad. Still, sorry to cover any part of this phone's design. Really very stunning Tricks I don't need/want - facial recognition - to whom does the benefit accrue with that one? You'll find out when Apple monetizes it. I wouldn't buy the X because it HAS that feature. - wireless charging - would take it if available, but haven't missed it much - submersion resistance level of IP Bottom line - this phone is a great bargain. Superior build, superior industrial design, superior specifications, excellent, clean operating system and installed apps, excellent cellular/wifi and virtually every band available. Again, the risk I still feel is with the small company - will they continue to come through as they have so far? I can't see the future, but I will say this - they have me as a customer right now, and have done nothing but delight me to this point.

I've had this phone for about a month and I absolutely love it. I did a lot of research about it because it was the first time I was getting a new phone in 4 years. I don't swap out phones every year. I hold on to them. After having 2 Galaxy's back to back, I wanted something new. I know what some have said about the camera but I also know the phone is fast, sleek and a truly amazing and with the updates, the camera has gotten quite good. The fact there have been so many updates coming out to fix the camera, software and security patches made me confident in my purchase. I had looked at another phone (that is getting really rave reviews) and was just about to purchase it but after hearing the customer service from the company was awful, I decided not to. Another phone everyone is talking about this year, I heard the updates are sent very infrequently. I wanted a good quality product by a company that backs up what they put out. Was it perfect? No. They are putting out updates to fix it all the time and I love that. It's a solid and gorgeous phone. And oh....no bloatware!!! Fantastic.

I have the Essential phone now since a week and used it as my daily driver. The price has dropped $200 since I bought it, and since Amazon does not price match after shipping, I will have to return this phone in order to buy it at a better price. The overall look and feel of this phone is excellent. The combination of titanium and ceramic looks and feels great. I personally don’t mind the slightly larger weight of the device. To me the phone somehow reassembles the older iPod’s and I love it. Seeing that screen for the first time was amazing. The little font camera cutout (Cyclopes eye) is barely noticeable after a while and way smaller than the iPhone’s X cutout. Stock android is a plus and the phone runs smooth, most of the time. I had to reset it once a day so far, as it would just stop working in the middle of a task (Various tasks). The position of the ear piece is a bit off, and you need to hold the phone in a slight angle to hear anything. I also find the call volume to be low, even if maxed out. This is especially annoying at louder places like an airport. Not a deal breaker, but just something I noticed. I connected my Samsung Galaxy Frontier S3 watch to the phone and generally it works pretty good (some of the features are not as good vs. having it connected to a Samsung phone). However, there seems to be an issue with the plugin as I quite often would receive a call, take it on the phone, but it was directed to the watch instead. This caused me quite some trouble. The battery life is great and I easily make it through a full day with normal use. Overall I have to say I am very impressed with Essentials first phone, and can recommend it. With the recent price drop it should be a strong contender for everyone who is looking for an Android phone that offers great specs at an affordable price.
reviews.review_header: Overall a great phone, with minor issues.

reviews.review_text: I purchased this phone as a replacement for my Nexus 6; while I really liked the Nexus 6 and the "pure" Android experience, it was long in the tooth and due for an upgrade. Keep in mind that I only picked this up -after- the price reduction from the initial price so I am reviewing it with that price in mind. TL;DR: Pros: Display, size, storage, Android updates (supposedly - still no 8.0 OTA) Cons: No headphone jack, camera, slippery body, display (if you hate the notch) The display is eye catching and the feel in the hand is premium. It's smaller than the N6 but also heavier on account of the ceramic & titanium build. While the ceramic feels nice it's as slippery as ice. I don't mean this as an analogy, I found the coefficient of static friction in testing to be a little under 0.08. Ice on ice has a range of .02-.09. Teflon is 0.04 so this only slightly less slippery than Teflon. You need a case or this phone will slide on any surface at an angle of less than 4 degrees. I did find the camera cutout a bit odd at times and certain apps in fullscreen mode don't seem to know it's there. Others work fine. I prefer AMOLED to the LCD tech used in this phone but it's perfectly adequate if a bit duller than I'm used to. The camera is mediocre. I found performance spotty an occasionally worse than the N6. It does have some lag to it so be prepared to wait a second while it processes. Storage is great - I would prefer an SD slot but 128GB of default storage certain helps ease the pain; I don't really have to juggle anything on device storage and that includes keeping a full music library on board at all times. I absolutely hate the lack of headphone port. It's horribly anti-consumer and gives you yet another adapter to carry around compliments of the USB-C standard. I like the new standard, but there is absolutely no benefit to removing the headphone jack. I can't charge my phone while listening to music (without another dongle with a passthrough) and the USB-C to 3.5mm headphone jack adapter doesn't always work properly leading to situations where my phone randomly stops playing music or just starts playing over the phone speakers. On the whole, it's a decent phone for the money and is a decent replacement for my N6, though not perfect.
reviews.review_header: Decent phone with premium feel but with compromises

reviews.review_text: My last phone was a windows 950xl. So I like trying the newcomer startup type phones obviously. I wanted a similar screen size but smaller form factor.. this fit the bill. So far I've been pretty happy with it. Comparing speed with my buddy's S9 I really can't tell a difference in speed.. just that mine is more affordable. I just popped in my T-mobile card from the previous phone and I was done (so it works with T-mobile well) It seemed to get the oreo 8.1 security update actually before the pixel2 another friend has. Its plenty fast, feels substantial. I'm running the Microsoft launcher on mine, main reason is the daily bing wallpaper. Having Edge and Chrome on the same phone is nice. Camera is fine for what I do, I guess that's what ppl complain about, maybe iti was pre-oreo that had more issues.. it seems halfway decent. Everything is pretty smooth and solid.
reviews.review_header: So I like trying the newcomer startup type phones obviously

reviews.review_text: To establish my Android Street Cred™: I was a T-Mobile G1 preorder customer. Then I had a G2. Then I've had a handful of Nexus devices, along with most iterations of the Moto X. This is one of the best of them. Fantastic industrial design. Very prompt software updates; this is basically the only phone that isn't called a Nexus or Pixel guaranteed to receive Google's monthly software updates. On the negative side: the camera isn't good. My old Nexus 6P had a better camera. Some people report weak signal issues with T-Mobile, but, my particular unit has far better reception than my 6P did on T-Mo. YMMV. tl;dr - if you're looking for a Nexus/Pixel software experience but unwilling to shill out the money for a Pixel 2, the PH-1 is a pretty unbeatable value at the moment.
reviews.review_header: This is one of the best of them

reviews.review_text: Surpassed my expectation. The screen is brilliant and it is more stylish than the google pixel phone which i returned to get this one. The camera app has been getting better with each update and the black and white camera is actually very good in low light. In fact i find myself taking more grayscale videos and images than color. Hopefully the color camera on the back catches up soon. Battery life is phenomenal. Went clubbing sat night and came back and forgot to plug into the charger. Did a day trip using gps for a good part of the day and the battery was 15% by the time i was back home that night. Finger print reader unlocks my phone very fast.
reviews.review_header: Better than phones at much higher prices.

reviews.review_text: I purchase this phone in cyber Monday deal with 360 camera for just 399. Pros -great form factor, which is the only one I could find in flagship phone other than iphone, Easily to reach every corner of the screen in one hand. - frequent security update. I receive monthly updated after using this phone, which should be the only one other than pixel and Nexus phone Cons Not great battery life. Many comment said they have good battery life. But I just got a not so good battery life. Normally a got 3 to 3.5 screen on time, with Bluetooth and GPS on. I don't play any games , just normal surfing , Facebook , and messaging, so I really don't know why there are many user said they got more than 5 hour screen on time, It is really impossible for me use the phone in such a long time without charging. Not quite smooth indeed. When I open WhatsApp to people which I have many conversation before for many years, Its take quite a long time to open it, which I don't expect in flagship phone. While app opening is generally fast, screen rotation when changing orientation is not as instant as I expect in flagship phone. Fragile phone. A 2 feet drop make my screen crack. Yes, it is my fault, buy my previous moto x style drop much more times and much higher height and the screen is still intact. I believe the glasses is good quality , it may be j ust because I am unlucky or due to phone design. A case is need for this phone but it may compromise one handed usability. Those are major pros and cons I encountered in my 2 month usage. There are still some minor problems. Reception is acceptable but but in bad reception area it constantly have worse reception than my friend phones like Samsung or iphone. But I usually stay in good reception area so it is not a big problem for me. Photo quality is better than my expected. In Good lighting situation, image is bright and detail can be seen. Low light condition is not comparable to other flagship phone but it is what I expected. The worse part is the shutter response, after pressing the shutter, need to wait a few second to see the image which is disappointing. Oreo update is still beta. For a company which promise quick upgrade, there are some competitors already release Oreo upgrade. I would like to have a stable oreo upgrade as quick as possible. Verdict I really like small compact flagship phone, if the battery life can be improve by software upgrade , I will love this phone.

The headline says a lot of it, but I want to clearify that this phone is awesome. There are a lot of long critical reviews, that make you over think this purchase. A lot of people rate it 3 to 4 star range, but don't read into them too hard. My last phone was a Nexus 5x which was great, until it started to get phased out and lag uncontrollably with Oreo on it. After, I looked into getting a pixel, but did not want the same experience I had with my Nexus, because I thought it was more on Google's end with the software update issues. I also didn't want to drop a grand on a phone over the span of 2 years of monthly payments. After doing some research, I found the Essential phone, which had everything I wanted in a phone; -Great newly designed, sleek bezel -Big screen, small phone... I love this because I can hold it in my hand so comfortably and the screen is almost -Basically identical hardware to the pixel 2 -Stock, pure Android -Andy Rubin's awesome vision for a simple, futuristic company -Smooth operating system and seamless multitasking -Great camera (It's gotten way better, people are really over critical on this, its definitely better than my Nexus 5x) -A ton of storage (I'll never fill close to 128gb's of space) Yeah... I want to keep this short because I'm tired of all these tech nerds taking a dump on this phone. I've had it for about a month and sure, the camera might not be as good as some other phones, but its pretty darn close for me. If you're not an elitist photographer and want a phone from a company that wants the simplest, purest, freest android experience, then go with this phone. It's top notch, especially if you're considering a Pixel. I prefer this much more, especially because the screen and bezel is much nicer.
reviews.review_header: This is everything I wanted in a phone, for an inexpensive price.

reviews.review_text: This phone has a ton of love/hate and divided opinions. Knowing this, and doing a lot of research before buying it - while fully intending to return it if I ran into the myriad issues reported - here is my experience so far. I have the newer revision white model and it came with stock 7.1.1 Android. Right out of the box I updated it to the last OTA offered, I think I took two total OTA updates with reboots. Being an experienced Nexus phone-haver and rooting/romming/tinkering with 6 different nexus phones and tablets, I also was excited to sideload the 8.0 Oreo beta 2. I unlocked the bootloader and reboot/auto wiped. Then I sideloaded the Oreo beta 2 factory image with no issue. I fully expected to be risking a "beta" experience with this phone due to its reputation, but after all updates and Oreo upgrade, I have not seen any of the issues people slam this phone for. The OS is very smooth, scrolling lag isn't a thing for me, the touch response is slightly less sensitive than my Nexus 6p which I just moved from but isn't a problem. Now the camera app... doesn't take the best quality pics. Coming into this phone after the devs have been updating the phone and app it isn't as bad as reviews from even a month ago, but compared to the nexus/pixel camera app it still isn't even close. But it does work now. Please note you have to update the camera app from the Play Store after upgrading the OS as well, make sure it is always updated as the devs work on it quite a bit. Battery life is great, I had about 3 hours of SOT with heavy use yesterday and after 14 hours still had 45% left. Way better than my N6p. Only weird things I've noticed are that the Amazon Shopping app and Prime Video apps will not work, they come up with the splash screen and then go black or never log in. I have to swipe them away from the recent screen. Not sure who's to blame there, app devs or Essential. Overall this phone is fast, I love having 128GB of storage, and all the apps I use except Amazon apps work as expected. I would recommend this phone without any problem. Feels great, looks amazing, and is performing well.
reviews.review_header: So far a great experience, beautiful phone

reviews.review_text: If you're interested in this phone you may have watched the reviews from back when it was released, as did I. When I got the phone in December I was thus anxious to see if the specific complaints were still present. I figured I would address a couple with my experience for anyone looking now. Buggy software: fixed. I watched videos with wonky page scrolling and apps closing, I have not encountered this at all. Everything is smooth and working as intended. My previous phone was a moto x pure which I was a big fan of and honestly that was a buggy phone in comparison. Sometimes it won't recognize the 360 camera at first and you have to take it off and put it back on, about 1 second. That's about it. Don't worry about your essential phone being buggy. Bad camera: fixed, largely. The camera takes great pictures in good lighting, and ok pictures in low light. This is standard for phones- some are a little better but I have used a lot of phones and let's be honest none really triumph in low light under normal circumstances. I would put essential within the margin of error of anything besides maybe the pixel/iPhone 8/x. Those were the 2 big complaints every publication had when reviewing the phone and they are non-issues. This is a really nice phone at a decent price.
reviews.review_header: Jan18 review/status of some web review complaints

reviews.review_text: Amazing phone!!! Clearly the best android ever, I wish other manufacturers 1) take pride in their devices as experienced with this phone b) listen to their customers complaints and dislikes. Its really not that hard. Build quality like no other i have had in many years. I have read so many reviews and watched so many videos and at this point i am surprised with the cons that other reviewers bring up (professional bloggers or regular users). Really ? give this phone 3 and 4 stars. Do we really think there is nothing wrong with other phones critical shortcomings that affect daily usage and infuriate the end user. I have had to live with critical and truly frustrating bugs with other manufacturers (let me not name them but you know who you are). Bugs that were never resolved year after year. At least the Essential team resolved most if not all of their outstanding issues a couple of months after release, pretty respectable if you ask me. Regarding features now... I see from other reviews that water proofing must be a super critical need I guess these days. Also like how we all take OLED for granted now and complaint for the choice of using LCD. Then when we get an OLED we complaint about image retention and inaccurate colors. Which is it ?? two different techs with known pros and cons. Essential's screen is nothing short of brilliant, bright, sharp with astonishing colors. Andy Rubin you are on a great path, keep on ...

So thrilled I nabbed this premium phone (including camera) for $399 on Black Friday. Purchased a following glass cover and case for a clean black on black minimalist look: - Essential Phone PH-1 Case, TUDIA [Ceramic Feel] Lightweight [GLOST] TPU Bumper Shock Absorption Cover Featuring [Tempered Glass Back Panel] for Essential Phone PH-1 (Black) Sold by: W2 Corporation - Essential Phone Screen Protector, Tempered Glass Screen Protector [0.3mm] [9H Hardness] [Crystal Clear] for Essential Phone PH-1 pack of 2 Sold by: mocolo88
reviews.review_header: So thrilled I nabbed this premium phone

reviews.review_text: I have seen many YouTube reviews on this phone that this phone is OK Kinda and has software issues however after having used for a week below are my feedback points. 1. Excellent Build Quality and material :- This phone feels elegant and solid in hands and feels premium quality and strong 2. Screen :- The QHD screen is of good quality certainly not at par with Iphone X or Galaxy S8 + but definitely produces rich and vivid colors 3. Battery :- About an average and lasts a day of moderate to heavy usage and quick charger takes almost 60 mins to make it full 100 %. 4. Speed :- Fast processor for multi-tasking and games , excellent RAM management 5. Software :- Pure Android experience I have had received 3 Software Updates in less than a week so Software keeps getting improved. 6. Camera :- Average , I prefer LG G6 or V30 for Camera over essential Ph1 however if you expect a best camera experience then this phone may disappoint you . Overall I'm happy with my purchase and Iwith every software update this phone gets better , yes I do recommend this phone for its excellent premium build quality and processor speed and QHD screen .

So far this has been the best Android phone money can buy. I was hesitant at first but the build quality and the pure Android OS make this the next best thing to a Pixel Phone. I'm not into comparing camera quality but it's way better than what I had before. So if you are looking for something to take great pictures than buy a Pixel 2 phone but if you just want a Smartphone with a pure Android and no bloatware (Alexa was the only bloatware installed because it's the exclusive Amazon color but you can uninstall her with no problem) than this is the phone your looking for. Very solid phone so you can tell it was built with quality in mind. I would buy their next phone if it comes priced under $500 again with the same specs as this phone. Oreo was waiting to be updated as soon as I powered up the phone. Speaker phone is fine and earpiece sound is great too. Battery life is great considering there was no bloatware on here which I personally think makes a difference in battery life. Any bad reviews about this phone are just being nit picky.
reviews.review_header: Great Android phone with no bloatware.

reviews.review_text: The hardware is so awesome, but the software, not so much. I purchased one (in full price) and liked it so much when I got it to buy another for my partner (this time for the lower price). After using it though you start to notice the terrible touch experience. Sometimes it stops accepting touch gestures at all, and sometimes it decides that a specific spot is being tapped continuously (which would open a random app and invoke random commands on it, like uncontrollably deleting a bunch of emails !!!) The only way to "fix" it temporarily is to shut the screen off, wipe it, and reopen. Often a restart is required. One of the phones is running the Stock nougat and the other is on the official Oreo beta. Both present the same set of touchscreen related issues. And recently essential informed us poor users that 8.0 would not get an official GA build, and that the touch problems would maybe be solved in 8.1, which they are not even telling when the Beta for it would start. Very disappointing, I had high hopes for this phone to be a low-friction just-use-it phone.
reviews.review_header: Beautiful phone, too many software bugs rendering it an artwork - nice to look at but not really useful

reviews.review_text: I have owned this phone / micro computer for a few weeks now. I took a leap of faith coming from Samsung and Nokia before this. The phone has not been turned off since I got it, (The acid test). I put it into an Icipio case immediately, as it is slippery. I have always put my phones into bumper cases for protection. This thing is beautiful, screaming fast, and I believe that most bugs were taken care of in the software updates that happened during my first boot up. The portrait mode camera update I added from the Play store, and it has been a surprisingly good camera. I am happy with this device, and await the forthcoming Oreo update. I really appreciate being able to set this up the way I want, and that it is unlocked world wide. This is a revolutionary device, that runs with the big dogs and often beats them for LE$$!

The Essential Phone has a lot to offer: stock Android, great screen, decent battery life, and expansive storage. Some people complain about the camera, but I find it to be quite good. The camera software could use some improvement--more manual controls, for example--but portrait mode works well, and I find the color reproduction to be quite good. Some people complain about the camera, but I think it's a tempest in a teapot. If you *really* care about photography, you can't beat a DSLR or good mirrorless camera. Essential has made several camera improvements, and they say there are more to come. BTW, the 360-degree camera, which I was able to pick up in a great Cyber Monday package deal, works really well and it's very intuitive. To me, the biggest drawback to the Essential Phone is memory management. After keeping the phone on for a while (days rather than hours), performance degrades noticeably, and it also degrades when I have several memory-hog apps open simultaneously--although that problem is typically solved by simply closing the offending apps. Not a huge problem, but a little surprising considering the specs. Overall, it's a great value and worth the money.
reviews.review_header: Great phone, and don't get all worked up over the camera

reviews.review_text: 22-Feb: I have been using this phone for a few weeks now. So far very very impressed. Design - 5/5. Usability (5/5) Camera (4.8/5) Battery(4.5/5) Let me start with the much maligned camera. Camera: Monochrome mode is the best I have seen on any phone camera. Portrait mode is really good now. Auto mode is good but has about a 0.3 second software lag in low light. The 360 camera is just brilliant. If you buy this phone get the 360 camera accessory - very portable (fits easily into jeans pocket with no discernible bulge) and easy to use. 360 camera software hangs about 5% of the time when I try to navigate to view the picture immediately after taking the picture. For the above mentioned auto mode low light lag and 360 software hang I give the camera 4.8. Having said this I would easily recommend this phone over iPhone/ Samsung note/ Google pixel to camera enthusiasts just for the mono and 360 camera. I have experimented with all 3 phones for their inbuilt camera capabilities. Full disclaimer -Google pixel/iPhone/ Samsung Note beats Essential camera in the Auto mode by a very small margin after all the recent updates. Design and Display - Best looking phone on the market in my view and display is right at the top there with the rest of them. The screen stretches across almost the entire face except for a small notch at the top and a thin bezel at the bottom. Battery - lasts easily for a full day under normal use. However heavy use leaves with little to spare at the end of the day. Interface - Clean, zero bloat and very slick. If I were to nitpick I wish gestures like double tap wake and gestures for volume changes / screenshot were available out of box. Last but not the least, the device is encrypted right from the start and since there is no bloatware and with 3 years of security updates, the phone is right at the top when it comes to security. At this price point, this is by far the best value for money as well. It's comparable to the top phones and beats them in a few areas too!!
reviews.review_header: Amazing product. Severely underrated by the internet.

reviews.review_text: I purchased the Essential Phone on Jan 31 2018. This phone may have had issues when it first came out but as of 2018 it works very well. Better than my vaunted Nexus 6P that it is replacing. That phone performs much worse, has worse lag. It was a fine phone but certainly not perfect. The Essential Phone is still getting bad press and for what I am not sure. The few photos I have taken worked fine and I haven't had anything crash this first week of use. The performance is totally fine. Now on to the build quality. This phone is the best and most elegant phone I have owned period. Hands down. Same size screen as the Nexus 6P but in a much smaller overall package. The lack of bezel is a game changer and the notch is so small you don't even notice it. I appreciate the extra mile they went to achieve this. Way better than the huge cutout on the new iPhone. The only downside is this phone is hard to pick up and hold due to it being so slippery. I reluctantly ordered a slim case for it and it doesn't ad that much bulk but makes it way easier to pick up and hold. I love glass screen protectors and tried to order my favorite brand Skinomi. They didn't have one, only the film type protectors. I looked and purchased an off brand glass protector. I just got it and applied it and now I know why Skinomi didn't make glass protectors. The screen of the Essential phone is slightly curved for the last few millimeters and the outside ring of the glass protector doesn't stick. So fair warning, you have to use film protectors or go Au natural. I have already dropped this phone off the top of the shower (listening to a podcast) and it slid off from over 6' high and landed in the shower with the water hitting it directly. I quickly toweled it off and scrapped off the fiberglass from the shower from the corner of the phone and not a scratch on the phone. Do not try this at home.
reviews.review_header: One of my favorite phones. Ever.

reviews.review_text: Tech sites seemed to be biased. User reports that it might not be for everyone seem very accurate. As for me, I love it! One thing I didn't think about was I used to charge my phone a lot while listening with head buds, and that isn't possible so the headphone jack would be nice. Back is a bit glossy and shows finger prints (I solved this w3ith a thin case). I find the software to be responsive. Camera not anything impressive, but not bad (but I'm not that way inclined).
reviews.review_header: I love it, but also realize it might not be for everyone

reviews.review_text: I have had this for a week and a half. Everything works very well and fully compatible with the SIM card I received from ConsumerCellular to continue my membership in their network. Fingerprint reader makes it very easy and convenient to unlock as I take the phone out of my pocket. The fast processor and large storage make this very responsive. I had seen a number of reviews indicating that the camera left a lot to be desired. My experience so far is that it is more than adequate for general photos and video. I have noticed that it introduces much less barrel effect than my previous phone when shooting closeups of text or other rectilinear material. Down side: it is taking me awhile to get used to the slippery ceramic back. The phone is a very holdable size but if you are used to depending on a stickier back surface, you may find this phone easier to drop. I had to create a small stand to hold the phone from sliding while reading the news during breakfast.
reviews.review_header: This seems to be a great phone for me!

reviews.review_text: The Essential Phone is an excellent phone with a few compromises. Many tech reviews have not really done this phone justice. Let me explain why. Although the phone hardware is well designed, Essential did not include some ideal features like water-resistence, a headphone jack, and an OLED display. The truth is that these decisions were likely made to keep costs down and avoid supply hiccups. Although choosing an excellent IPS instead of an OLED display, may not seem ideal, when considering the Pixel 2 phone's OLED screen blue haze issue, and Apple's supply issue with their OLED displays, Essential made the obvious choice. During the initial rollout Essential had some hiccups in their quality control, but their real blunder was that they initially rushed the software without indicating that the phone was a "work-in-progress". This made the original price tag seem obscene and the phone unrefined. In addition, the camera software was a huge letdown. With the recent price adjustment and the frequent software updates, the PH-1 has become a smartphone package that is easily one of the best phone values today. It is now competitive with the Oneplus 5/5T rather than paling in comparison to the Pixel and iPhone, which are significantly more expensive. That said some folks seem to feel that the Oneplus 5T edges out the Essential PH-1 in a close race. One key thing to consider is Android Oreo. Although both phones will get Android 8, only the PH-1 will support Google's Project Treble which will allow for faster Android updates longer into the future. This means that the Oneplus may become unsupported and not get updates in the near future. The Essential PH-1 looks beautiful, feels well made and gets great reception. Although not number one in the camera, it takes pretty good photos. Unless you have unreasonable expectations, for the price this phone is a great deal. In my book, it is the best phone value going in 2017.
reviews.review_header: The Essential Phone is an excellent phone with a few compromises

reviews.review_text: Everything on the user end is great. I hear it may not have been a while ago before a lot of updates but I find it a nice phone to look at and use. It's a fairly compact phone, as far as phones go these days. I appreciate that too as it makes good use of its size. However, I find it odd to call this the essential phone and not include a headphone jack or the option to expand memory with an SD card. What if my phone dies? An SD card makes that much less of an issue to deal with since you can backup to a little hard drive you can always pull out. Plus, it makes it so much easier for someone with a huge music library to transfer the music. I just move the card over...but with this, it's drag and drop of a huge file that takes almost an hour and sometimes not everything transfers properly and I never know why. Anyway, back to the lack of a headphone jack...I find it mostly upsetting because it should be more water proof than it is especially without a headphone jack. So to take that away and have it's IP rating lower than a lot of it's competition is frustrating. But it's ok. I never dunk my phone in water or risk that really happening. And most of my headphone use is Bluetooth but I do use a standard one sometimes. And there's always the adapter, I guess. Overall, a really great phone that stands out in the competition. I think it's totally worth the money and a lot of my quarrels with it are often things I would say about other high end phones too. I hope there is a sequel to this phone that makes it even better. I'll be keeping an eye out for that.
reviews.review_header: Bad service on T-Mobile. Otherwise a great phone with a couple gripes

reviews.review_text: Please don't buy this phone! So many quirks and issues, the biggest one being that several times a week I can't send or receive calls without constantly toggling airplane mode. I even emailed the developers who basically told me that I must have Sprint (I don't), because they "fixed" the messaging issue, but not on the Sprint network. Are you kidding me?! How do you have a phone that you just shrug and say, "Eh, yeah, it doesn't work on all networks. Sorry not sorry!" If I could return this, I would. Don't make my same mistake.
reviews.review_header: Constant issues, the worst being that I basically can't text anymore

reviews.review_text: I decided to wait a couple weeks before doing a review. First a little background on my phone use ... through work and home I've used a Blackberry, several android phones, Windows phones, and the iPhone going back to the 3S. Since the Blackberry, I've always had an iphone for work. My personal phone has changed quite often until two years ago. At that time I gave up on the Windows phone due to app support and android due to lower app quality and general issues with battery and stability. Since that time I've been running two iphones. After IOS 11, I was very disappointing with the speed of my 6 plus. It would take forever to open an app, and it was having more app crashes than I liked. I didn't like any of the iphone options. The 8 was much of the same and I wasn't ready to pay $1k for the X. I decided I would see what improvements had been made in Android over the past two years. I really wanted a "pure" android experience, since the others I had tried were not. I loved the look and feel of the essential phone, and when they dropped the price it was a no brainier. First, I love the "pure" android experience. The operating system has been very stable and I'm having no battery issues. Standby battery drain is still slightly higher than the iphone, but it's much improved! Most of the android apps are also up to the quality of the IOS counterparts. The essential phone has been fantastic! I still love the quality feel of the phone and the large screen for such a small footprint. I'm not running a case or screen protector for the first time ever. It make me a little nervous, but so far it hasn't been an issue. I have no complaints about the camera. My wife and I were taking pictures at a dance for our daughter, and she preferred my pictures to the ones her mom took on her 7 plus. I'm sure the iphone X and Pixel are better, but I'm very satisfied. Battery life has been very good. I'm very happy with my purchase and think the phone is a steal for the current price.

I am sure glad that I found this phone! I had been using a Sammy Galaxy S 6 for quite a long time and looking to upgrade. I would have probably waited for the S9 but I'm not a big fan of the curved edges. I'm not even sure how I came across this phone but I did a couple weeks of reading and research on it as well as the OnePlus 5t and thought what the heck I'd give it a shot. Fresh out of the box this is a beautiful phone! By far the best looking phone I have owned. I decided that before I ever activated it to go to the Essential developer site and download Oreo Beta and install it. It ran pretty good had a few small freezes and reboots and then they released Oreo Beta 8.1. Since taking that in an OTA update this phone has been the bomb! No more freezes or random reboots it just runs smoothly. I do notice that after many days of uptime battery life begins to wane so I'll do manual reboots ever 3 or days to keep it up. Which by the way can be 30 plus hours with lots of on screen time. I never tried the 5t so I can't really compare but I can say that I am 100% happy with this phone! It just feels like a super quality device and now runs great and camera work very well maybe not the best but really good. If you're looking for a mid priced quality phone give it a shot. I have also use it on both AT&T and verizon and it works great on both.
reviews.review_header: A great phone! Most people will love it!

reviews.review_text: This phone is absolutely amazing for the price. Yes, there are bugs but the essential team is constantly pushing patches to resolve issues and increase performance. Apps open quickly and they are all pretty stable. I purchased the 360° camera and I'm having way too much fun with it. I'm really looking forward to seeing what accessories they will have in the future. I did buy a case for it because as much as they say the phone is drop proof there is still glass on the front. Plus all the internal components would surely suffer. Picture quality on the standard camera is fantastic. This phone is worth the money and I can honestly say that I'm a believer in the company's direction and commitment to their product.
reviews.review_header: This phone is absolutely amazing for the price

reviews.review_text: Stock Android Experience, Titanium-Ceramic construction, Best Bezel-less Display design. The Ph1 is Android at its Best. From the father of Android himself: Andrew Ruben. Also most Unique is their branding: No Branding at all! To all those youtubers taking it down for the average camera... Well from my personal experience, it may not be the best, but it is definitely among the best. And those comparing it with one plus 5t... "Pity you" is all I can say. There are other reviewers who are honest on their review of the ph1 camera. I in fact decidied sacrificing on camera quality for its sturdy make, and super premium hardware and materials,watchong those misleading videos which declare the camera as mediocre, and some even saying total crap. Only after i lay my hands on the device did i discover that the camera is actually top notch and comparable to apple n samsung. Only place where i find it a bit,and i repeat, only a bit lagging is dark ambience- like really dark. The images become a bit noisy n grainy. Rest the camera is just awesome. Man the judderfree superfast performance, and top notch built quality and a superior (if not the best) at the price of mid budget phone make the Essential a must have. Mind you Apple is total glass. One fall... N you are done. Samsungs, i dont wanna talk even. Ugly as usual with mediocre feel n touch, and still containing bloatware. While if you have any doubts about the essential phone sturdiness, just check essential phone break test on youtube. Just check... You will be amazed. Thanks Amazon for super quick international delivery. N Thanks Andrew Ruben for the bery wonderful phone. It is Essential indeed. Never took so much pain, penning a review till now in my 10 years with Amazon. But this product just made me go ahead n write my heart out... It is that good.
reviews.review_header: Purest Android Experience. Avant Garde Phone!

reviews.review_text: It's by far the best phone I ever owned. Small form factor easily fit in a hand with a huge screen. Feels solid, looks luxury. I have not experienced any freezes or slowdowns other are talking about, and I have about 150 apps on my phone including many that like to hang out in the memory. Camera might not be the best, but more then decent and perfectly satisfies my needs. 360 camera is a nice toy. Battery life is more then adequate. You can't get anywhere close to the specs of this phone for it's price. My only concern is if by practically giving away this phone, Essential will be able to stay in business.

The build quality is so amazing. I dropped my phone on my concrete drive way and it bounced then slid about 10 ft. I was nervous to pick it up. When I did, it was still in pristine condition. Never could've thought it was possible. Improvements : The camera is a work in progress. I can say that is about the only thing that is bothersome. But I have a DSLR so it's not a deal breaker. I think a notification slider like the one plus would be a huge improvement. Overall this phone is amazing
reviews.review_header: Hands down. The classiest toughest phone around

reviews.review_text: Have had the phone for about a month so far. Its replacing a Asus Zenfone 2 and WOW what a difference. The phone feels quite solid and is the perfect size for my hand. The phone also performs quite well. no real quirks that I can point out yet as I haven't had it long enough though I do use it everyday to brows the web and listen to music. Battery life is quite good and it charges quickly using other 5v wall chargers. I do believe that most of the camera issues have been smoothed out from what I've read before buying this phone as I have yet to encounter a problem with my own. Pictures are crisp and more vibrant than my prior phone's camera. I am highly satisfied with this phone.
reviews.review_header: The phone feels quite solid and is the perfect size for my hand

reviews.review_text: Update: So the first Essential phone I ordered from here had a small hairline fracture in the back chassis. They sent out a replacement unit & the replacement has scuffs at the top of the screen new the sensors and had black smudges around the titanium chassis...nothing major I just dont know why these units are clean brand new. Maybe its my luck. Not worth sending it back I can deal with it..I need a phone..Still 5 stars the phone is amazing. Just minor cosmetic issues with chassis.. I just switched from the gigantic phablet Pixel 2 XL & I must say the Essential phone fits me alot better. The screen is 10x better than the Pixel 2 & 2 XL. The camera is a bit worse but I can hardly tell as I am not a photographer. This Essential phone camera is phenomenal. The speed on the Essential phone is almost identical to the 2 XL. The battery life is great. I don't need a crazy flag ship phone. If you want a pure Android phone with a great display, camera, battery & able to use it with one hand the Essential phone is hands down the best smartphone for the price.

This is an extremely good phone. I've only had it for a short period of time but I can honestly say this phone is performing far above and beyond any expectations I had for it. Coming from an apple 6 plus I am shocked at the phone's elegance, intuitiveness, usability, accessibility, performance and just over all completeness. I, at one time, only used my phone for work related activities. Using this phone for that and so much more. The best thing about this phone is it has everything I need and nothing more. A wonderful change of pace and perspective. Highly recommend this highly underrated phone. Battery lasts long, full day heavy use, uses maybe half of capacity. Quick charge feature works well. Att network call quality far better than iPhone and more reliable. Screen is delectible. Bluetooth is flawless. Camera is wonderful after camera software update! Absolutely fantastic phone!!
reviews.review_header: Perfect hardware and software make a perfect phone!!!

reviews.review_text: My prior phone was a Samsung Galaxy S6 that was on it's last legs. Even still, I was wary of the Essential because of many reviews criticizing the camera and the responsiveness. It's refreshing to have a more stripped-down version of Android without all of the bloat! I've had no issues with the camera or responsiveness. I also love having a larger screen in the same size of phone! It's a very attractive device. I'm less crazy about the lack of a headphone jack, but that's not an option with most phones. I take off a point for that and the fact that the phone is slick to the point of almost dropping it often. I knew these things going into it but it's still room to improve!
reviews.review_header: I'm not sure I'd call it Essential - but I'm very happy!

reviews.review_text: I've had this phone for about a month, and I'm very happy with it so far. I am not particularly a "power user", but I want my phone to do a few things very well. Note that my comparisons will be to my previous phone, an HTC One (m7) (yes, a 5-year old phone) -Connectivity: I have not observed any signal / reception issues on AT&T -- reception is comparable to or better than previous phone. -Photo quality: I know the PH-1 has received a lot of criticism for its camera, when compared to other 2018 flagship phones. All I can offer is that it's a very definite improvement over a 2013 phone! Quality is just fine as far as I'm concerned. -Operational "smoothness": My experience with this phone has been perfectly smooth. Scrolling on webpages / apps / menus is all smooth. Responsiveness is good. One note: In developer options, there's a setting to turn off "grip rejection". DO THIS! Otherwise software creates a "dead area" for 5mm or so around the edge, which makes some controls and links untouchable. -Battery life: Easily 2 days of "normal" use. Never been below 30% after one day of very heavy use. This phone has seen a lot of early bad press, but at the current price and feature set, it's a fantastic deal. Oh, and the only special thing about the "amazon" version is that Alexa is a preinstalled app (but she can be uninstalled without any trouble.)
reviews.review_header: Fantastic deal for a great phone

reviews.review_text: This is easily one of the most well built phones on the market right now. The Titanium and ceramic feel great (though very smooth, easy to slide off clothing if it's resting on your leg) and the screen is sharp with really wide viewing angles. I have a Pixel 2 XL and will be returning it. For half the cost the phone feels just as snappy performance wise. The camera on the Essential doesn't quite compare to the incredible one found on the Pixel 2 phones but for me personally I feel the essential phones camera works really well and I understand it should continud to improve in the upcoming updates to the phone. All things considered, this phone is worth a purchase if you're looking for something new and solidly built.
Best phone I've had in a long time. Fast and great battery life. I've installed Oreo beta, from Essential webpage. Coming from a Galaxy S7 Edge.
reviews.review_header: Good price for a great phone

reviews.review_text: Great phone. Very premium feel. Camera is horrendous in lowlighting but takes decent pictures in good lighting.

If you are reading this I recommend reconsidering purchasing this device. Everything worked correctly for a few hours, but suddenly the audio from my headphones stopped. I have tried all of the methods I know of to fix strange problems like this. Restarting, a factory reset, developer options, etc. Nothing worked. The speakers on the phone still worked, but using the included adapter did not. I collected a large amount of information regarding the problem I was having and sent it to Essential to see if they could help me. I am not an expert, they should know more. They did not help me at all. They could not confirm if it was the adapter or the phone that was the source of the issue. They did not even try to, perhaps I had already exhausted all the options they would otherwise tell me to attempt. Instead they decided that a warranty replacement for the adapter was what they were going to do. Since I assumed that the adapter was the issue, and not the phone this seemed like a good solution. That is, until they found out I live in Canada. International mail is too difficult for them and they ceased communication and refused to help me in any capacity. So, be warned. Essential's products can be defective. If you have a problem and do not live in the US they will not help you. Imagine the frustration of being stuck with a broken device. Your money is better spent elsewhere. Fortunately Amazon was willing to offer me a credit, which is better than me having to pay to ship it back to them, or nothing.
reviews.review_header: Essential refuses to assist customers with defective items

reviews.review_text: I had to take it to Best Buy to get it situated because the guys at Sprint here locally are terrible. This is by far the best phone I have ever owned. I have been a previous Apple guy and after the passing of Steve Jobs, I have made the transition to Android/Windows. Prior to this, I had a Samsung S7 edge. I love the OS. I like that it is simple. People are constantly impressed by the sleekness of the phone. The updates have improved this phone tremendously compared to the reviews I read. I have no complaints except a couple which I will list below. Cons: Low call volume. I usually have to put people on the speaker to hear them well. Occasionally, the Bluetooth will disconnect in my car. However, that could correspond to my car and not anything else. Pros: The design is amazing and I constantly get people asking about it. It has a good weight in your hands. Speakers are crazy loud. The screen has great contrast. The performance is great. I had an iPhone user mention how great the camera was. I am not sure if that's any consolation since those were a lot of the launch issues.
reviews.review_header: Best Phone I have ever owned.

reviews.review_text: I love the phone the design is awesome and quality is top notch. it is very fast no bloatware, great memory, and awesome screen. no other phone comes close to the look and feel. Camara is good after software updates. I have it on T-mobile, the reviews have trashed this phone. And I can say it works on t-mobile. Pros: Desing, Fast, Memory, Updates Cons: Slippery, Fingerprint magnet, no headphone port
reviews.review_header: Great phone for the price - top specs processor , memory, screen, design.

reviews.review_text: I was eyeing the Essential phone ever since it was announced. Now, after the price drop, it's almost a no-brainer. If you look at the hardware specifications alone, you don't do this phone justice. Sure, there is no heart-rate monitor, no iris scanner, no wireless charging, not even a headphone jack. It's not an OLED display, there is no optical image stabilization (OIS), no telephoto or wide-angle lens. But there is also no Bixby button, no pre-installed proprietary calendar / app store / file browser bloatware, no screwing around with basic android functionality. Not unlike the Pixel, Nexus, and old Moto phones under Google's control, the Essential PH-1 is about user experience. The Essential PH-1 looks not as sleek as some other flagships, but somehow you want to pick it up and interact with it. Why? It is not annoying. Essential gets more stuff right, and - more importantly - less stuff wrong than other companies. Here is what I mean: SOFTWARE EXPERIENCE It's pure Android with basically no modifications (just optimizations). Why is that important? Just three random examples: - Unlike other flagship phones, the Essential PH-1 listens to "OK Google" even if the screen is off and the phone is not connected to a charger. - The Essential PH-1 implements Google's "Cast screen / audio" feature without modifications like strange overlay bubbles. It just works as intended. - When abroad, you see a small R next to you mobile data icon to indicate that you are on roaming. There are no annoying pop-up message every 30 minutes or anything like that. HARDWARE EXPERIENCE Unlike some other flagship phones, this one get's the essentials right. Like microphones and fingerprint scanner: - The Essential PH-1 uses four microphones for audio input and noise cancellation. Cover whatever part of the phone with your hand / car mount / charging dock and voice commands / hands free calls will still work. - The Essential PH-1 hat an extremely fast, easy to reach fingerprint scanner that works reliably even with swipe gestures turned on. BUILD QUALITY Just wow. This is no fragile all-glass phone. The Essential PH-1 is really slim but feels substantially heavier / rigid than other phones its size: - Unbreakable / unscratchable ceramic back. This is no coated plastic or painted glass. It's colored ceramics which is harder than steal. - Titanium frame (unpainted) with buttons made of the same material. Much stronger than standard aluminum or steel frames. The plastic antenna lines and the trim (that protects your screen) are colored (not painted) and thus won't loose their color from wear and tear. CAMERA Very basic, but constant software updates by Essential bring more and more functionality. A portrait mode (background blur) was recently introduced and it works very good. The rest of the camera app is very basic with virtually no settings and limited manual controls: - Good user experience (for example there are no integrated half-baked editor and gallery but links from the camera app to the excellent Google Photos app editor and gallery). It lacks features like panorama mode or something like the AI post-processing on Pixel phones, but you can install the Google camera app with full HDR+ compatibility. Unfortunately only the stock camera app can use the monochrome sensor for enhanced low-light shots. I attached to pictures that compare the camera quality between the stock and the Google camera app. (December 2017 software, Android 7.1.1) - I always loved the Google camera panorama and photo sphere modes. But taking those pictures takes a lot of time and you look quite funny doing it. Other phones try to imitate these features (sometimes with horrible results / bad stitching). Essential on the other hand offers a 360 camera extension that not only produces a perfectly stitched 6080x3040 sphere but can also record 360 degree videos and even live stream to YouTube and Facebook VR. But you have to pay extra for that 360 camera. SECURITY AND UPDATES The current stable software (as of Dec 10) is Android 7.1.1 with security patch level from December 2017. This is really impressive. Essential published the December security update at the very same day as Google did for their Pixel 2 phones. No other company did this. And everything looks extremely promising for future updates - The Essential PH-1 has an open Android 8.0 beta test with detailed instructions for manual installation, covered under warranty. Reports say that the software experience is further improved even in the beta version. - The Essential PH-1 will get hardware abstraction layers (HALs) for much easier and faster updates (Project Treble). While all phones that are released with Android 8 or newer are required to implement Treble, phones updated to Android 8 can choose if they want to support it. Essential is one of only three companies that confirmed Treble support. All the big players will not add support to old phones. Again: Project Treble will make it much easier for manufacturers (and custom roms) to release Android updates for phones. It looks like Essential wants to provide software updates for the PH-1 for a long time. (Essentials released a statement saying that initially some HALs are "Passthrough" to relase Android 8.0 as soon as possible, but that over time more and more HALs will be reworked to full "Binderized" HALs.) As you see, I am impressed by the commitment of Essential. It's not the perfect phone. But it's close. And it's an amazing value after the recent price drop. MY MAJOR COMPLAINTS - no Daydream compatibility (Google's VR goggles) due to the LCD screen (you can root the phone and activate support manually) - no full waterproofing, no headphone jack, no OIS (absolutely OK for the price you pay) WHY I AM IN LOVE WITH THIS PHONE - gorgeous screen (great black levels and punchy colors even though it's not OLED) - great user experience and latest software / extremely fast updates
reviews.review_header: Best User Experience! Visionary Phone with Amazing Value and Out-of-this-world Build Quality

reviews.review_text: Undoubtedly Essential Phone's design and build quality are top-notch. Their support is also good but unfortunately you don't get any actions besides them being (responsive and nice) with their international customers for obvious reasons of Limited Warranty. In a nutshell I can say that I can't recommend this phone to anyone because it just dies after a couple of weeks of using it, LITERALLY! At least that's what happened to my unit. (the pic attached showing the screen while it's ON) Here's my detailed experience if you're interested: It all started in mid-Jan when I got my brand new EP from Amazon. It was all okay with some hiccups every now and then, I knew that before getting it but I believed in Essential team's frequent updates. The most things that frustrated me were random shutdowns, most of apps are not (yet) compatible with the notch, the slow response of Google Assistant and the shutter lag of the camera (though quality of photos taken were very good). Anyway, in mid-March my phone couldn't turn on the screen. Did a restart, hard reset, power off/on but the device didn't seem to respond nor reviving the screen. Phone seemed to be dead, screen was only able to illuminates blacks when turned on. I was getting accurate vibration feedback form the fingerprint scanner (long vibration for registered fingers/ two short ones for other fingers) and from power off/on. Contacted Essential to see if I can get it repaired, I received a polite and fast reply that they can't due to my location outside the US. Now I got my phone returned thanks to Amazon Support's understanding.
reviews.review_header: Two stars for the design and build quality ONLY.

reviews.review_text: This is the best-designed, most beautiful phone ever. Someone spent a lot of time thinking about how to make people fall in love with a phone. The ceramic back is silky-smooth. That means no distracting textures when I hold it; but also that if you put the phone on a tilted surface, there is very little friction, and the phone will slide. The included USB-C charging cable has a braided cover and feels much tougher than normal charging cables. The camera is just fine. Yes, it could benefit from image stabilization and faster focus. Yes, there are better cameras and camera software; but media reports of poor quality are greatly exaggerated. After loading all the apps I could ever need, the phone still has 100 GB free for podcasts and taking pictures and video! The software experience (I'm on android 7.1.1) is very nice. No irrelevant advertising apps or pre-installed games. The ringtones and alarms offer a pleasant selection.

There have been many that are critical of this phone. Reviewers have slammed the camera and say they have experienced glitches. Maybe there were some issues when the phone was first released, but I can honestly say they have all been resolved. The physical phone itself is gorgeous and stands out among all the others. Operation is silky smooth and the screen is very clear with accurate colors. The camera produces very good photos, particularly in good light. There is no bloat and plenty of storage. If you are on the fence, don't hesitate. It's just as good as the other flagships without all the gimmicky fluff and at half the cost. Highly recommend!

Please, please don't believe those few negative reviews, I have to believe they are being paid to bad mouth the PH-1, this is truly a great phone, have had two ( my wife and I) for a month, not one freeze up, smooth and fast, very fast. Camera works very well in all the ways I've tried. Couldn't be happier, came from Lumia 950 and Lumia 950 XL.
reviews.review_header: I have to believe they are being paid to bad mouth the PH-1

reviews.review_text: I bought this phone as many on Cyber Monday deal. I LOVE IT. I had a Motorola X Pure Edition and was looking at the iPhone X or Google Pixel, this phone feels and works as good or better then my Motorola X. I love the design, there is not "junk" installed on the phone, great space at 128gb. Screen looks good, the front side camera does not bother me at all, I was worry a little about it but it just blends in after a little while and you don't even notice it. I'm very happy with the phone and my son its getting one for Xmas as well. With the deal on Cyber Monday I could not find another phone for me that would be better.
reviews.review_header: I LOVE IT. I had a Motorola X Pure Edition ...

reviews.review_text: Pros: 1) the phone is fast. 2) the camera, despite negative comments from others is better than my motto x camera. 3) the screen looks great. 4) battery life is sofar way better than any other phone I have had in recent years. (I usually stick around the $400 price range on my phones) 5) it's solid feeling. When I first picked it up, I noticed the weight. Cons 1) not many cases or screen protectors available. 2) it's big for small hands, but with this big of a screen I can't see how they could reduce the size much. I haven't tried the 360 camera yet, but will soon.
reviews.review_header: Snappy phone, good camera and great screen

reviews.review_text: I wanted this phone since it first came out. I think that it's a great price for the specs that it has and the build quality of the phone. It's so nice to hold as it just feels solid. Yes, it's slightly heavier than most phones it's size,, but I don't think that's a draw back. I really love the fact that I could easily put on a different version of Android, I'm looking at you Lineage, and even if I don't, I like the option. As for the camera. I'm coming from a Nextbit Robin, and I feel like the camera is just fine. The video at high resolution is just beautiful looking, but I don't really use the camera all that much. There is no audible click when you press the capture button, so I've found myself taking more than one of a picture not realizing that it's already been taken. The battery was one of the most important parts of the phone, I've not had a problem yet and end up between 30-40% at the end of the day if I don't charge it up. I'm not a heavy user so I don't know how it would be for someone who plays more games or is on social media more.
reviews.review_header: Well worth the price and great battery life

reviews.review_text: Excellent phone for 500$, price is now lower, have been using xiaomi phones for a while now mi5 mi3 which were best bang for your buck, was true until this phone lowered the price. Now I have to say the quality of this product is far superior than xiaomi in terms of build and quality screen, battery is ok, overall reminds me of nexus line of phones with a better build. Definitely would recommend

Hardware/build quality wise, this phone is second to none. The screen size and form factor are absolutely perfect, IMHO (not too big and not too small). The phone's chassis is made of super hard scratch resistant ceramic, and the phone is wrapped in a solid titanium frame. Everything about this phone screams quality except the software. I purchased this phone for my wife, but I ultimately had to return it to Amazon for a refund.
