Whether there's something wrong with the phone or not, I'm not 100% sure, but she literally couldn't make it a day without having to reboot or hard reset the phone 3+ times. The last straw was when the phone suddenly shut off in the middle of a medical emergency call. We struggled to get it to turn back on. Luckily, I had a backup phone in the drawer to switch over to. At first, I thought the phone was completely dead, but I finally managed to get it to power on long enough to do a factory reset. Back to Amazon it goes! Sorry Essential, this phone is just not ready for mainstream usage...
reviews.review_header: You'd think that the co-creator of the Android OS would have an edge on software and stability...

reviews.review_text: My daily driver is a beautiful Samsung Note 8 and I needed a second phone. I thought this phone was stunning and I was not let down. This phone is an absolute joy to use. Please don't hesitate to buy it. Let's support this amazing startup.
reviews.review_header: Gorgeous phone, better build quality than any iPhone that was ever made

reviews.review_text: I bought the Halo grey essential phone from Amazon and it's awesome. The entire phone feels solid being made from quality materials. The back, on this color, is a matte finish that does not show fingerprints. The screen is larger than my daughter's iPhone 7 plus but smaller overall. The camera seems to be an issue for some people but it works fine for me. I have no complaints.

This review is painful for me. I WANTED to love everything about this phone. With all the top-of-the line flagship phones coming out ever increasing in size, this was a breath of fresh air. The community was active and supportive. I've never felt a phone whose hardware design language immediately clicked with me better than this one. Unfortunately, the software was atrocious. Every day, the UI would slow down until it gradually locked up and required a hard reset at least twice. The signal reception was noticeably inferior to its peers and last-gen offerings. Ultimately, I returned this and bought a different phone. It was an emotionally trying experience, and I look forward to what Essential comes out with next.
reviews.review_header: Pure gold in the hand... When it works. Don't expect to make any calls.

reviews.review_text: I am really overall happy with my Essential phone after about a month of use. The Good: 1. Battery life has been amazing, better than any other phone I've owned. I easily get through a whole day. 2. Screen and hardware is nothing shore of gorgeous. 3. Feels good and fits in my pocket well. 4. Coming from a locked Verizon phone, it's amazing to have had three system updates since I've owned this. Security concerns are addressed quickly and the camera issuse are being addressed. 5. The camera is actually pretty darn good. I feel like the mono mode captures the photo better. 6. I got the version that came with the 360 camera which is really cool for photos in that it captures the whole environment. However, where this really shines is in videos. I captured everything while the whole family sung happy birthday to my mother on her 60th. It was pretty awesome. The Not So Good: 1. I have experienced some crashes. They aren't too frequent but I'm glad the updates keep coming. 2. I'd have though the 4k 360 camerar would capture more detail. 3. I hope they continue to improve the camera. I wish the color (as opposed to mono view) was more crisp. Overall, I'm quite pleased with this purchase. The Essential team is working hard to continue to improve the experience and I hope they keep at it. Buying this with the camera included and at around a 400 price point was kind of a no brainer and I've continued to be happy about the experience.
reviews.review_header: I am really overall happy with my Essential phone after about a month of ...

reviews.review_text: This is an awesome phone! I'm not gonna get into detail about the specs and all that, you can get those in the description or the other reviews. All I'm gonna say is it is well built and it has stock Android! I hope Essential keeps coming up with products, this is a great start for them, I think it is worth the initial $700 price tag but it is a steal at $500.

May be biased as it's my first Android after years of iPhones. My priorities are functionality and minimalism, and I feel the essential phone delivers. No real issues with the camera, although I don't demand much from phones. I've been using the Google hdr+ and native cameras with good results, and actually enjoying low light results. Anyway, working well for me after a couple weeks of ownership.

I bought this phone one week ago and updated to latest build. One think I didn't like about the phone was camera. It was grainy in low light. Also no portrait mode for front camera. I decided to return this phone and buy s9. Yesterday I saw a update for the camera app and upgraded it. I would say image quality is acceptable now. I liked their hard efforts to make it better by continued updates. So I decided to keep it. It's a good buy for 350$. An above average beautiful phone with great build quality
reviews.review_header: An above average beautiful phone with great build quality

reviews.review_text: This phone is probably one of the most underrated phones of 2017. I sell phones for a living so I have used everything from the S8, Note 8, iPhone X, and many more. There are many features packed into this powerhouse of a device. I love the simple Android experience I get with this phone. There is absolutely no bloatware you normally get with a phone that you get from a cell phone provider. I also love how the quality of the phone, I would go as far to say it is the best phone I have ever put in my hand. The device is very premium with the cermic back and titanium body. The phone does have some weight to it which I appreciate it feels solid and sturdy which is a plus. I don't want a phone I can feel like I can snap in half or a phone that will bend. This phone is currently running Android 7.1.1 with 8.0 in the works. I believe there is even a beta for it. The design is very modern and fits in with most flagships as a very minimal bezel is very in right now. The USB-C charging port is nice and up to date with other high end Android's. The USB-C is also a much more durable charging port vs the micro which end up wearing overtime due to prongs breaking or wearing out. The photo's from the camera are great quality. The snapdragon 835 is fast with plenty of ram on board it makes multi-tasking a breeze! I do appreciate the 128 GB of storage, it is more than enough for me. This phone is unlocked and works for any carrier which is a huge plus. It is a shame this phone isn't sold through my employer because I would sell this phone all day to customers. Why pay $700+ when you can get everything and more for half of the price!

Phone is incredible! Received mine in Halo Gray (Amazon exclusive). Common points on reviews seem to suggest the black and white models show fingerprints like crazy. Happy to report the gray option stays cleaner! Awaiting the 8.1 beta to be pushed to my device but I am also happy to report that on 7.1.1 I am seeing zero issues with screen lag or the commonly reported latency issues. Camera also seems to produce some truly spectacular photos with decent lighting. However, low light photos get very grainy and the stock app has some serious shutter delay although that is reported to be better with the 8.1 beta. All in all it is an incredible device with a very premium feel and lightning fast performance. No more iPhone for me. The screen is incredible with deep blacks and vibrant colors.
reviews.review_header: Common points on reviews seem to suggest the black and white models show fingerprints like crazy. Happy to report the gray option stays ...

reviews.review_text: I literally love this phone. It works great. Huge storage, easy to use. No extra garbage preinstalled that I don't want but can't get rid of,like most phones. Does everything I want, and does it well. And I have never noticed the camera not being good, I have seen that in reviews, but I think it is great. By far the best phone I have ever owned or used. So then why the three stars? I have had it 3 months, just dropped it 4 feet onto a memory foam bathmat and it cracked the screen.. They market it as being tough. Made of stronger materials than other phones. They don't sell cases. There appears to only be like one aftermarket case even available. I had a screen protector on it, thank god, because otherwise my bathroom floor would be covered in little pieces of broken glass. And apparently it is pretty hard to get repairs or replacement parts, so wooo. Haven't had the opportunity to see yet, since this just happened, but so far I haven't found much info on places where I could get a screen. So I am not even sure if that's fixable. Didn't bother with warranty since I am not really a heavy phone user, I need the large harddrive for music and audio lessons, but my phone spends 90% of it's time safely in my pocket and I am only 5 feet tall anyways so how far am I really going to drop it, lol. The glass is rated to fall from my height without cracking
reviews.review_header: Great phone, buy the case and warranty because it is just as breakable as all the rest

reviews.review_text: Great phone, has a nice premium feel to it and the company seems to be regularly providing updates and addressing issues with the phone. When the phone first came out there were some software glitches although I personally haven't had too many issues with it and use the phone on a daily basis.The price was definitely right too, I think right now this phone is well priced at $400-450.
reviews.review_header: Great phone, has a nice premium feel to it ...

reviews.review_text: This phone has the best quality and hardware I have ever used in a phone and I like it much better than the iPhone 10. However the software is very unpolished and unpredictable. I used this phone on Verizon for 3 short days almost immediately I had problems getting service. Then it finally gave up and said "No Service" a brief restart would fix this then it started happening all the time before I knew it I was restarting my phone 5+ times a day that's absolutely unacceptable. Then when it did get service it wouldn't let me text or call. And the worst part about the whole thing is Essential knew about this issue over 5 months ago. And says "We will be rolling out an update to fix this soon" I can't wait another year to get my phone to actually be a phone. Steer clear if you're using it on Verizon.

I really wanted to like this phone. It's got a solid feel to it, and looks really good. The screen is nice and bright. I liked how there is very little bezel around it, and the screen is all you really see. The phone is fast at processing and transitioning from one thing to the next. The battery life on the phone is incredible and I would get about a day and a half of use from it before needing to be charged. But I think that's about all the positives I can think of. So the major construction of the phone is titanium and ceramic. However, there is still a plastic bezel around the glass screen, and for whatever reason, a small portion of the plastic bezel broke. I cannot figure out why that little piece broke either. I did not drop the phone and it's only been in and out of my pocket or sitting on my desk at work. When making a phone call the earpiece is built into the very top of the phone, and if you didn't get it just right to your ear, you could barely hear the conversation. Plus the top of the phone is a little sharp, and trying to find the right spot on your ear can be ever so slightly painful as it scrapes your ear. While using the speaker phone, the speaker had a slight vibration to it that you could hear at certain times. I heard it often enough that it bothered me. The screen is marketed as a "full screen" which it is when you are just looking at the home screen, but as soon as you go into any app or webpage, the only visible part of screen is below the front facing camera, so your actual usable screen is smaller and not "full screen". The reception also seems to be really bad. I would drop calls, or have to walk outside my office to get any kind of reception. I switched phones, and the reception is much better now. I have returned this phone, and I hope that in the future it gets better, I may try it again. But for now, I picked up a Huawei Mate 9, and for the short time I have had it, I like that much more. But I will do a separate review for that later.
reviews.review_header: Good phone with some flaws. Wait for a second version.

reviews.review_text: Overall, it's a great phone that just needs a couple of things fixed. Major problem is the call log. Every single call is being displayed as missed call. Now, I don't know what's the issue behind that, but I had a replacement sent to me, after receiving the first one with the same problem. Please, address this issue, as it is really annoying. I found a way to work around that, just using a different Phone App from Play Store, but others may not be this chill about the issue. So far, that's about it. If battery life is something that matters for you the most regarding cell phones, this is a great option. I left home today around 7 am, now it's 8 pm, and the battery is still at 48%, which is really really good. Also, this phone is very fast. Camera is OK, haven't played with it a lot, but as a former nexus 6p user, I can say 6P is definitely better. Overall, this is a B+ phone. Considering this is their first model, not bad. Please, do something about the call log.

I owned it for 60 days. I just returned the phone. It was freezing requiring reboot, sometimes while browsing safe websites, sometimes for other reasons. The camera would lock up causing reboot (and missing the photo opportunity). Trying to reject a phone call rarely worked; the phone would just keep ringing. Dismissing alarms took 3 or 5 button presses instead of dismissing on the first press. I did not have a screen protector on the phone. I temporarily threw my SIM into an old backup phone and returned the PH-1. I'm on TMobile, which has never been a problem.

Using for two weeks now and loving it. Spouse has had 2 different iPhones and 2 different Samsung's and using them has kept me from smartphone desire. I finally broke down and soooooo glad I got this one without all the junk. I used to tease spouse because had to charge smartphones all the time and my flip would go a whole week. I haven't tried to wait a week, but only have charged every three days. And talk about fast charging!!! Good size too - who wants to carry a tablet in their pocket? Not me!

I don't normally leave reviews, but after reading all of the negative feedback on other sites and from older reviews, I felt compelled to leave this. First off, don't put any stock in any review posted before November, Essential was such a new company, with no existing products, they had to have some bugs when it was first launched. However, since then they have been rolling out software updates to EvErYtHiNg. The other day I got an update for my headphone dongle. The bugs have been all but entirely eradicated and the camera has improved drastically, I have no problem with the camera app right now, it is not perfect, but it takes good pictures reliably. The feel of this phone is like no other phone, it is solid and quality feeling, it reminds me of an iPhone 4 (in a good way). I hate to hold other phones now, they all just feel cheap (pft, aluminium frame). The headphone jack is missing, but the dongle is quality and easy to just leave on your headphones, plus it has a decent DAC, better than would have been in the phone, and the battery and flat architecture are more than worth it. I absolutely recommend this phone to anyone who has a little bit of technical ability (see: following googled directions).
reviews.review_header: it is not perfect, but it takes good pictures reliably

reviews.review_text: The phone is great. The camera setup may also be really good, but the camera app leaves much to be desired. Ultimately you have to work a bit to get clean shots. I knew this from reviews already. The camera is important, but not my highest priority. I assume that it will be improved. So far this company has been kicking out updates at an impressive rate. Let's see how long they will keep that up before the focus changes. Support is great based on the attention to fixes and updates. I recommend it.
reviews.review_header: It's a solid phone, if camera is not your most important feature.

reviews.review_text: I will only list the things bother me the most. Otherwise, it is good looking and the performance is somewhat solid. 1. The density of the phone. The phone looks great and feels luxury in hand. However, the small size + heavy material makes the phone extremely dense. While it won't bother most people, it is definetely not for small hands. 2. The camera is not quite impressive. The stock software is definitely not working correctly even with the update. I installed the google zsl hdr+ package and compared so many shots. The google software outperform the stock software 90% of the time. Especially in low light, the noise is much better processed. And the color dynamic range is better with google camera hdr+. Also it focus better with google hdr+. However, sometimes when rotation while using the google app, the screen flashes and sometimes freezes. Therefore, this leaves me no good solution for photography. 3. Not sure if it is just mine. The front camera does not produce sharp image. The exposure won't adjust no matter how I touch different point on the screen. 4. There are some coating imperfection between the screen and frame. Once you notice it, you keep seeing it all the time. This should not happen to a 500 dollar phone.
reviews.review_header: Not for small hands and the camera software is still bad

reviews.review_text: I’m a phone fanatic and there’s a lot to like about the PH-1. Unfortunately, the one thing that I dislike is also the dealbreaker for me and that’s the camera. It’s bad. You will find people who claim it has improved (which is technically true) but that doesn’t mean it still isn’t bad - because it is. Battery life was good considering the battery/screen size. Heck, I even liked the cutout up top giving that full screen look. If picture quality doesn’t matter then go ahead and buy this. If it does, stay away!

Overall I hate this phone. It's a waste of money. As someone who changes smartphones yearly I can same with certainty this is the worst purchase. Looking pretty is all it has going for it. Pros: Looks nice Large screen Cons: Touch screen is inaccurate Touch screen is unresponsive some times The touch screen tech they use is visible at certain angles Screen scratches easily, never had so many small scratches on a screen before Phone is slow, takes long to load apps No wireless charging No memory card Fingerprint reader is finicky and takes multiple attempts Overall a huge downgrade from my LG G6. Only gets two stars because it looks nice.

Beautiful phone. The weight and finish are splendid, and the size, even compared to my Pixel 2 XL, does not leave me wanting. The 360° camera attachment is quite fun, too: full-motion 360° video capture. It does show fingerprints very well, thanks to the mirror finish. If only it worked on Project Fi, it would definitely be my primary phone, but that lack isn't the phone's fault.

Looking for an alternative in the Android phone market I thought the Essential would be a great option. The look and feel was spot on! But then I turned it on. I must have have gotten a bad one but didn't have time to play the exchange game. The screen would randomly freeze and the only way to get it back was to hit the power button and wake it back up. Then I had random times when it acted like something was touching the screen when nothing was near it. I tried a factory restore and made sure all recent updates were installed. I believe this was a hardware issue that didn't get caught in QC by the manufacture. Back to my trusty MotoZ Force.
reviews.review_header: Great Look & Feel.....Operation Not So Much.

reviews.review_text: I really wanted to love this phone, but at this point I only like it. First off I think I got a great deal. The Essential phone is priced about right now on Amazon and the 360 camera thrown in for an extra $50 is great. My biggest complaint is lack if signal strength. I work part-time for Uber and Lyft and have a terrible time now. In neighborhoods where I usually would have full bars I'll just randomly lose signal and it completely screws with the apps I've got running. Suddenly someone is in my car and I can't even navigate to where they're going because the signal is suddenly gone. I never once had this happen with my old S7 edge. On the positive I adore how simple this phone is. No bloatware, super clean design. Great battery life. Decent camera after they pushed out some updates. If they could somehow clean up the reception/signal strength I would give it 4 stars. If u are not a power user like I am (using it for work in your car constantly) like I am, I think most people would really enjoy this phone.
reviews.review_header: Good phone with some room for improvement

reviews.review_text: When this phone was first released, it was a pretty poor value proposition. At $699 the price was just too high for a phone with buggy software and a very poor camera app. But fast forward a few months, and the price has dropped to $499 (sometimes even less) and the updates have made it pretty solid. And the camera is now one of the very best out there. It's a beautiful thing ... ceramic and titanium. But don't be tempted to go without a case. That may come back to bite you. But there are many very high quality cases out there for the PH-1. It's a great phone. Updates are frequent. And it appears that Android 8.1 may be rolling out in March. It's now a beautiful thing ... for $499 ;-)
reviews.review_header: With new software and a new price, the PH-1 is now a really good deal for a great phone

reviews.review_text: I bought this because I love stock Android and the mission statement of Essential Products resonated with me (simplicity, no branding, stock Android, no bloatware). *Hardware* Pros: Sleek, good specs, unbranded Cons: Bad camera, power button on the side is too hard to press, unlock speed is slow compared to even cheaper phones, battery life isn't amazing *Software* Pros: Stock Android, smooth and fast Cons: None (maybe camera software) Overall, it's good for a first phone but has many areas which need work. Definitely wasn't worth the $700 price tag, but at $500 it isn't terrible. Not as good and smooth as an iPhone 7 or later, and I'm guessing not as good and smooth as a Pixel 2, but if you support their mission statement especially, it really isn't too bad for $500. Hopefully they will polish it a bit for the next release (if there is one).
reviews.review_header: Good phone overall, but definitely not at the level of an iPhone or a Pixel yet. Hopefully next model will be better!

reviews.review_text: I replaced my Nexus 5X with this Essential Phone after the price drop. It has great specs including the generous 128 Gig of memory. I agree with the reviewers wishing for a better camera and application. I side-loaded a port of the Google Camera to give more adjustability i.e. photo aspect ratio. This improved it to a notch above my old camera. Some reviews were negative on the stability of Android on the Essential Phone. My experience after installing and testing all the apps I was using on my old phone is that it is as stable the Nexus 5X. I didn't experience any problems before or after the phone completed Android and Security updates. I did have to live with reverting from Oreo to 7.1.1, but the differences are minor and an update is likely soon for non-Google devices like this. I tried to like a Samsung phone, but couldn't deal with the re-skinning of Android and limitations on which apps could be removed/replaced. I've used unlocked Google phones for a few years and didn't like having everything be different but not necessarily better. Overall, I'm pleased with this phone as a replacement for Nexus 5X. I was able to score an open-box item from Amazon bringing the cost below $390. What other similar phone can you buy with the features for that price? One extra feature of the phone that was important to me was being able to connect an HDMI cable to mirror the phone screen to a TV while camping in an RV. Other options like Chrome Cast and Fire TV don't work without high speed internet. Miracast is hobbled by copyright protections preventing casting Netflix and similar content. See the "Inspira Type C Hub" for connecting to a TV via HDMI.
reviews.review_header: A great replacement for Google Nexus phones with high-end specs at a mid-range price

reviews.review_text: This is hands down the most beautiful phone I have ever held. The design is so unique. Seeing this phone at $499 instead of the initial launch price of $699 was a no-brainer deal for me! For the first day of use, this phone was wonderful. Camera was great after updating the app (like, really great - on par with most 2017 flagships) and I was blown away by the edge to edge screen. After one day, however, the phone began to freeze suddenly while switching apps or turning off WiFi. I read that this is a common issue that people face but is often alleviated with an exchange. I am awaiting my exchange and hoping that the new phone is better. I really want to like this phone, but if the bad performance is a consistent problem I will have to look elsewhere and await a future generation of this phone. I can imagine it's very difficult to assure quality for a company as new as essential.
reviews.review_header: Suddenly freezes and becomes unresponsive. Defective unit?

reviews.review_text: Amazing amazing cell phone. I've always have Android based cell phones in the past so I can't vouch for how easy the switch was, but the phone itself is incredible. Looks and feels expensive, but didn't break the bank to get. Takes incredible pictures, massive screen, incredible customer service. The only real and true downside is it's just slippery. The ceramic back will slide when I lay my phone on a pad of sticky notes on the desk and slide until it lays flat or slips more in my hand if they're dry. Can stand real and true to the corner drop test but if dropped just right will shatter the screen. A skin or case will solve this, but be aware if you'd rather have it bare.

This is the best phone I have ever owned after leaving the Samsung Flag Ship market it is a relief to finally have a phone that is not trying to reinvent Android. I have had 0 problems with this phone other than sim connectivity one day but i narrowed that down to carrier issues not the phone. If you like android and want a pure android experience and are also looking for a powerful phone look no further this is an awesome phone.
reviews.review_header: This is the best phone I have ever owned after leaving the Samsung ...

reviews.review_text: It`s a pretty solid device all around. Build and display really pushes this thing to the next level. It's so different, that people have stopped me to ask what phone it was. I'm on Oreo 8.1 Beta 1 and I haven't really seen the problems that others have talked about yet. I'm coming from a 6P, so I'm missing the stereo speakers, but the PH-1 gets pretty loud without getting tinny on the higher end, which is pretty nice. Battery is great: +6 hours SOT! Personally, I find the camera more than serviceable. Essential's own app is great for Mono photos, but I threw a Google Camera port onto it, and the pictures come out as good as the 6P easily. That's no question. Essential's own stock app is much better than it was before. It's not the hardware that's buggered up, it's the software; the hardware is pretty good. I don't think I"ll be returning this phone. If you like the design, go for it. I think you'll be pleasantly surprised. This phone outperforms everything in its price range; it's a flagship phone with midrange price; can't really go wrong!

Great phone! I love the pure Android experience that Andy Rubin has completely captured with this phone. It's stripped down to bare bones so you can truly make it your own by installing whatever app or launcher you like. It's fast, it's super sturdy, and it's gorgeous. The camera is just fine (now) and I've had many updates to make the phone even better. The bad rap that this phone received right after its' launch is totally unwarranted now.

I don't know why this got bad reviews initially. My only guess is that the software at the time wasn't running well. I got 2 of these phones from the cyber monday deal for $400 each for my kids. The specs by itself make that an amazing deal. I mean you get the top of the line CPU/GPU Snapdragon 835, 4GB of ram, 128GB of internal storage and a beautiful screen that almost covers the entire front of the phone. Those are not specs you will find for $400 anywhere. The software is pure stock android and it has not once crashed, slowed down, hiccuped, or has done anything strange. It has not behaved in any way some of the reviews would like you to believe. I also run this on T-mobile and the signal strength in db is identical to my S8+. The voice call is clear and has never dropped. The camera. Let me preface by saying I am not a camera guru so this is purely based on my family's and my feedback. We use auto for 95% of all of our picture taking, even me on my S8+. For these use cases, the quality and speed of the pictures for the Essential phone is great. Be it outdoors or indoors, lots of light or low light, it has all performed well. There aren't nearly as many camera options on the Essential phone compared to the S8+ but I find myself hardly using them anyways. Now the video is interesting. The quality is good but without image stabilizer, I can tell the video is more shaky especially when shooting while walking around. That would be my only negative only because I've grown so used to the stability of S8+ video. All in all, this was an amazing purchase at an amazing price and my kids love it and it will be their phone for a long long time.

Excellent phone. Works with Verizon. The store rep could not help. I had to call 611 from Verizon phone and talk to technical support person (not general customer service) to get the phone working. Ask them to turn on HD voice calling from their end so you can start making nf receiving phone calls. No problems with camera or 360 degree camera. Fabulous device. I was initially sceptical reading bad reviews about camera but I did not have any problems.
reviews.review_header: Works with Verizon... Excellent device ...No camera issues

reviews.review_text: Great phone .. works perfectly ..setup was fast .. but you have to update the OS to Oreo ( Android 8.1 ) because Essential fixed a lot of bugs and issues with that update .. If you are planning to buy this phone read the latest reviews ( after update ) ... 2018 reviews only .... Even if there were a few issues they are fixed now .... And Oreo looks way better ...you will see ..

This is a great phone. The setup/transfer from my old Samsung was painless. It has tons of storage (128GBs), and no unwanted programs. Battery life is fantastic. I have gone 48 hours without recharging. I miss the headphone jack, but it comes with an adapter, so no big deal. It is built very solidly, and has a great feel to it. The camera works fine for me. The Essential phone is also very quick. Whatever the task, it's fast. The OS was just updated and it took about 5 minutes. If you want a fantastic phone for less than $500, this is the one.
reviews.review_header: Essentially, this is a great phone!

reviews.review_text: I love this phone; it's beautiful, I love the feel in my hand, and the performance is fantastic. Good battery life too. At the new reduced price it's an amazing value. Don't believe the bad reviews of the camera - once you update the software it's perfectly adequate for just about anything you're likely to attempt. The only real downside is lack of waterproofness. (The Oreo beta is great, by the way - very stable and works great on this phone).

phone is nice if you never drop it. I've had this phone for nearly 2 weeks and it's already got a huge crack in it. Don't listen to them when they say it's nearly indestructible. Turns out it's very fragile. BUY A PHONE CASE if you get this phone and save yourself some heartache.
reviews.review_header: phone is nice if you never drop it

reviews.review_text: I was looking for a new phone to replace my aging Sony Xperia Z3 Compact. My requirements were: 1. Flagship level CPU. 2. At least 4 GB RAM. 3. At least 64 GB of storage + expandable storage or 128 GB without expandable storage. 4. Good screen for reading books on the go. 5. Reasonable price. 6. Design This phone ticked all the boxes: 1. It has snapdragon 835 CPU, the best you can get at the time of writing this review. 2+3. The phone comes with 4GB RAM and 128 GB of storage. 4. I'm in love with the screen! This phone comes with excellent QHD screen with 16:10 aspect ratio. 16:10 aspect ratio makes the screen perfect for a casual ebook reading. 5. I got this phone for 435$ + taxes and shipping. I could not see why to pay 700+ for a phone like S8. Mainly because camera wasn't a priority for me. 6. Easily phone of the year in terms of design.
reviews.review_header: Excellent QHD screen with 16:10 aspect ratio. Stock Android. Winning design and build quality.

reviews.review_text: Fantastic phone. Probably the most exciting phone period. I was always a huge iOS fan but this phone has made me change my mind. Such a beautifuly crafted device and what's a powerful device too. I will highly recommend this product to anyone even to those people that are hesitant to switch from iOS. No skin Android. One of the best things ever. Kudos Andre Rubin. Can't wait to seewhat this company has to offer in the future.

Just a really awesome , super solid phone. No extra bloatware. Just clean Android that works. Love how the phone is completely flat on both sides. Very durable. Dropped it 3 1/2 ft onto hard tile and the only thing that happened was a tiny scratch on the screen. The ceramic back seems very durable but it is slippery. Overall, I am very happy with the phone. The white is not a fingerprint magnet.
reviews.review_header: Just a really awesome, super solid phone

reviews.review_text: Great phone - great price. Many issues mentioned by previous reviewers should have disappeared after the latest Android 8.1 (!) update. Smooth software performance, camera not top, but ok. No problems to operate phone in European networks. Older topics as the repair / battery change issue of course remain. Fast and easy delivery o Europe by Amazon!

My wife bought this phone for me a few weeks back. I don't know that I would have felt good about paying $700 for it but at $449 this is one amazing phone. Its built like a tank, it looks beautiful and its fast as heck. I like leaving it on the table and having people ask if its an iphone x. Then I tell them its better. The stock camera ap is not so hot. I use open camera instead and have no issues. I think they look as good as anything from Apple and almost as good as my wifes pixel. I have been lucky and not run across any of the other issues I have seen posted.
reviews.review_header: I don't know that I would have felt good about paying $700 for it but at $449 this ...

reviews.review_text: I've had several generations of iPhones and Galaxy S series, Motorola and HTC's. I love this phone for its solid craftsmanship and premium design. I love that is has a pure Android OS and open Bootloader makes this phone virtually limitless. The team at Essential has been great at pushing out monthly security updates as soon as they become available. The only shortcomings of this phone are the camera (software) and the IP rating. If there is a second generation of the essential phone I would love to see them address both of these issues.

I switched from an old iPhone 5s, and wow, this phone is great. The screen size and display is perfect for me. I love the ease of use that Android has. Everything has been running great and was very easy to set up. It's tough to beat this phone for quality vs price. There's no way I wanted to pay for the latest "flagship" phone, so this fit my needs perfectly. Incredible phone for the price.
reviews.review_header: Sick of running out of storage with old iphone so this upgrade was necessary for me.

reviews.review_text: Speedy phone, questionable materials. I've owned this less that 1 month. Some examples: Selecting items on the screen that trigger an audible "click" sound more like a crackle. The screen, which should be Gorilla Glass 5, already has micro scratches from putting it in and out of jeans pocket. I've not had this problem with older GG versions or even competitor Asahi Dragontrail glass screens (price drop maybe swapped out to lower quality materials?). It's not a bad phone, and works, but don't expect super premium materials performance like in the spec list. Get a screen protector ASAP!!
reviews.review_header: Speedy phone, questionable materials, screen scratches

reviews.review_text: So much room for improvement! Snagged this for $450 from amazon.com making this phone a great value. If it wasn't for a few software shortcomings with the camera and general snappiness during the early days of having this device, I would have given it a full five stars. The first week i owned this, I had to install at least three updates which seemed to have fixed a few things I saw. Scrolling issue isn't as noticeable as others have mentioned. Build, battery life, and screen are top notch. Touch responsiveness and camera post processing need a little bit of work. This phone is already very ahead of the competition in terms of OS updates.
reviews.review_header: awesome value, prompt updates, lacking software enhancements for camera and general stability

reviews.review_text: Have been using for about a month now. Great phone. I had a setup problem initially, doing the google copy of my old phone caused a boot loop. Must have been some app that didn't' agree with the new phone. Had to factory reset and then just install the apps that I wanted. Has worked great every since. So far Essential has kept up well on monthly updates and that is what I was looking for.
reviews.review_header: Great phone. I had a setup problem initially

reviews.review_text: This phone just looks and feels incredible. Solid, with some heft, no plastic, just ceramic, glass, and titanium. And NO bloatware and nothing on the phone you don't want! It took me a while to work my way through the setup so that it works the way I want, and I am still exploring the menus to learn more. I am not a heavy phone user, but compared to my LG G4 which this replaces and required being on a charger every night, so far I have gone more than two days without a charge and it still has 70% battery life! More documentation online would be helpful, and online and phone support are yet to come. However my interaction with support through email has been very positive and helpful, and I have not yet had a need for instant support. One small negative, there are very few cases currently available, and literally only one I thought was classy enough for this phone. And no memory expansion - I haven't transferred my photos from my previous phone to this one just because I don't want to lose too much memory. So we'll see if the internal memory - which is quite large fortunately - will be sufficient. I hope this company succeeds because this phone is a beautiful piece of hardware and seems to work really well.
reviews.review_header: Unlike anything else on the market

reviews.review_text: Seriously this phone has been a pleasant surprise. Dispite reviews that claim various issues, I have been very pleased with this phone. My main criteria for a good phone is user experience. This phone is bare bones and to the point. No duplicate apps, no wow features that clutter up the phones function. This phone is smooth and fast. The build quality is next to none. The size of the screen is 5.7", bigger than the iPhone plus modelsvin a much smaller package. This is essentials first phone and if they keep it up, it will have e a real winner on their hands and will compete with his the big boys. The only gripe is the Camara performance and I recommend downloading the Google Camara app apk. I encourage anyone who just wants a fast smooth straight forward phone not to hesitate.

Awesome phone. Works with Verizon and you need to go get a nano SIM card which is free. Loving this phone a month in and it is the best phone I have ever owned. 128 gb is and the speed is impressive. Google AI is incredibly fast. It is clean and the picture is good. The draw back is the camera is not as good as the pixel and s8. Overall I would still recommend this phone to Verizon customers as a FAR more affordable option at $450.
reviews.review_header: Awesome phone. Works with Verizon and you need to ...

reviews.review_text: Excellent screen while it does have a slight glow on black background. I do appreciate the edge to edge screen. The resolution and size are big pluses. The phone feels like it weighs a lot - it's kind of deceiving. It may be partly due to the weight for its overall size. Camera is a little slower and lower quality than expected. Device is not waterproof. Essential did miss a few things. Overall, however, I am happy for $399. It is unlocked which allows me to use on T-Mobile. g00ber
reviews.review_header: Very nice edge to edge screen

reviews.review_text: This Phone is beautiful, handles well and takes good enough pictures for me. Call quality is good, and have had no complaints from people on the other end about how i sound. My only negative of this phone is that it could not survive a bad accident like they claim. I had my phone on my notebook and due to the slippery body (which I love!), slipped off and cracked the screen. First time i have ever broken a screen, and it was on a phone i figured could handle a little roughness. Still would recommend the phone to anyone looking to buy a new phone.
reviews.review_header: Beautiful, but not as strong as its being billed.

reviews.review_text: Update 3 weeks in. It is absolutely brilliant, no other words for it. Earlier review: I really can't understand all the negative reviews of the phone - mostly pointed at the camera function. I upgraded to the Essential phone from a Samsung Note 3 which I have owned for the last 4 years. You have to understand that my upgrade to this phone is like trading a Beetle for a Rolls Royce. This phone is light years ahead of what I have been used to. I am completely satisfied with this phone. The build quality of course is stunning but the experience of the functionality is fantastic. The camera is great, no complaints. My Note 3 would take about 5 minutes to load the camera (slight exageration) but seems like it. This thing rocks and don't let anyone influence you otherwise.
reviews.review_header: You have to understand that my upgrade to this phone is like trading a Beetle for a Rolls Royce

reviews.review_text: Very solidly built (read: nice and hefty, but not too much). Roughly the same size of an iPhone 6s, but it gives a larger screen. Love their take on "the notch" over what Apple did on their X. Everything is very responsive. Essential keeps updating the software, and an Oreo beta is already available. Loved the "bare bones" applications it comes with out of the box - basically just the core Google apps and nothing else (not even Android Pay), so you don't have to worry about bloat.

I really like this phone. Was eyeing it since it was announced, but price was way too high for a first generation product from a new company--despite Andy Rubin's involvement. Waited for Cyber Monday $399. deal with 360 camera. Updates have really made this a solid choice for enthusiasts who want a beautiful piece of hardware, with improving software, and a reasonable price!
reviews.review_header: Great bargain when bought on Cyber Monday for $399 with 360 degree camera. Happy to see it getting better every couple of weeks

reviews.review_text: I was weary about this phone with the reviews. However upon using the phone, I've realized most of those bad or lukewarm reviews were largely bandwagon sentiments. The phone is fast, very attractive, and premium feeling. The camera is good, but it's pretty great if you sideload the Google Pixel camera. The only reason for 4 stars instead of 5 is that the signal does seem weaker than my Moto X, at least when in low signal areas. If they could fix that in an update, it'd be an easy 5 stars. This is basically an iPhone X at half the price with a better UX.
reviews.review_header: iPhone X-like device at half the cost.

reviews.review_text: My Essential phone has met (or exceeded) all my expectations. Very good build quality, feels good in my hand and looks great. It's a very fast phone. No more waiting for pages to load. Easy to become familiar with. Felt comfortable with operation and features within a couple days. I love the full screen and this phone fits nicely in my pocket. But be careful, because the phone is very slippery. I hated to cover the beautiful back but I bought a cover to keep it from sliding away or falling out of my pocket. Absolutely pleased with my purchase.

Got it $241 after the 20% coupon. It's amazing and I'm wondering if I should sell my Pixel 2 XL...it's that good. Camera is 7/10, everything else is nearly perfect. It's a keeper no matter what - timeless design and bullet proof construction. Added a $35 360 cam for fun. Great deals to be had and worth every penny.
reviews.review_header: It's amazing and I'm wondering if I should sell my Pixel ...

reviews.review_text: Simply put, this phone is amazing. I've had this phone for just 3 days and it's been an absolute joy using it. There is no bloatware or branding on it but does include critical google apps. Great app switching and performance. I love the fact that it comes standard with 128 GB of space (though with formatting it's a bit less). It feels and handles like a luxury phone with exceptional screen resolution and vibrant colors. All around fantastic phone that is an android purists best friend. Pros: Sturdy feel (but not too heavy) Strong Performance Professional look Cons: No integrated 3.5 mm headphone jack (I don't see this as a big issue as they do include a USB-C to 3.5 mm converter that you can use) No integrated Visual Voicemail app (I believe that this is an issue with many unlocked devices though) How I use the device: I'm a big google services user who uses Straight Talk as a carrier. I stream video regularly and play several graphic intense games. I'm a heavy browser user who regularly uses multiple tabs. Bottom Line: If you don't like branding and bloatware but still want a great phone, this is your device. I wish I would have found this phone earlier.

I really wanted to like this phone but it was extremely unstable. It would randomly reboot and lock up every day I had it and would freeze at simple tasks like surfing the internet. The design was beautiful but the software was sub par.
reviews.review_header: Bad software experience, nice looking phone.

reviews.review_text: I'm really like this phone. My friends and family always say how beautiful it is. In most ways it performs like $1000 phones. Occasionally, the phone does have some glitches but the developers are regularly putting out updates to improve performance. The camera is good. If you take alot of pictures and high-quality is important, choose something else. Overall super happy with this phone.
reviews.review_header: A high end phone at a reasonable price!

reviews.review_text: The Essential Phone makes me… happy!?! Yeah, I know weird.. happy about a new phone is an odd way of putting it. Maybe, it just feels good and makes me smile. I have the awesome opportunity to trial tons of new handsets from utilitarian to flagship and yet somehow this Essential Phone with LESS tricks and gimmicks is my current favorite over all. It’s hard to put a finger on exactly what it is (no pun intended). I don’t know any other way to put it.. the haptic feedback on the Essential phone is.. delicious. No, you can't change the vibration intensity (yet), but I don't want to. It just has the perfect feel. I think part of the feedback feel is due to the solid body design with the titanium and ceramic. Running a finger across the screen feels SO nice. It’s the nicest touch screen I’ve run my finger across to be honest… so smooth. My finger literally glides across the surface. I don’t use screen protectors any more. Just too much hassle and often times reduced responsiveness. So, with no screen protectors I can say when comparing this to say my S8+, the glass is just less 'tacky'. Swype typing on the Essential PH-1 is a pleasure and I find it to be much more accurate than on any handset I’ve used thus far. That's pretty impressive. Snappy! OK, so I only just got this thing and barely loaded it up with Apps. I wanted a clean start – and what that means is a clean phone. Essential, not just a clever name… only comes with 21 ‘essential’ apps pre installed. 20 really, but with the version from Sprint you also get the Sprint account manager (My Sprint) which is the only carrier app on the device to track usage, pay bills etc. It's nice to be able to load what I want and it I like not having to go in to setting to shut off notifications from OEM and carrier bloat. What else? A clean android experience. I’ve never used a Pixel/Nexus, so I had no clue what ‘stock’ android was really supposed to be. Now I do. It’s fast – blazing fast. Opening up the menu pull down from the top of the device is quick and not loaded with a trillion customization options. Sliding up from the bottom brings up the app tray snappy and fast too. I know, nowadays people love all the additional options, but that isn’t what this device is really about. For example, my S8+ has 23 system options from the top pull down whereas the essential has 10 by default, and you know what? I really don’t need more than that. Other options are still available in the settings menu for example the ability to turn on/off NFC, though anyone that uses NFC would probably argue they keep this on most of the time and not need to shut it off in a hurry. Which by the way, if all that customization is important you can always go with a ‘launcher’ from the Play store rather than one that’s forced upon you by a device manufacturer. I’m just starting to understand that now. On the one hand you have the major custom ROMs by device manufactures and on the other (Nexus) a completely unblemished version of Android. Then there’s the Essential which leans more towards stock, but adds just the right amount of personalization to make you feel like it’s a unique experience. I do agree at times it’s nice to have some of the manufacturer specific options and things we’re used to seeing (like Touchwiz/Saumsung Experience). I just hadn’t realized what I gave up in Android responsiveness in order to have the manufacturer specific Android mods. I may have to test it out with a launcher at some stage just to see if it functions as fast as it feels now. The default ringtone is nice and not obnoxious and I like the new unobtrusive text tone too. It’s all google messaging with the latest version as well as google keyboard and ability to text with GIF’s etc. My favorite feature so far? Home Screen Rotation! I haven’t seen a handset where the home screen turns! Almost all handsets don’t rotate the actual home screen, only the apps. I love the way the phone looks in landscape. The screen and colors are beautiful too. Granted I find it to be just slightly less bright than say the GS8+, but the colors seem to be more ‘authentic’ and realistic. By the way, for those reading… I think the S8 is an amazing device and I’m not knocking it in any way. Really, up until now I’ve been touting it as the best phone I’ve ever used. We’ll see how I feel about the Essential in the coming weeks to see if the ‘new car smell’ so to speak wears off and if I’m back to my love affair with the S8. The screen looks awesome when on a call. Simple, clean and bright. Personally I like the camera at the top of the screen, rather than an unusable bar taking up part of he screen. Looks great with websites too. Haven't done video yet... Additional things – Activation was a breeze on Sprint.com with exception of one additional step. After activating the device I needed to go to the dial pad and enter *#*#72786#*#* in order to have the device reset with the network (took a min) and it downloaded a new MR to the latest software version.Not a bad idea to do that upon activation for those reading. The Sprint network has been excellent on this device with full bars and quick loads of streaming audio and web pages. I’ve made a couple of calls so far. Using the handset to my ear and using on speaker phone has been a pleasant experience. The speaker is loud and clear. I did use the adapter for the headset using the Samsung S8 earbuds and was told there was a lot of ‘noise’, but so far that was with two calls. This is early days so I’ll report back. So far I really really like this phone. It makes me happy. Have questions/thoughts about the Essential? Let me know.
reviews.review_header: I like it - fast, snappy, makes me smile

reviews.review_text: I am an extremely value-conscious shopper when it comes to expensive electronics and, after extensive research, this won my seal of approval. With this phone, you get 2017- early 2018 flagship performance and top-notch hardware at a price that compares favorably to alternatives (Samsung Galaxy S8/9, HTC U11, Google Pixel 2/XL, LG V30, Moto Z2 Force, etc.). The main competitor at this price point is the OnePlus 5T, which offers some advantages including a UI with more features, a polished camera app, larger screen, more RAM, and a headphone jack. However, the essential phone overall has a more premium feel with the materials used, and a beautiful bezel-less display that helps 'future-proof' the phone (based on the mobile world congress this year, a lot of phones are heading in that direction), and more storage. The 'Halo Gray' variant also has a nice matte finish on the back that is easy to grip and not as much of a fingerprint magnet as the ceramic. If you are looking for a phone that has good enough performance for most things look at options below $400 like Honor 7X, Moto G or X series, HTC U11 Life. Options coming to the US this year include the Nokia 6 (2018) and possibly ASUS Zenfone 5 (unclear if releasing in the US). Or you could get a used flaghsip phone, but that of course has its risks.
Very well made. Better at reducing fingerprints than the black.
reviews.review_header: Better at reducing fingerprints than the black

reviews.review_text: Great all around phone. With the updat to oreo 8.1 in beta all of the issues are gone. The camera still isnt the best in the market, the camera app its awfully oversimplistic, but overall a great phone.

Early report will update over time. Initial setup went well and copied over my normal setup. It wouldn't play back music though. Tried quite a number of things and I ended up doing a factory reset and resetting and installing from scratch. Everything works now and has been quite stable. Early reviews ding the camera but it seems to be working pretty well so far. Phone has been quick and responsive, is fantastically put together. Hardware and quality is excellent for the price. There were number for updates available Essential seems to roll out updates quickly that's a good thing. And no bloat. As stupid as the notch looks initially it disappears in use pretty well.

Absolutely love this phone. It's fast and pure Android. I get monthly updates from Essential and most of them as of late have been cameras improvements. Great phone for the money. Probably my best purchase of 2017

I can tell a lot of love has gone into this phone from the little details starting with the unboxing, to the craftsmanship and their commitment to continuously update & better this product. I got this as backup phone for kids in case one breaks, but I keep using it instead. I have a Note 8 and dont get me wrong, I love my Note, but there's something about the simplicity & feel of the Essential phone that I really like. I look forward to more Essential products in the near future & will consider future Essential phone as primary phone if they continue this trend.

After 3 years with a Samsung S5, it was time to update. I have always been a fan of Android devices so when I saw this I was very interested. So far, I've used this phone for about 2 weeks. The interface is very familiar and easy to navigate. It's simple to customize. I've downloaded all the apps that I've had with ease. I chose the 128GB model and I doubt I will fill even half of it. It feels solid and has a good heft. With the case I purchased for it, I feel as if the phone would survive just about any fall. Overall, it's a great phone. I hope to have this for at least the next 3 years.

I loved the Essential phone! I spent two days setting it all up and then when I was out of WIFI, I realized that no data worked over the air only via Wi-Fi. I read so many negative reviews and I really thought everyone was wrong! The phone itself is the perfect size and hardware was very nice. I want to love this phone but now after two days to configure and 5 plus hours working with Sprint, I am disappointed to say all of my work to configure the phone to my perfection was all for nothing! Sprint put a new sim card in the phone, and since that did not work they said they needed to do a factory reset. All my hard work and feeling of having a phone to my liking was now reset to factory. Now all I have to show for my hard work is a nice phone that is reset that still wont access the internet over the air only via WIFI. I want to love this phone!! But now I must return it. The worst part is the time I spent is lost and now I will be without a phone until I get a new phone. https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0748TWQHK/ref=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_0 Amazon and Essential, please help me to love this phone, it has so much potential. I am posting an update. Amazon provided info for essential support and they contacted me with things to check. Nothing worked. I left them phone off for 8 hours and apparently Sprint reset the Phone on their network. All the issues were Sprint an not the phone. I have changed the rating to four stars. I will update the review after I try the camera. Everthing else beats my I-phone 6 s plus. If all goes well, I will buy another for my wife!!! Amazon or Essential, can we purchase the essentail phone service protection?

The negative buzz surrounding this phone regarding the camera (plus the original price point) was what made me hold off on buying this, but it seems like Essential's pain was my gain. Having seen the price go down $250 (caught this phone when it was down to $450) and the camera undergo many patches I decided to take the plunge. Taking it as it is now (Apr 2018) as opposed to what it was at launch, I can recommend this phone. First off, Android 8.1 runs fast and smooth, very slick as one would demand a (then) cutting edge Snapdragon phone to have. Form factor is amazing - it looks gorgeous and the material weight makes it very tactile without feeling hefty. The matte finish on this helps with my grip, at least. Camera, as per the title, is honestly not that bad. It may be damning with faint praise but I find it fine. You will see it shortcomings upon heavy zoom but in terms of 100% view and ability to be printed out on, say, 7 x 5in it is perfectly serviceable. No phone shoots well in low-light anyway. So yes, a solid first effort for Essential, and with the price drop, the best bang-for-buck premium phone on the market. This phone will last me a while, I feel.
reviews.review_header: Camera's much improved, if initial reviews are to be believed!

reviews.review_text: very good, used for couple of days, really fast, the camera is ok for me, I think it is smoother than my wife's samsung s8, the system is cool, it's a real google phone comparing with pixel, I don't know why so many people had bad issues...,btw,$400 with 360 camera, nonthing I can complain of.
reviews.review_header: very good, used for couple of days

reviews.review_text: Build quality is top notch, software is slowly but surely improving. Speedy and with the latest updates, touch, camera and overall user experience has improved drastically. I have a feeling once this phone moves to oreo, it will finally live up to its initial flagship status.
reviews.review_header: It's almost a flagship for almost half the cost.

reviews.review_text: I purchased this phone when reviews were just so-so, but after the price dropped to $500, I figured I'd take a risk and purchased this phone. It definitely paid off, as I've been using this phone for over a month now, and I am in love with this device. I switched over to Android in August of 2017 after using iPhones for over 6 years. I needed a phone and purchased the Moto g4 play because it was the cheapest phone I could get that day. I got tired of the slow processor and limited RAM on that phone, but I didn't want to Shell out $700+ on a phone just to get the latest and greatest. When I first got this phone, it seemed quite buggy and would completely freeze up from time to time, but after many software updates, including camera app updates, this is my favorite device out of any I have ever used. I use this phone for everything, from streaming movies to doing homework to taking pictures, and I couldn't be more impressed. I love how there is no bloatware on this phone and no logos on it whatsoever. Here are the pros and cons of this device from my point of view: Pros: +No Bloatware - The Essential Ph-1 is as stock Android as it gets ((even moreso than Pixel phones). The launcher is the stock Android launcher (launcher3), which does not offer much in terms of customization. All of the apps that come with this device are needed to function properly, and you can customize your experience to suit your individual needs. +Bezel-less Design - Yes, there is a small bezel along the bottom of the screen, but I have found that it is actually beneficial for avoiding accidental screen touches. +Premium Feel - I have never held a phone that feels this good in my hands. I use a case when I am out and about, but I take it off while at home or work just to enjoy the feel of this phone. The smoothness of the titanium and ceramic coupled with the added weight of the phone make it feel special. Even the haptic feedback feels better than in other devices I've used. The vibrations are audible in silent rooms, but it has a great feel to it. Many of my friends with other Android phones like the feel so much that they will play with my phone just to feel the haptic feedback. It's small things like this that make the Essential phone truly enjoyable to use. +The Camera - While this phone started off with terrible camera performance, the many updates to the camera app have caused me to truly enjoy taking pictures. While its camera performance isn't as good as that of the iPhone X, I am able to take better pictures on the Essential Ph-1 than my coworker can on his Pixel XL(first gen). The front-facing camera performs better than any other phone I've used as well. With the latest camera app update, portrait mode is now enabled, and low-light image quality is greatly improved, which puts this camera near the top in terms of performance. +Magnetic Attachments - While there is only one out at the moment, more are said to come in the future. I use the 360 degree camera attachment quite often and am quite pleased with the results. As soon as you attach it, the camera app opens and allows you to take a picture or video. The results so far have been better than I expected. Cons: -No Headphone Port - While this is a big deal for some people, I only use Bluetooth for audio, so it doesn't bother me. It is an unfortunate compromise for some, but most phone companies are abandoning this feature, giving consumers little choice in the matter. If you want to use wired headphones, the dongle included in the box works well. -Lack of Waterproofing - While many newer phones are water resistant, the Essential phone forgoes this feature. This doesn't bother me for a couple of reasons: 1. I never use phones in and around the water, and 2. Water resistance can be compromised by scratches, dents, or cracks on certain parts of the device. -No Expandable Storage - This also doesn't bother me because I will never even fill up the 128gb of internal storage, but for those that would like this option, you're out of luck with this phone. -No Wireless Charging - While Essential is supposedly working on a charging dock that connects via the magnetic pins, it doesn't support wireless charging on the Qi standard, which is an inconvenience for those who are used to this feature. -Smooth Design - While it feels great to hold in your hand, the smooth design of this phone means that it will easily slide off smooth surfaces (like pants), so putting this phone on your lap without a case could lead to an unfortunate fall. Therefore, I would recommend using a case (or skin of you want to keep things minimalistic) in order to add some texture to the ceramic back. -Limited Selection of Device Protection - While there are more cases and screen protectors out now than a month ago, there aren't as many options as there are for other devices. There is one tempered glass screen protector that covers the whole screen without having a halo effect, but its weak adhesion allows the case to push it off. The limited selection of cases is mostly due to the limited amount of these phones initially sold, but Essential is partially to blame for claiming this phone doesn't need a case to withstand drops. There have been drop tests conducted with this phone that show the phone is not impervious to falls, so a case is a must in my opinion. While there are some downsides to this phone that may deter some people from purchasing it, the Essential Ph-1 is a truly great device, especially when you consider that this is the company's first phone. If $500 is too much for you to spend on a phone, and you live in the US, Sprint is currently offering the device for a great price ($25 down and $5 a month for an 18 month flex lease) if you want this phone but aren't sure you want to buy the device outright, and right now, they have a promotion offering the 360 degree camera free with a lease or purchase. If you are an Android enthusiast that isn't bothered by the cons presented in this review, this phone is definitely worth looking into!
reviews.review_header: I took a risk purchasing this phone, but it paid off

reviews.review_text: Just arrived yesterday—my initial thought is that at the sale price ($399), the Essential Phone is a technological and design marvel. It feels great, looks great, has an extremely snappy Snapdragon 835, and the screen is crisp and responsive. I'll still playing around and customizing, so I'll probably update my review soon, but so far this is easily the best phone I've ever owned and brand new costs less than half of other flagships.
reviews.review_header: A marvel of phone technology and design (at the current price)

reviews.review_text: Haven't experienced any of the issues that some have mentioned about the phone. Only concern on unboxing was its inability to stay connected to wifi for more than five seconds (which makes it impossible to set up). Strangely, but fortunately, rebooting my router fixed the problem, and ever since it's connected without fail. It's fast and has worked flawlessly. Just upgraded to Oreo 8.1. The camera has produced a few pictures that could be better, particularly in very bright light, but the monochrome camera is excellent. Also I use Lightroom and that's a great way to use the camera's sensor but not the Essential software. Certainly heavier than previous phones I've owned, especially the iphone 6, but then again it won't bend like an iphone 6. As others have noted, it's extremely well built. At Amazon's price, it's a great value for a premium phone.
reviews.review_header: A five star experience so far

reviews.review_text: Excellent phone. I've been using it for over a month now and am constantly impressed. The hardware is top notch, extremely high quality build and feel and flawless performance. The camera is the only downside but it has been improved a lot through updates to the point where I don't feel like it is a sacrifice anymore. The form factor is perfect - enough screen to do anything on but just small enough to use with one hand. This was really important to me and this phone has delivered where no others have. Handling of the phone is very good too, the square edged frame has a beveled edge that is a matte finish which really helps with grip. The software is excellent and updates consistent. I get security updates every month a day before my partner's pixel 2 does.

Well built smartphone. Looks beautiful and is attractive. Feels solid in hand. Speed tests both on wifi and cellular network exceed other flagship devices. Battery life comparable to the best ones. After software updates, the cameras take nice pics. 360 degree cam is a bonus. Quality leaves almost nothing to be desired. Stock Android and guaranteed updates are added incentives. Generous 128 GB capacity. Almost half the price of competitors. Couldn't be happier with this thing.

TOP phone in 2017. Out of the box the phone had some software issues but Essential has been pushing updates at an amazing rate. Already on Beta Oreo 8.1 and its solid. Camera issues doesn't bother me but I know that was a concern for many in the past. I recently purchased the 360 camera so I cannot wait for the first family vacation to play with it.
reviews.review_header: Top 2017 Smartphone! Great support from Essential. What else do you need!

reviews.review_text: Yes, there are much bigger things in life than having a good phone but this is a good phone, a great phone actually. I remember hearing about this phone last year and then became disappointed to hear that the phone was buggy and also quite expansive. Now after all the software updates and the drop in price, I must say that if you considering buying a new phone, this is the one. Once I got it, there was a notification to upgrade the phone to Android Oreo 8.0 which of course, I did. The phone is very fast with the SnapDragon 835 processor and 4 Gb's of Ram. The 128 Gb for storage is very nice too. The screen and camera have both been brilliant (thought the screen could be brighter). Sound is nice and loud. Fingerprint scanner is placed well. So I guess what I am saying is that after all the updates, this is an excellent fast phone with plenty of storage for the price (right now below $500).
reviews.review_header: Excellent fast phone with plenty of storage for the price!

reviews.review_text: Horrible Quality Control on an otherwise nice design o_0 1st unit (on the right) had terrible connectivity issues, especially with Wi-Fi, with no definitive information if it is hardware, software, or both. 2nd unit (on the left) has what is called "light bleed" on this LCD panel which is something I Am unfamiliar with, I received a notification and thought my screen was broke, downloaded a screen test app to confirm, what I was seeing on the ambient screen, or even watching a video, it is pretty distracting and discomfort when viewing. This is severe light bleed not minor at all. Very noticeable. Tried requesting return but since this was already a replacement that isn't an option, only thing to do is return for refund.
reviews.review_header: Bad Quality Control, skip this generation...

reviews.review_text: I have been using my Essential on Verizon for several months now, absolutely no issues! I love the clean system, and all my apps function perfectly. What a great buy this was; I know my next phone will be another Essential. My previous phone was a Samsung S5, and I simply could not justify paying the S8 price. After months of searching and research, I decided on the Essential, and at $350 with the camera, I could not pass it up.

*** UPDATE *** 4/21/18 Two days after receiving the phone and struggling to get the phone to work with straighttalk verizon, I figured out that if I turn the wifi off and restart the phone, my LTE capabilities are enabled and the APN in the phone is updated. Not sure why it couldn't update when it was connected to WiFi. For some reason,the phone wasn't updating the APN correctly and in the new oreo update you can't add or edit APNs unless you root the phone (which voids the warranty), but I did it anyway and even editing the APN didn't work. I also had to go get a new SIM card because according to straighttalk, only one SIM can be registered to one IMEI. I didn't know that, but I am still able to put the NEW SIM back into my old S7 and it works fine.. not sure about that one. It may also be worth mentioning that I tried to take the phone to Verizon yesterday (4/20) and they were unable to add the phone to their prepaid network using its IMEI. He tried it three times but said their system was being weird that day so maybe I was just having a stroke of bad luck. Maybe straighttalk changed the way the operate over the past year or two, not sure because I have had the S7 since it came out and that's the last SIM I had to buy. Just be prepared to have this problem if you are trying to swap the sims and expecting it to work. Enjoying the phone like I should be now, just had some minor hiccups with the service provider. As promised, I took some low light pictures in the bar and of my dogs in my dark bedroom. The camera is not the best in low light situations, but I rarely take photos at night so this isn't really a problem for me as I have a photography camera that is much more well suited for things of that nature. The phone is 250$ cheaper than the Pixel 2 as of right now so you can expect somewhat of a quality difference between cameras, but this phone looks sharper and feels really solid. I don't take a lot of bar pictures because I'm usually drunk and forget, so again that really isn't a problem for me. I read some reviews about the fingerprint scanner being bad, but mine unlocks faster than my mom's iPhone 8 and my old S7, it's almost instant. If my finger is on the scanner and I hit the power button, it unlocks immediately. The only complaint I have is the phone isn't waterproof. I've never needed it on any other phone, but it's nice to not have to worry about accidental splashes. *ORIGINAL REVIEW* 4/18/18 Love the phone, super snappy, looks awesome and feels like a quality device. The only thing that originally stopped me from getting the phone sooner was all the reviews of the camera, which in my experience is awesome. Front facing camera looks amazing, as well as the rear camera. Photos in well lit areas look good, don't think the camera is as sharp in low light as the Pixel 2 though. I'm coming from a galaxy S7 and this takes better pictures than my girlfriends iPhone 7 and my moms iPhone 8, can't compare it to the X though because I don't know anyone with it so I just youtubed comparison videos and they are all on par with each other. If the camera reviews are stopping you from buying, don't worry, it looks great. Haven't had the chance to take low light bar selfies due to finals but I plan to this weekend so I will update the original review with my opinion. The phone is also super slick, so you will definitely want to get a case. I got the Poetic Guardian case with the plastic front screen protector and it covers the entire phone well. Couldn't find a glass screen protector so I had to go with the all-in-one combo. Display looks awesome outside in sunlight even though it isn't OLED. No problems seeing it inside a plastic screen case with sunlight directly on it. There is a major issue with the phone though. My service works completely fine (straighttalk - verizon sim) on my unlocked galaxy S7, which I have actually switched back to because of service problems. I have factory reset, updated, factory reset, and updated again, and I still can't get straighttalk to work on this phone. Putting the sim card back in my S7 gives me instant service, I can browse fine, and there are no problems. I'm not an idiot, and actually really want to like this phone, but I can't because it isn't a phone, its a 400$ camera/paperweight. I even changed the APN multiple times on the device, disabled enhanced LTE per instruction of a reddit thread to no avail. It gets onto wifi fine and downloads updates, but it will not connect to my mobile service for web-browsing, I can however make calls. This device needs far more work, it could have been a really great device but I feel it's rushed. I will most likely be sending this back to Amazon and purchasing a Pixel 2 or Pixel 2 XL. For now, I'm using my broke screen galaxy S7 because at least it works lol

I've had this two months, last phone was a Moto X Pure. What's better about the Essential: Battery lasts much longer. All day even with heavy screen use. I read a lot of books using Kindle app and Overdrive. Charges fast with the supplied charger. Also can get rapid charge with my older USB Quick charger using a USB C adapters, which are cheap to buy. Essential pushes security updates and other Android fixes regularly, at least once a month. Screen is awesome. Big, clear and bright. Cons: no show stoppers for me. Not having headphone jack is minor, you get an adapter w the phone. It is heavier than other phones, but not like it's a brick. I recommend a case, not to protect so much as because the phone is super slippery, I guess it's the ceramic.

This phone checks all the boxes for me: 4GB of RAM, 128GB of storage, a good camera setup, beautiful screen, and great battery life. I mainly listen to music on my phone and don't deal with a bunch of apps or take huge amount of pictures, so on that front, is where I'll start. There is no 3.5mm headphone jack, but Essential includes a USB C to 3.5mm adapter in the box. You won't be missing your old headphones with this. The audio quality, if anything, short of a good external dac and a $250+ set of headphones (none of which I'd want to carry with me). A good quality set of buds, the adapter, and the phone are all I need - the expensive stuff stays at home, in the office/lounge. The audio quality is great for what is expected with a cellphone these days - no cutouts, no distortion, just good deep audio (when using good buds or headphones). Note, that you can't charge and listen at the same time (which I've never done prior to this anyway). As for performance - I play a few games; GTA: SA and KOTOR run perfectly, along with some emulation. This phone has handled everything I throw at it, and well. The battery life, with a little tweaking easily lasts me 3.5 to 4 days, with around 5-6 hours of screen on time, easily as long distance as my E4 plus was but with better performance in apps I use.
